PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 11.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 32 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 37 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

PARA.TAB: Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Fee Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee from time to time asks Ministers to nominate officials from the relevant department to attend meetings to assist its deliberations. In this case the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, not only sent along one of the most senior officials in this particular area, but also one of his own staff members. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
STATEMENT OF WORK OF COMMITTEE DURING BUDGET SITTINGS 1991

1)The work of the Committee during the present sittings involved the scrutiny of the usual large number of instruments of delegated legislation tabled in the Senate and subject to disallowance. Such delegated legislation was made under the authority of scores of parent Acts administered through every Department of State. It was made by the Governor-General, by Ministers, by officials, by statutory authorities and by courts and tribunals. Virtually every legislative scheme relies on delegated legislation to fill in administrative details of its operation, without which public administration would not be possible.

2)The Committee acts on behalf of the Senate itself to scrutinise each of these instruments to ensure that they conform to the high standards of parliamentary propriety and personal liberties which the Parliament applies to Acts. Where the Committee detects what appears to be a defect in delegated legislation it writes to the Minister asking that the instrument be amended or other action taken. In cases of a serious breach of propriety or liberties, the Committee reports to the Senate and places a protective notice of disallowance upon the instrument, in case the Committee should wish to recommend such action. However, this final sanction is rarely invoked. Almost invariably the Minister agrees to take action, often including amendment, to meet the concerns of the Committee.

3)During these sittings Ministers and other law makers have undertaken to amend 23 instruments or parent Acts to satisfy the Committee. This does not include undertakings to take administrative action or to provide numbering and citation for instruments. This illustrates the high level of cooperation which the Committee receives from Ministers in its non-partisan operations.

4)During the sittings the Committee scrutinised 778 instruments, which is historically a high number. Of these, only 263 were from the Statutory Rules series, which are generally of a higher quality than other series. The rest of the instruments were the usual heterogeneous collection of ordinances, declarations, determinations, directions, rules, orders, plans, deeds, guidelines, notices, exemptions, licences, standards, codes of conduct, specifications and approvals.

5)Each one of these instruments was scrutinised by the Committee under its four Principles, or terms of reference, which are provided for in the Standing Orders. The Committee detected prima facie defects in 94 out of the 778 instruments which it scrutinised. These defects are described below under each of the four Principles.
Is delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?

6)This Principle covers every aspect of parliamentary propriety. It is not merely a narrow legal check of technical validity. Nevertheless, the first requirement under this Principle is that delegated legislation should not have any technical or other defects apparent on its face. In this context an instrument will be defective if its drafting, presentation and access is less than that of an Act. In one instrument a commencement provision was left blank. In another a provision referred to an activity prohibited by paragraph (a) but there was no such paragraph. Another contained two provisions with the same number. One set of regulations contained 10 separate cross-reference errors. Two more instruments provided for review of non-existing provisions. One instrument was ineffective because it was tabled without a Schedule. Another had wrong attachments, another missing attachments. One regulation included blocks of ages numbered "25 to 30", "30 to 35", "35 to 40" and so on. One instrument mentioned two Australian towns, each with five separate entries in the Australia Post Postcode, without indicating to which State the provision referred. One substituted copy of an instrument corrected an error in the first copy, but itself made another error. A number of instruments included spelling errors, including one in an international treaty. Another misspelt the name of a large Australian regional city. One instrument gave the wrong date for a consolidation. On the other hand, another instrument amended the principal instrument for the 344th time, but with a consolidation.

7)It is a breach of parliamentary propriety if changes in taxes, levies, fees, charges or allowances are not explained. One instrument doubled an allowance paid to public servants, another doubled a particular fee. Another substituted an allowance with an identical sum. The same instrument increased one allowance for public servants from $382.78 to $382.79 and another from $382.79 to $382.80. Here the Committee was concerned that the public servants might be left without a penny to spend.

8)Delegated legislation must effect an intention evident on its face or advised in the Explanatory Statement. One instrument prescribed a levy of 0.25 cents per unit. However, the Explanatory Statement twice advised that the purpose of the instrument was to prescribe 0.0025 cents and that the maximum permissible amount of levy under the parent Act was 0.0025 cents. Another Explanatory Statement advised that the purpose of the instrument was to allocate States Grants money to one State and one Territory, whereas the instrument allocated money to three States and two Territories. Another advised that the intention of the instrument was to allocate a stated sum of States Grants money, but the instrument allocated a different sum. Another Explanatory Statement advised that the instrument was intended to provide only for officers of the Department to be authorised officers, although the instrument itself provided for any person at all.

9)Delegated legislation often provides for public officials to delegate powers granted to them by that delegated legislation. Such delegation must be appropriate in all the circumstances. In one instrument, important powers could be exercised as delegates by certain senior officers, who were carefully and properly limited by rank. However, the power to appoint such officers could be delegated to any person at all. In another case a statutory authority could determine conditions to which certain standards were subject. This was virtually the same as determining the standards themselves. In another instrument one class of persons, for whom no qualifications or experience were prescribed, could appoint another class of persons for whom there were such requirements. In addition, the first class of persons could delegate most of their powers.

10)The general scheme of delegated legislation may be so unusual on its face that the Committee will write to the Minister. In one instrument the Explanatory Statement advised that the instrument repealed regulations dealing with an international organisation of which Australia had ceased to be a member in 1980. Conversely, another instrument effected arrangements under an international treaty signed four years before. In another case, two separate but related series of delegated legislation had not been synchronised.

11)The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that delegated legislation which operates to the prejudice of any person other than the Commonwealth is of no effect. Many instruments of delegated legislation do operate retrospectively and in every case the Committee requires an assurance that no member of the public is adversely affected. In one case the Minister was unable to give such an assurance but advised that the parent Act expressly provided for such prejudice. The Committee then asked for a special Report from its Legal Adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan, who concluded that, on balance, the Act could be said to have this effect. In another case there was apparent prejudicial retrospectivity affecting livelihood. In another there was possible prejudice because an instrument was expressed to commence on the date of another which may have commenced earlier.

12)Every instrument of delegated legislation should be accompanied by an Explanatory Statement giving the background to the instrument and explaining its provisions. One instrument did not have an Explanatory Statement, although it dealt with the recovery of public money. Another Explanatory Statement did not advise that one of the purposes of the instrument was to implement undertakings given by the Minister to the Committee. Another Explanatory Statement gave incorrect references to provisions in the parent Act. Other Explanatory Statements were similarly brief, incomplete or inaccurate. In a related area, some instruments had no numbering or citation, without which delegated legislation may be confusing and imprecise.

13)The Committee questioned other instruments which may have breached parliamentary propriety. One of these was so uncertain and subjective in its effect that it may have been defective. Another provided for notices which may have been legislative or partly legislative in effect and yet were not subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Does delegated legislation trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties?

SPEECH.PARA: 14)The Committee interprets this principle in a broad and expanding fashion to ensure that delegated legislation does not operate adversely on any aspect of personal rights or liberties.

15)From time to time delegated legislation fills in details of the administration of elections. Such details must provide full safeguards both for those standing for election and for those voting. One instrument provided that any voter may request a secret ballot. However, there was no requirement for voters to be informed of this right, although there was extensive provisions for them to be informed of other, seemingly less important, rights. Another provision required a voter to place the number "1" in a box to indicate his or her preference. Nevertheless, another provision merely required the voter to indicate an intention, which appeared to indicate that a tick or a cross, a "yes" or an "aye" might be a valid vote. Another provision required only that the winner of an election be notified. There was no requirement for the losing candidates or even for the general body of voters to be informed, even though other information, such as a list of candidates, had to be publicly notified.

16)The Committee looks closely at any offence provisions. Every sittings delegated legislation includes a number of strict liability offences, each one of which is questioned by the Committee. One such strict liability offence related to duties of employers. Another instrument replaced general offence provisions with specific penalties for each offence. This was an appropriate change, particularly as most offences, which had previously been strict liability, were now provided with a defence of reasonable excuse. Nevertheless, some provisions were still strict liability. Furthermore, there seemed to be no obvious reason why some of these provided for such liability, as they included offences for which a reasonable excuse would seem suitable. For instance, one strict liability offence did not take account of adverse weather conditions which would make it impossible to comply with the provision. Another instrument provided for vicarious liability, with adverse mandatory consequences affecting a person's livelihood flowing from such liability. This vicarious liability was imposed on the owner of a boat used previously to commit an offence, even if the offence had been committed when the boat had a previous owner. One instrument dealing with drug trafficking and the confiscation of the proceeds of drug trafficking seemed to provide for strict enforcement measures, although these may have been justifiable given the nature of the subject matter.

17)Discriminatory legislation is a breach of personal rights and the Committee insists on a full explanation of such provisions. One instrument provided that the working age for males is up to 65 years while for females it is up to 60 years. Another expressly provided for factors such as nationality, sex, age and marital status to be taken into account when making decisions. Another included provisions which may have disadvantaged Australian companies in favour of foreign companies.

18)Delegated legislation must not unreasonably affect a person's livelihood. The Committee not only ensures that decisions by public officials affecting livelihood are subject to appropriate review, but also that mandatory provisions do not operate adversely. One instrument appeared to provide that if a cheque from an applicant for an extension of a commercial privilege was dishonoured, then that privilege would automatically terminate. Another provided for methods of labelling which raised concerns about unnecessary costs imposed upon smaller producers. Numbers of recent instruments have provided for the facsimile transmission of mandatory information to public officials in place of existing manual methods. This is an appropriate change which should assist users. However, such changes should not prejudice smaller businesses who may wish to continue to use existing methods. The Committee questioned one instrument which provided for transmission of a form by post but for amendments of the form by facsimile.

19)The right to privacy is an important aspect of personal liberties. Delegated legislation must not intrude on this right. The Committee suggested that exemptions from the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988 should be expressed more clearly. Again, the Committee questioned another instrument which omitted two of the 11 Information Privacy Principles provided by that Act. Conversely, the Committee raised a provision which seemed to exclude the public from important provisions of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 for a period of five years.

20)The Committee was concerned at a number of other provisions. One doubled a fee with no explanation. Another operated with prejudicial retrospectivity. Both of these breached personal rights as well as parliamentary propriety. Another instrument appeared to provide for a person to elect under its provisions before the provisions came into effect. On a lighter note, one instrument provided for "sentencing". The Committee was immediately alert to the need for appropriate safeguards. However, the Explanatory Statement explained that sentencing in this case was the archival process of classifying records according to the period for which each record is to be kept.
Does delegated legislation make rights unduly dependent on administrative decisions which are not subject to independent review of their merits?

21)Many instruments of delegated legislation grant discretions to Ministers or public officials. Such discretions should be drafted as narrowly as possible, include objective criteria to limit and guide the exercise of the power, and in appropriate cases provide a right of review of the merits of the decision to an independent, external tribunal, which usually would be the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

22)During the sittings one instrument gave a discretion to a public official to withdraw an infringement notice, with no apparent right of review. The Committee raised this with the Minister even though there were criteria provided to guide and limit the exercise of the power. The same instrument also provided a discretion to extend the time available for payment of a fine, again with no obvious right of review. Another discretion with no apparent review was to cancel certain numbers allocated to private individuals, with consequential adverse commercial implications. In another class of case the Committee questioned discretions granted to an electoral official to admit or reject votes and to declare an election void. In another case the Committee asked for an assurance that there was AAT review of conditions attached to a decision, as well as to the decision itself. In one case the Committee was dissatisfied with an instrument which, while it provided for AAT review, did not provide for the applicant to state a case before the decision was made. The Committee also followed the progress of the review provisions of principal regulations and associated specialist review regulations which had been first made and then amended some 41 times in the 24 months to the end of the present sittings.
Does delegated legislation contain matters more appropriate for parliamentary enactment?

23)This Principle is not often raised by the Committee. Nevertheless, it is an important element of parliamentary propriety. The only instrument which may have been defective under this Principle provided for decisions to be made by officials on the grounds of nationality, sex, age and marital status. As well as being a possible breach of personal liberties, the Committee considered that such unusual provisions could be more suited for inclusion in an Act.

24)The most important future development in Commonwealth delegated legislation is the Administrative Review Council Report on Rule Making by Commonwealth Agencies, which is expected to be presented to the Minister this month. The Committee has already reported to the Senate on the Terms of Reference of the inquiry, on the Committee's submission to the inquiry and on the Interim Report by the ARC. It was very pleasing that the ARC accepted all of the main points put to it by the Committee. If the final Report is along the same lines and is implemented then Commonwealth delegated legislation will be made within a single series, include all legislation properly so called, be properly drafted and presented, and have appropriate access. The Chair of the Committee has reported to the Senate several times that the implementation of these points would represent the greatest reform of delegated legislation since the passage of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Earlier this month members of the Committee had the opportunity of discussing these issues with members of the ARC at a dinner held here in Parliament House. These gatherings, which have become regular affairs held every two years, are an opportunity for the legislative scrutiny Committees to meet informally with the ARC, the peak Commonwealth body concerned with review of administrative decisions. The Committee will, of course, report in detail to the Senate when the final Report is available.

25)During the sittings there was another significant development in the operations of the Committee. From time to time the Committee asks Ministers whether senior officials of the Department could attend meetings to assist in its deliberation on particular instruments. This was done recently in respect of a sensitive instrument; the Committee asking the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator the Hon Michael Tate, to nominate a senior official to attend a meeting. The Minister not only sent a Senior Executive Service officer from the Department, but also a member of his personal staff. It is not known whether this has ever been done before, but certainly it is an innovation for present members of the Committee. This is a good example of the willingness of Ministers to cooperate with the Committee to ensure that delegated legislation is of the highest quality.

26)Finally, the Committee was pleased to note a generous description of its work. Opening a public seminar on delegated legislation the Acting Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Norman Reaburn, observed that the operations of the Committee were "vital to maintaining the integrity of the law of this country". That was a gratifying comment from such a senior official.
27)The Committee is grateful for the continuing support it has received from all Senators during the past sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)notes that, after nearly nine years of Labor Government and the call by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for a `clever country', no programs have ever been develop by the Government to assist gifted children; and
(b)condemns the Government for its boasts that it will destroy the Coalition's `Fightback' package which will help to meet the needs of those children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that —

(a)on Friday, 13 December 1991, six Victorian unions, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association (ATEA), Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union, Hospital Employees Federation (No. 1 Branch), Electrical Trades Union, Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association and the Vehicle Builders Employee's Federation of Australia (Vic. Branch), joined with the Australian Democrats, the Rainbow Alliance, some Green groups and the New Left Party in a statement demanding that the Australian Government adopt a more interventionist economic strategy designed to boost industry and employment and setting out the strategies required to achieve this; and
(b)that the ATEA, at a special meeting on 13 November 1991, passed, among others, the following resolutions (4d and e):

TAB.TAB: To aim to build support for independent politicians and/or candidates from the Australian Democrats with the specific aim of building a parliamentary force which will form a barrier against and opposition to the right-wing legislation and actions of governments thrown up by the two major political parties.
To continue to work to build a new political base for `peoples action' through a coalition of unions and like-minded community organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Soviet Union, which has held the free world to the ransom of a nuclear holocaust for much of the post-war period, will be dissolved at the end of 1991, and
(ii)the ideology of communism which has held the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics together under a bond of terror has collapsed and led to the dissolution of the union;

PARA.TAB: (b)welcomes the victory of freedom over totalitarianism and calls upon Australia and the international community to accept the former Soviet Republics as independent states, and to accept their sovereign wish to form a commonwealth; and

(c)recognises the pain and stress being experienced in both the transition from totalitarianism to democracy and from a command to a market economy, and calls upon Australia and the international community to support these difficult processes which will not only benefit the peoples of the former Soviet Union, but also have the potential to lead to a more productive and safer world.

The Committee's priority during the Budget sittings has been its report on the employment of people with disabilities, its inquiry into the implementation of pharmaceutical restructuring measures and its consideration of three Bills which were referred to it. The Committee will report by 24 March 1992.
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes that, after nearly nine years of a Labor Government, there is no provision for a Medicare rebate for densitometry;
(b)deplores the fact that the Government has not given greater importance to achieving early diagnosis of osteoporosis for older women; and
(c)condemns the Government for its boast that it will destroy the Coalition's `Fightback' package which will meet the needs of these women.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)applauds the dissolution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics at midnight on 31 December 1991 and, thereby, the final demise of the `evil empire' of Soviet Communism; and

(b)notes the horrors perpetrated by successive Governments of that Union until the rule of President Gorbachev and expresses the hope that the new Commonwealth of Independent States will deliver an era of peace and prosperity to the oppressed people of the former Soviet Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)condemns the Government for the closure of the Family Court Counselling Service for the Gold Coast;

(b)acknowledges that the removal of this service is going to hurt those who are already victims and who lack the knowledge and understanding required to seek out other services appropriate to their needs; and
(c)calls on the Government to reinstate this fundamentally necessary service immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes that, after nearly nine years of Labor Government, Australia is the only country that taxes the superannuation of workers thrice; and
(b)condemns the Government for its boasts that it will destroy the Coalition's `Fightback' package which will remove the tax on lump sums up to $300 000.

TALK.START.PARA: — I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE), on 17 December 1991, forecast that the gloomy outlook for Australia's commodity exports has worsened, with exports expected to fall in value by 5 per cent to $390.8 billion in 1991-92, and
(ii)ABARE predicts that the drought and weak commodity prices will hit the rural sector harder than previously estimated;

PARA.TAB: (b)further notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)comments made by the former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, at a press conference on 5 December 1991, called to discuss the national accounts when he said he `knew the farm result would be bad, but when framing the budget in August 1991, policy makers had been unaware just how long the drought plaguing south-eastern Australia would last',

(ii)that, prior to becoming Treasurer earlier in 1991, Mr Kerin had been Minister for Primary Industries and Energy since 1983 and should have had ample knowledge and awareness of the extent of the rural downturn, which has been steadily growing for a number of years, and

(iii)that the national accounts figures, which included drops in sugar and wool production, do not reflect the extent of the failure of winter cereal crops, which will not show up until the December 1991 quarter national accounts; and

PARA.TAB: (c)urgently draws to the attention of the current Treasurer (Mr Willis), or whoever will be Treasurer at the time of the proposed economic statement early in 1992, to take particular note of these current forecasts by ABARE so that he will not fail to take account of this situation when framing the statement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)notes that, after nearly nine years of Labor Government, no recognition has been given to the need for special training for nurses who have to work in isolated areas of Australia to provide health care to Aboriginal communities and for other isolated Australians without adequate medical assistance; and
(b)condemns the Government for its boast that it will destroy the Coalition's `Fightback' package which will meet the needs of those isolated Australians and their nurses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)expresses its deep distress at the plight of the Samoan people due to the devastation of Cyclone Val;

(b)both welcomes and condemns the Australian Government's contribution of $500 000 in emergency aid as an important humanitarian reaction to a country in crisis, and as a woefully small amount in relation to the $1 million it is prepared to spend to recall Parliament for the visit of just one person, President Bush;
(c)notes that supplies of both food and medicines are now critically low in Samoa; and
(d)urges the Government to increase the amount of financial aid and to offer to send Australian troops and medical personnel to assist as required by the Samoan authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes the comments about the ailing health of the economy made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that:

TAB.TAB: (i)he is dubious about whether the Budget forecast for investment in plant and equipment would be reached even though the Budget contains the already pessimistic estimate of an 8 per cent decline,
(ii)the non-dwelling construction was a particularly hard hit sector of the economy, and

(iii)the high level of unemployment was an argument for slackening the pace on structural change in the economy, because measures such as tariff cuts and micro-economic reform to increase productivity had compounded the effects of the recession; and

PARA.TAB: (b)deplores the Government's failure to implement economic policies which promote appropriate economic measures for Australia and thus enhance the living standards of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)expresses regret at the recent tragic and untimely death of Australian conductor, Stuart Challender;

(b)notes that, during his lifetime, Stuart Challender devoted a great deal of his time towards establishing the Sydney Symphony Orchestra as one of the world's finest and most respected orchestras; and

(c)notes that Stuart Challender's performances will remain an inspiration to many musicians and that his legacy of sound and video recordings will bear future testimony to his outstanding musical abilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the latest ABARE figures which confirm that farm incomes have been slashed by a massive 75 per cent in 1991,
(ii)that this is a disaster of massive proportions,

(iii)that it is suggested that recovery is unlikely before the second half of 1992, which will simply be too late for hundreds, and maybe thousands, of farmers who are bankrupt, financially and emotionally, and

(iv)that the Liberal and National parties have been desperately trying to tell the Federal Government for the last 2 years that farmers were under precedented financial pressures that were not merely a result of bad management or low commodity prices; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns this selfish, self-serving, naval gazing Labor Government which is so arrogantly pre-occupied with who should become General Custer that is has failed to see that a significant sector in our economy has been ruined by their disastrous high interest rate policies.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)congratulates Mr David Hill upon his re-election as President of the North Sydney `Bears' Rugby League Club, and for his highly principled stand in opposition to tobacco advertising and the sponsorship of sport by tobacco companies;

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, no mention has been made of the fact that the Opposition members of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure have presented a dissenting report, which was supposed to have been attached to the Committee's report. The Opposition members of the Committee successfully moved a motion, after listening to six hours of contributions from representatives of transport industries right around Australia. The resulting resolution adopted by the Committee reads:

PARA.TAB: That the Committee recommends that the Senate not proceed with the National Road Transport Commission Bill, because of the failure of the Government to adequately answer questions raised in evidence before the Committee as to the impact of the legislation, unless and until the Interim National Road Transport Commission examines and publicly reports on—

SPEECH.PARA: 1.the economic and social impact of full cost recovery of road costs on rural and regional Australia;
2.all input taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry;
3.the likely level of Road Charges and Road Use Charges on various operators.
and the Committee has had time to consider the Interim Commission's Report.

This morning we attended a meeting called by the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and we were given a copy of a draft report which was to be presented this morning. Of course, this morning the numbers at the Committee were different and our recommendation was overturned.

PARA.TAB: I suppose I do not object to the Government members on the Committee using the numbers if they have them. But what I do object to very strongly—and I said so at the Committee this morning—is that this was done after we had listened to six hours of informed submissions from representatives of the transport industry coming from all round Australia. We had submissions from L. Arthur Pty Ltd; BHP Transport; the Hon. F. Finch, Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works; the National Freight Forwarders Association; and the Victorian Road Transport Association Inc.

Appearances were made not only by members of the Department—and the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) was in attendance—but also by Mr G. Boulton, National Freight Forwarders Association; the Hon. F. Finch, Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works; Mr B. Fletcher, Fletchers Freighters; Mr G. Goucher, National Farmers Federation, representing all branches of the NFF; Mr R. Gunning and Mr B. McIver, Road Transport Forum; Mr J. McLean, New South Wales Branch of the Transport Workers Union of Australia; Mr J. Pearson, Long Distance Road Transport Association; and Mr R. Seach, of the transport firm of Goodman and Seach.

After the Bill was referred to the Committee we had, at the most, only five days notice that our hearing was to take place. The people representing these transport groups, involving one of the most important industries in Australia and one that affects the costs paid by every Australian, turned up in Canberra within five days. Contrary to what normally occurs, we met on a Wednesday evening—commencing at 8 o'clock and going right through until 2.00 a.m. During that time not one of those witnesses moved from his place. That just demonstrates the importance of the National Road Transport Commission Bill, which has been dropped on the Senate without very much consultation with the industry at all.

So we listened for six hours, Mr President. The problems and fears of imposing full cost recovery around Australia are enormous. There will be an enormous effect on those transport operators—and this is the point that sticks in my throat—without giving this proposed National Road Transport Commission any guidelines to look into what is being paid already. That is what I strongly object to. We will be setting up a commission for new commissioners—interim commissioners are there now—to define and set up a charge to reflect full cost recovery in Australia. They have no guidelines to look at what is already being paid and they have no guidelines to look into the efficiency of road-making in Australia; and from what I can see—especially on the eastern side of the continent—the road-making efficiency is terrible. As I say, they have been given nothing like that; yet here is a Bill that will set up a commission to do those things. We listened to those transport operators for six hours and there is not one mention in this report of what those people submitted or what their concerns are.

TALK.START.PARA: —And supported by the Democrats.
—And supported by the Democrats, of course. Incidentally, now that I mention the Democrats—they chose to ignore the hearing. We had these people from all round Australia—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot knew it was on.
—I did not know that meeting was on.

—Does the honourable senator deny that? I apologise if the honourable senator did not know, but that is not in my hands. I know that the meeting was moved around, but there are highly paid people in this Parliament to advise when meetings are on. So I apologise if I said the honourable senator was not there. In fairness, I rang the staff in Senator Powell's office to see whether she would be there, because I wanted to talk to her about it. Obviously Senator Powell's staff must have had some idea that it was going to be on. If Senator Powell was not going to be there, I presume that she could have sent somebody else.
—You haven't noticed that she was on compassionate leave.

—The staff are still there to do a job. I am sorry about that. I wish the Democrats had had a representative there. I take it that they did not know. If they make that statement, I believe it; I have to believe it, unless I know anything to the contrary. But as I said, Mr President, I rang Senator Powell's office, and there are highly paid officers in this Parliament to make sure that everyone knows when meetings are on. I was very annoyed that the meeting was changed around, and I made it known in the Senate that it was changed around. But these transport operators came from all over Australia with five days notice; at least those in Parliament House could have turned up. The Democrats did not turn up for reasons of their own.

PARA.TAB: Incidentally, this morning the Democrats did not turn up again to deal with the Chairman's draft report. There was a meeting at 10.30 this morning; the Democrats did not turn up there either. So I ask the question: are they interested or not? They purport to represent all Australians. I think they get a third of the vote from country areas, so hopefully in the future they will take more interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think the Democrats are doing?

—All right; I cannot go any further. I am disgusted that there has been no mention of what we were told by these people who came to the meeting for six hours the other night. I concede that the people from the Department of Transport and Communications who turned up changed the tone of their thinking by the end of the night. All of us on this side of politics were there: Senator Chapman, Senator Macdonald and me, of course. Unfortunately, Senator Macdonald is not able to be here at present because he has parliamentary duties in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, we have taken an interest in this matter and signed a dissenting report. Although Senator Macdonald signed the report, I notice that his name is not on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm going to raise that.

— His name should have been printed in the report. Before the Senate sat today, I delivered a dissenting report signed by Senator Macdonald to the secretariat of the Committee. At the meeting this morning I brought up the point that I was trying to get hold of Senator Macdonald to have him sign the dissenting report that I wrote. When I came out of the meeting I contacted Senator Macdonald and faxed him a copy. He signed it and sent it back. I then handed it to the secretariat before Parliament sat this morning. Mr Deputy President, I want to know why his signature is not included.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague—It's not accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is inaccurate. There is a blank spot where his name should appear.

PARA.TAB: I wish to emphasise the fears that we have. Not one word is mentioned about the six hours of sitting. That is why my colleagues and I decided this morning to bring down a dissenting report. Mr Deputy President, I certainly want to know why Senator Macdonald's signature does not appear on the dissenting report as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly to the motion and correct some of the misinformation which Senator Panizza has just given us. As the Senate should know, Senator Powell, who has responsibility for this portfolio and would normally be present at meetings of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, is on compassionate leave and is not available. The meeting in question was called at extremely short notice when other senators had other business engagements which had been prearranged some time beforehand. Consequently, it was simply not possible to have a Democrat presence at the Committee meeting.

PARA.TAB: Bearing that in mind, between 7.40 and 7.50 in the evening I met with all the people who are mentioned in this report representing the road transport industry and put before them the motion to which the Opposition has agreed. All of those people agreed that that was the appropriate way to proceed. I find it rather surprising that the Committee found it necessary to sit until 2 o'clock in the morning in order to conduct the same amount of business that I could have got agreement on in 10 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, you won't listen to them.

—I listened to them and put matters before them. They were in agreement. I just want to put on the record that there was no discourtesy on the part of the Democrats in terms of meeting with these people in the time that was available. I simply observe that the Opposition has agreed to the motion which was an outcome of that meeting.

—I want to make a couple of very brief remarks on the report which has just been tabled in the Senate. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The main reason I did not attend the meeting that Senator Panizza mentioned when evidence was taken from various interest groups was that I had a conflicting appointment at that time. I think most honourable senators would be aware that back bench senators on the Government side serve on an overlapping number of Senate committees and joint committees. As a result, it is very difficult to get to every meeting of a Senate standing committee. I regret that I was unable to attend because it is an issue that I am interested in. It is an issue of interest in South Australia, the State I represent.

PARA.TAB: However, I am surprised that a motion was passed at the end of a meeting that I understood was to take evidence. Members of the Committee are quite entitled to put a motion. In view of the short time span available for consideration of the Bill, members of the Committee who were present at the meeting might have thought that was the most appropriate thing to do. I was unaware that a motion expressing a view about the Bill itself would be put at that meeting. I thought the meeting was to take evidence and that a subsequent meeting would be held to prepare the final report to be tabled in the Senate.

Nevertheless, I do not disagree with the right of Senator Panizza—or other honourable senators—to move any motion he liked at that meeting when public evidence had been taken. The Committee can choose to carry, defeat or amend the motion. At the meeting I was able to attend this morning I voted to support the Chairman's draft. I thought that, in view of the disagreement amongst members of the Committee, the only place this Bill will be resolved is here in the chamber. Senator Panizza has concerns about the Bill, Senator Macdonald is not here and, clearly, Senator Chapman will take part in the debate when it comes back into the full Senate. I do not think honourable senators should be concerned that the debate in the Committee is being ignored, because the debate on this important piece of legislation will take place in the full Senate.

This incident demonstrates the problem of referring to the standing committees of the Senate lots of legislation which has to be investigated at short notice and reported on within a short time. Honourable senators serving on a number of committees cannot get to every committee hearing, come across all the evidence or brief themselves on all the hearings. Many honourable senators on both sides are serving on joint committees of the Parliament as well as Senate committees. There is a heavy workload.

I have been a critic of the process of referring lots of legislation to standing committees, because I think the time and resources honourable senators can put into studying the Bills do not do justice to the committees. For example, I am on the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. We are grappling with a major piece of legislation about amendments to the Trade Practices Act. It is a very technical inquiry, with conflicting evidence, dealing with a specific Bill. It has been a major effort of the Committee. Irrespective of political affiliation, as Committee members grapple with the information, their views are not along party lines. A major inquiry, into the cost of justice, conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has now been delayed for nearly a year because the Senate is referring to the Committee more and more legislation, which gets priority.

If we do not watch out, the standing committees will lose a very valuable opportunity to conduct broad inquiries into matters of interest and concern in the community, because we are always being loaded down with work due to the referral of legislation. I do not think it would be a positive development if we were to lose, effectively, the ability to deal with major issues which have been referred by the Senate but which do not deal with legislation.

I note Senator Panizza's remarks. I think the debate should take place in the Senate. I apologise for not being at the meeting on Wednesday evening when the evidence was taken and the motion was put forward. I hope that the debate can proceed expeditiously in the Senate over the next two days, despite the differences of opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, you were not in the chair when the first motion was put. I wanted to seek the call to speak to the motion that the report be printed. We have a dilemma before us now in that the report that has been circulated—in relation to which the motion that the report be printed has been moved and passed—is incomplete and inaccurate in that Senator Macdonald's name does not appear, as Senator Panizza has pointed out. It reads: `Dissenting Report by Senators Panizza'—then there is a blank—`and Chapman'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald's signature has been received, but this report is still inaccurate and incomplete. There are several ways of dealing with this matter. I could move that the Senate rescind the motion that the report be printed, that we defer consideration until a later hour this day when the correct document has been tabled and that a motion be passed that the correct document be printed.

I made it plain earlier this morning that we did not want this report presented to the chamber and tabled until it was complete and that I would move at the placing of business that it be deferred. I was subsequently informed that the report bore Senator Macdonald's signature and was complete; so it was produced and Senator Foreman moved that the report be printed and that the Senate take note of it. After that, the document came to our desks and I saw that it was an incomplete report that has not been dealt with properly. I am in the hands of the Senate as to whether the matter can be deferred, this document withdrawn and the correct one produced or whether I move to rescind the motion that this report be printed. However, this document must not be printed and cannot be regarded as an accurate report tabled in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are debating a motion to take note of a report, Senator Foreman can respond without closing the debate.

—As has already been mentioned, there are only two names on the dissenting report that has been presented so far, those of Senators Panizza and Chapman, but I have been notified by the Clerk that Senator Macdonald's name will appear in a further report that will be included in this report.
—I understand that Senator Macdonald's signature is included in the tabled copy.

—As has been reported, the Committee sat for about six hours on Wednesday night, until about 2 o'clock in the morning, and heard something like nine witnesses, who represented a number of other people who came along on that evening. At the conclusion of the hearing it was agreed that we have a private meeting to consider a number of matters— amongst other things amendments moved by the Opposition. As a result of that meeting and a draft report that has been compiled over the last few days, I called a further meeting this morning to consider that draft report and the amendments that were moved by the Opposition. That meeting took place, as has been indicated; as a result of that, it has been moved that the report be printed and dealt with.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza has made a point about all of the evidence being given and no mention made of it in the report presented today. It was mentioned to him at the meeting this morning that it would have been very difficult to prepare a consolidated report on everything that was dealt with at that six-hour meeting on Wednesday evening. I indicated to him that the Hansard would be available to him if he required it or if people wanted to know exactly what transpired at that meeting.

In respect of the Committee member from the Australian Democrats, Senator Powell indicated that she was not able to attend on that particular night because she was not in Canberra. As I mentioned earlier, the report has come down without Senator Macdonald's name on it, but it will be included later. I understand that the report is currently being reprinted with the signatures of all Opposition Committee members contained in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support the remarks made by my colleagues Senator Panizza and Senator Reid. I address my comments through you, Mr Deputy President, to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan), to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and to the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter).

PARA.TAB: In this case there has been a series of serious lapses in the way in which this matter has been handled. Let me refer to them, as I can see Senator McMullan blushing. The first point is that the Senate used to sit on Fridays. When sitting on Fridays it dealt with regular Senate business. However, we agreed—there was very sound agreement—that we forgo sitting as a Senate on Fridays to enable the standing committees of the Senate to meet to deal in particular with referred legislation.

I remind the Senate that for 20 years the standing committees of this Senate have been called Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees. One of the essential functions of the committees is to consider referred legislation: to look at a Bill; to hear reports from interested groups, such as those witnesses who came before this Committee whose names Senator Panizza has read out, and then to consider that evidence carefully; and to bring recommendations before the Senate so it can deal with the legislation. There is nothing at all wrong with the setting aside of Fridays or with the long established procedure of dealing with legislation in this way by Senate standing committees.

Senator Schacht made a criticism that the procedure is delaying some of the general purpose activities of these committees, and I reject that criticism. Clearly, what is required is for the general purpose sittings of committees to be conducted on days when the Senate is not sitting. I support the view that all sorts of important matters need to be properly considered by committees and brought to the Senate's attention.

I say to Senator McMullan and to Senator Foreman that the Government was at fault in intending to seek to get the National Road Transport Commission Bill approved in a rapid fashion in a series of days before the Senate rose for Christmas. This intention led to the date of the Senate Committee hearing being changed four times. When it was finally changed, with only 24 hours notice, to a Wednesday night—an unusual time—a Government senator, Senator Schacht, and an Australian Democrats senator, Senator Powell, were not present. In the case of the Democrats, Senator Powell did not even know that the meeting was occurring.

I put it to the Senate that this type of mistake, this type of lapse, occurred as a result of going outside of our stable and well-ordered Senate committee procedures. Ultimately, I believe that the Government is at fault for forcing the pace and insisting that the Senate press everything into a constrained path in order to get some legislation passed before Christmas. In particular, where a matter is controversial, where there are different assessments and where the Opposition is opposed to a matter, we are in fact damaging the reputation of the Senate by using such a procedure. I make no criticism whatsoever of the Opposition senators on this Committee. I am directing my remarks to all of the lapses that have been rehearsed in the last half an hour to ensure that in future the Government does not force the pace when it leads to these sorts of errors.

Let me assure those members of the public who are interested in the good procedure of the Parliament or who are concerned that the Senate go about its legislative duties properly that this is a sound Senate which has very well established procedures. This matter is very much the exception to the rule. It is a great pity that the Democrats did not have even 24 hours notice of the meeting, so did not have proper information. It is very important that senators representing the various parties be able to make arrangements to attend hearings. We will remember this as an example of the kind of conduct that is not up to the standards of the Senate. It ought not to be repeated just for the sake of the Government's trying to force legislation through this place in a way which is not acceptable to the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In closing this debate, I reiterate that the other night we moved the motion for the Senate to postpone consideration of the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991 because of the evidence which came out after six hours of hearing by the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. However, I assure the Senate that we would have moved that motion whether we had the numbers there or not; at least it would have been put on record. We did not move it to get on anyone's nerves or to further delay the Committee. We still stand by it.

PARA.TAB: We have an undertaking from the Chairman that the finished printed report will include the name of Senator Macdonald, whose signature I handed to the secretariat of the Committee before the Senate sat this morning.

Finally, I briefly mention that I believe the Standing Orders need to be looked at. This is the only place I know of where a motion passed by a committee can be overturned without any notice of motion of seven days, 14 days or whatever the case may be. It seems that, so long as one has the numbers, one can have a meeting every five minutes until one gets the required result. I recommend that the Standing Orders be looked at to prevent this happening again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wonder whether you could tell the Senate what the status of the report will be and what document will in fact be printed?

—I have a copy of the report as circulated in the chamber. I also have received, by way of fax, a copy of the page which is headed `Dissenting Report by Senators Panizza, Macdonald and Chapman', which has Senator Macdonald's signature on it. My understanding is that that page will be reprinted. The page will be headed `Dissenting Report by Senators Panizza, Macdonald and Chapman' and have the three signatures at the base of it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report by 11 September 1992:

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition will be supporting this motion but I wish to move a small amendment. I move:

PARA.TAB: That after paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Short had moved by way of amendment in respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991:

PARA.TAB: add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for its economic policy failures which have resulted in one and a half million Australians being unemployed or underemployed in the worst recession for 60 years, and urges the Government to adopt the Opposition's `Fightback!' package of proposals to provide hope, and a vision for the future, for all Australians, including in particular:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history, amounting to $13 billion;
(b)the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, petroleum products excise, superannuation lump sum tax, customs duty, training guarantee levy and the coal export duty;
(c)significant, and beneficial, restructuring of the capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax;
