(f)the introduction of a 15 per cent goods and services tax that will:

PARA.TAB: (i)reform and simplify Australia's grossly inefficient taxation system,
(ii)boost our national productivity and savings,
(iii) enable greater international competitiveness by slashing taxes on business inputs,
(iv)assist in reducing marginal tax rates and thus increase incentives to work, save and invest,
(v)make the tax system fairer by reducing avoidance and evasion and
(vi)adequately compensate Australians for the net one-off price effect of the goods and services tax".

PROCTEXT.PARA: and upon which Senator Herron had moved by way of amendment in respect of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991:

PARA.TAB: add ", and that the Senate encourages Australians to `Fightback' by insuring themselves for both hospital and medical expenses".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is returning to the debate on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991, the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. I was speaking when the matter was adjourned some weeks ago and I was restricting my remarks to the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill, which lifts the payment for fringe benefits from 47 per cent to 48.25 per cent.

PARA.TAB: At that time, I said that the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill has been one of the notable failures of this Government. It has been a notable failure because it has been founded entirely on the wrong principle. The principle upon which we base taxation has always been that the person who receives the benefit pays the income tax. Payment is made in lieu of services, for the provision of goods, or for whatever reason. The fundamental principle in this society has been that those who receive the payment pay the tax. Yet the fringe benefits tax is levied against the donor, it is levied against the employer, and not against the person who receives the benefit. That produces some major distortions within the economy. At the end of the day it does not achieve its simple objective, namely, to make sure that people who receive an income do not pay income tax at a lower level.

The Opposition fully supports the closure of income tax evasion loopholes and the strengthening of the income tax rules. However, we also believe that it is quite wrong to give tacit support to what is, in effect, a reduction in liability for income tax by taxing the donor—the employer—rather than taxing the recipient.

There is no doubt that the fringe benefits tax has been a financial success for this big spending Government. It has raised more money than the Government ever anticipated when it first introduced it. In that sense, the Bill has clearly been a success, but it is purely an additional taxing vehicle; it is something which adds to the very great complexity of income tax law in this country because the Bill is not simple to administer.

I mention briefly without expanding on it that the fringe benefits tax is largely avoided in the cities. The friends of Mr Keating, the forex traders and the young upwardly mobile professionals in Sydney and Melbourne are still paying income tax on low incomes of about $40,000 while their direct returns might be well over $100,000, $120,000 or $150,000. They are still getting their school fees paid, expensive cars, accommodation with interest payments on their housing loans through the company, holidays for their wives and themselves, and all the rest of it.

The people who are paying are the shareholders in the companies. The owners of the companies, whether they are private individuals or shareholders, are the people who are paying for those benefits. It is fundamentally wrong to persist with that sort of system in society.

The fringe benefits tax is having a big effect on rural Australia, which is enormously important to us. It has a hidden effect which is not seen by many people in this Parliament. Rural activity is very important to our economy. It is the very big export earning bloc after minerals. It probably provides 38 per cent to 40 per cent of Australia's export income. The effects of the fringe benefits tax on rural Australia are very high. The tax has two important effects: things are pretty tough in the country at present, and they will be for some time in the future, and the requirement to pay a fringe benefits tax puts many marginal producers below the line.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, will be absent from the chamber this week. Senator Evans is overseas on government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Ray.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. We welcome him back. We are also pleased that he is out of hospital. I ask: has the Minister had his widely reported meeting with the Prime Minister? If not, when will that meeting occur? If the Prime Minister does not resign, will the Minister, in all good conscience, resign from the Cabinet of a Prime Minister he does not support?

—The answer to the first part of the question is yes; I had a chat with the Prime Minister last night. As those opposite do not know what was discussed—and they never will—the second part of the question is a complete non sequitur, and I have nothing to say about that matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from that that the Minister is indicating that he will not resign. Is the Senate therefore to assume that the Prime Minister has his full support?
—I answered that question on a number of previous occasions. Senator Hill can read the Hansard and look at the answer. If he does not do that today, he can do it over the Christmas break.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer him to the question I asked last week and to the recent decision of the United Nations to rescind resolution 3379, which equated Zionism with racism. Will the Minister advise the Senate of the Australian Government's evaluation of this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes the vote in the United Nations General Assembly on 16 December to rescind the United Nations General Assembly resolution 3379 of 1975, which equated Zionism with racism. The rescission motion was adopted overwhelmingly with 111 votes in favour out of the 149 votes cast. There were 25 votes against the motion and 13 abstentions.

PARA.TAB: This was a fitting demise for a resolution which, as Senator Evans said in the Senate on 12 December, was wrong in itself and a hindrance to the Middle East peace process. As Dr Blewett said in his media release of 17 December:

It is particularly gratifying to see the United Nations remove from its books a resolution which has drawn such world-wide condemnation. This reflects growing recognition among UN members of the need to adopt more constructive positions in the organisation and to move away from outdated polemic and rhetoric. The UN will be the major beneficiary of this move.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia voted against resolution 3379 in 1975 and, in 1986, the Australian Parliament was the first in the world to pass a resolution calling to overturn 3379. Australia lobbied vigorously for the rescission of 3379 and joined more than 80 other nations in co-sponsoring the rescission motion.

PARA.TAB: I hope that the elimination of resolution 3379 will give added impetus to all parties to the Middle East process to adopt pragmatic and constructive approaches to the current talks in Washington.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: why does the Minister continue to serve as Minister for Social Security in the Prime Minister's Cabinet when he is prepared so disloyally to seek to overturn him?
—I am not seeking disloyally to overturn him, so I do not need to answer the rest of the question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister telling us that he is not disloyal, or is not seeking to overturn the Prime Minister? Why does he believe that Mr Keating would be a better Prime Minister than Mr Hawke, who was elected by the Australian people?
—I will answer questions relating to my portfolio; I do not need to answer these questions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance. Has he seen yesterday's statement and the report tabled last week by the Auditor-General, Mr John Taylor, about the use of a private sector auditor for the proposed National Rail Corporation? In his capacity as Minister representing the Ministers in whose portfolios the administration of the Audit Act falls, what is his reaction to that statement and report? What is the justification for the Government's position on this matter in the light of the general policy supporting the use of the Auditor-General as stated by a former Finance Minister several years ago? Given that it is now two years and one month since the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration tabled its report on government companies—which included strong recommendations on proper accountability, including the matter of auditing by the Auditor-General—when can we expect to see the Government's response to that report, and

QUESTION.PARA: what are the reasons for the delay other than wide consultation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates was kind enough to give me notice of this question, because I had not seen the material which he asked for. I have obtained an answer for him, as a result of which I can say that the essential points of the Auditor-General's report on the National Rail Corporation have been drawn to my attention.
—It was debated in the Senate.

—I understand that. The Auditor-General's recommendation was that the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill be amended to require the Corporation to report annually to Parliament and to provide for the Auditor-General to be the sole external auditor of the Corporation. I do not think that at this stage we should get too excited about this issue. The Government has absolutely no intention of avoiding proper accountability to the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I do not know precisely what stage has been reached, but I understand that the Bill is to be debated by the Senate this week. Consideration is being given to the issues that the Auditor-General has raised. In his statement yesterday, the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown, said quite clearly that in accordance with longstanding conventions the National Rail Corporation's annual report would be tabled in the Parliament. Whether we need to have legislation to require such reporting can be debated. I doubt whether that is crucial one way or the other.

Senator Coates asked the last part of his question in his capacity as the Chairman of the relevant Committee. I understand that Senator Coates's concern regarding the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on government companies is that this has not been dealt with before now. I do not know what the hold-up has been, but I shall see what can be done to provide an early response to Senator Coates and the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and I return to an unanswered question of 14 August—some 18 weeks ago—put by my former colleague Senator McLean. I remind the Senate of the promise of a forthcoming answer given at the time by Senator Evans, and can only assume that the delay of 18 weeks is a measure of the thoroughness of the investigation. I therefore ask the Minister: in view of reports in the United States that `virtually every major bank in the world' has been involved in funding Saddam Hussein through BNL Atlanta and in view of the Commonwealth Bank's close and direct affiliation with BNL, has the Reserve Bank or any law enforcement agency investigated the possible involvement of Australian banks in conduiting funds to Saddam Hussein's weapons development program? Has any investigation been undertaken concerning possible involvement of Australian banks with the Bank of Commerce and Credit International? If such investigations have occurred, will the Minister advise the Senate of the findings, and did such investigations include a search of the so-called `Grey Books'? If such investigations have not occurred, can the Minister advise the Senate why? Finally, does the Minister acknowledge the strong similarity between the operations of the former Nugan Hand Bank in Australia and BCCI, and have authorities recently considered the possibility that Nugan Hand was the leading edge of BCCI operations in Australia?

—At the time that Senator McLean asked that question, the Treasury was asked to conduct an investigation into this matter and to do some work on it. Consequent upon Senator McLean's sudden, precipitous, inexplicable resignation from this Senate, the work which Treasury was doing was stopped because the question was directed to the Treasury by a senator. Now that Senator Coulter has re-raised the issue, I will inquire into the matter to see what progress had been made and what further work needs to be done.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am absolutely shocked by the Minister's reply. Are questions important in their own right or are they simply important because they are asked in this place?

—I have already answered that part of the question. Every senator asks questions during Question Time, irrespective of party allegiances or whatever. If a senator leaves the Senate and is not present at Question Time, he or she is not necessarily entitled to an answer.
—Are you saying that this issue is not important?

—No, I did not say that; Senator Coulter should not get excited. I said that a senator who asks a question is entitled to an answer, but a senator who asks a question and then leaves the Senate is not necessarily entitled to an answer. As Senator Coulter has re-raised the question, I have undertaken to get some work done on it.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. With respect to the substantial increase in the number of Australian workers who are contributing to superannuation schemes and their concern that contributions are safe, what arrangements are in place to ensure that investments by superannuation trustees are made in a safe and secure manner?

—The Government has presided over a rapid increase in superannuation for employees in a number of industries—indeed, across the board. Superannuation has become a central element of the Government's retirement incomes policy. Improvements to prudential supervision are part of the process of extending superannuation coverage.

PARA.TAB: I make one or two points about the prudential supervision which is required. Occupational superannuation standards provide protection for members' funds. For example, there are restrictions on loans to members, on borrowings by superannuation funds and on the types of investments that can be undertaken by the funds. Superannuation funds are not required to meet the Government's standards. However, the Government gives access to taxation concessions only to funds which comply with those standards. If a superannuation trustee breaches the Government's operating standards, it stands to lose its concessional tax status, which is a huge and significant loss for a fund. In addition, there are the normal obligations on trustees under trust law to act in an honest manner and in the best interests of the beneficiaries. I draw Senator Jones's attention to the then Treasurer's statement of 20 August 1991 concerning prudential supervision of superannuation funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—Mr Kerin. I know Senator Lewis has been away, having a bit of a holiday in the South Pacific. The statement outlined measures that will strengthen the ability of fund members to scrutinise the activities of the funds, for example, by introducing improved requirements for funds to report to members. It is proposed to amend the relevant legislation to give effect to that announcement from 1 July 1992. The Government is also examining the use of corporations powers under the Constitution as a means of further developing the enforcement regime so that action can be taken against trustees who have failed to comply with the appropriate standards.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. When the Minister and five of his colleagues met with the Prime Minister last week, apparently to ask him to stand aside as leader, did the Minister believe that Mr Hawke should no longer remain as leader of the Labor Party and Prime Minister of Australia? If not, why did he join the delegation?

—Anything I say at a private meeting remains private. Whenever I have to deal with questions of leadership, I look back through history for inspiration. I have not really needed to refresh my memory much when I look at that mob opposite me.
—Go back 48 hours in Tasmania.

—No, I can go back much further than that. The mob opposite rarely has any leaders of any potential. During the First World War, the non-Labor parties had to steal a Labor Prime Minister to lead them. That is how badly off they were. No sooner had they got him into office than they started a plot to get rid of him. In 1923, we saw Page and Stanley Bruce get rid of Hughes as their leader. No sooner had that happened than there was a plot to get rid of Stanley Bruce. In 1929 that was achieved by his Party going into the national Parliament and stabbing him in the middle of the back. Then the non-Labor parties threw up a leader called Latham. He was pretty useless, so they had to steal another leader from the Labor Party—Lyons. No sooner had Lyons got in than they started to stab him in the back. He died in office, broken hearted by the attitude of his Party.

PARA.TAB: In quick succession, we had as Prime Minister Menzies, Page, Menzies again and then Fadden. The people had to get rid of the non-Labor Government in the Second World War. Admittedly, we went through a small period of stability with Menzies, because everyone of talent from the opposite side was appointed ambassador or high commissioner or was appointed to the High Court.

No sooner was Harold Holt put in than his colleagues started to plot against him; he died prematurely. Then Billy McMahon was blackballed by Black Jack McEwen and knocked out of the ring. Gorton was put in. Then there were plots against Gorton and McMahon was put in. He lasted 18 months and Snedden was put in. Some 1 1/2 years later we had the first leadership challenge, and four or five months later we had the second leadership challenge. Then Malcolm Fraser was put in, and Peacock challenged Fraser in 1980. Finally Fraser went off into the sunset and Peacock became leader. He was challenged by many people in this room who put Howard in. Then some of those opposite changed sides and put Peacock in and now we have ended up with John Hewson. How long is he going to last? I have no idea.

I have noticed that in the last six weeks the Liberal Party, the Party that espouses leadership, has axed Robin Gray in Tasmania—it got rid of him absolutely—and has got rid of the Queensland Liberal Party leader. The National Party leader in Queensland has quit. There are plots against the Liberal Party leader here in the ACT. And those opposite waste my time asking me what meetings I have gone to! The answer is: you will never find out; get stuffed!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his walk through history. I would like him to bring us up to date. I also draw his attention to the fact that he is the Minister who has accepted the honourable position under Mr Hawke of Minister for Defence. Is it too much to ask the Minister to give us his view as to his loyalty to the Prime Minister who appointed him to that position? Would he please indicate whether he believes that Mr Hawke should continue to be the leader of the Labor Party and the Prime Minister of Australia?

—As I said at the start of the question, I will answer questions with relevance to my portfolio. Ever since I have entered this Parliament I have said that my loyalty to the Prime Minister is unquestioned, and it remains so.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications comment on the implications of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal research which has revealed that the level of advertising on prime time television is much higher than the networks say it is and is in excess of their own guidelines? Does the Minister believe that action is required by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in order to ensure a ceiling limit on the amount of advertising per hour?

—The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided me with the following response. The research referred to in recent press articles was purchased by the Tribunal as part of the investigations it is undertaking in its review of advertising time on television. This review is still in progress and it is not appropriate for the Government to comment until the Tribunal has released its findings.

PARA.TAB: It should be explained that the Tribunal deregulated advertising time limits in 1987 for a trial period of two years by repealing the relevant Tribunal standards. The current inquiry is a review of that trial to determine whether there should be a program standard limiting the amount of television advertising and program promotions and the likely format of such a standard. In July 1991 the Tribunal released a draft standard for comment, and the inquiry is currently continuing. Therefore, the matters referred to in this question are a matter for that inquiry to consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Why does the Minister continue to serve as Minister for Industrial Relations in Mr Hawke's Ministry when he is not prepared to give Mr Hawke his loyal support and is in fact seeking to have him replaced as Prime Minister by Mr Keating?

—I certainly cannot improve on the last answer given to a similar question by Senator Ray. I might say that I do not have the same encyclopaedic knowledge of dates and times of who was where and what. If I may, I will simply adopt Senator Ray's answer as my response in this case.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I might say that it was a rather pathetic and weak question—

PARA.TAB: Government senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —answer—to a very obvious question. I ask Senator Cook not to piggyback Senator Ray and to answer this question: if Senator Cook is loyal to Mr Hawke and wishes to continue to serve as his Minister, is he prepared to support him and give him his vote in Caucus?
—This is a nonsense question and should be dealt with and treated as such. I do not intend to answer it. It is absolutely A-grade nonsense.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and relates to several issues concerning women's health. Can the Minister inform the Senate about progress in the national program for breast cancer screening? What is the Government doing to speed up access to new drugs that are critical to women's health? Will the Minister outline the Government's approach to a national women's health program?

—I thank Senator Giles for her question. I know that she has had a longstanding and genuine interest in this area of women's health and that there has been concern about the national screening program to which she refers. Implementation has been relatively slow, but honourable senators would wish there to be proper planning to ensure the success of such a vital program.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, in February 1991, the Commonwealth offered a total of $11.4m in unmatched funds to the States. Ten per cent of the funds were to be paid on signature with the other 90 per cent payable on the basis of an agreed State plan. South Australia was the only State in a position to accept the offer at that time. Subsequently, participation agreements were signed by Queensland in May, Victoria in May, New South Wales in June and Western Australia in July. So Senator Giles can see that the implementation of the program is proceeding. A further $860,000 has been paid to South Australia, which has largely financed a new central assessment centre and State coordination unit for that State. Other unmatched funds will be paid once State plans and budgets have been agreed to between the Commonwealth and the States.

Senator Giles also asked about the speedy availability of drugs for health problems concerning women. There has been a very real recognition in the Government of the need to ensure that community expectations for access in a speedy and timely way to drugs that are available internationally should be met by their availability in the Australian market. For that reason, our former colleague, now Professor Peter Baume, produced a report to which the Government has responded very quickly. Indeed, the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991 was passed by the Senate last week.

Whilst women's interests were not the only factor, stimulus or catalyst for pursuing that reform, they were certainly well to the fore. At the same time, the Government is conscious that in the area of family planning options the products concerned are being made available to essentially healthy women, with a consequent need for added caution. The history of certain products has shown this; hence the Government has shown that same caution.

The Commonwealth Government is already implementing an extremely effective health program for women. It has clearly demonstrated its concern for women's health needs by developing the national women's health policy and providing in the 1989-90 Budget $16.86m over four years for a national women's health program which emphasises the promotion of primary health care. In addition, the Government has put in train the national breast cancer screening program—which I discussed earlier—and the cervical cancer screening program for which $23.3m has been allocated over four years on a part cost-share, part unmatched basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister inform the Senate about plans for mobile mammography and osteoporosis units for women in rural and remote areas?

—I think Senator Giles is referring to the fact that the Commonwealth Government has provided $2.8m for mobile mammography vans. If she is suggesting—as some have—that similar bone densitometry services be provided by that van travelling around, it has to be said about that mobile van program that space is already at a premium in the mammography vans for equipment and changing space for women and staff.
—So you don't support such programs in rural areas.

—It is highly unlikely that the two functions could be combined adequately in the one van travelling around; that is all I am saying. But the fact is that the States are using State and Commonwealth funds to extend screening to women in rural and remote areas by the commissioning of further mobile vans in this mammography program. I think two are planned to operate in Western Australia, which is Senator Giles's home State.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of bone densitometry services, some years ago the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee recommended against paying benefits for bone densitometry. The National Health Technology Advisory Panel specified certain clinical conditions for which bone densitometry would be appropriate. However, it noted that the value of widespread use of this technology had not yet been established and still did not recommend the use of bone densitometry for mass screening purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some years ago.

—I can tell Senator Newman that this is consistent with the view held by a similarly expert body overseas. Medicare benefits, therefore, may not be the most appropriate means of funding bone densitometry. The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is presently examining options for providing affordable bone density measurement services where these services are appropriate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer the Minister to his own statement concerning the internecine warfare within the ALP, where he said:

QUESTION.PARA: To suggest this could be left to next year is unthinkable. The question has to be resolved and as far as I'm concerned it should be done this week.
How does the Minister suggest it should be resolved?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is more appropriate to hold that sort of casual discussion over a lamington and a cup of tea. Perhaps Senator Tierney might like to come and have a chat with me about it. The question is so far beyond the executive responsibilities that I have in respect of this chamber that it is simply not appropriately directed to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I preface my question by reminding the Minister of the inquiry currently being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the costs of justice in Australia. I ask the Minister, firstly, whether he believes the application of a 15 per cent goods and services tax to legal services will further limit the opportunity for ordinary Australians to have access to the justice system; and, secondly, how will the Opposition's proposals affect Australia's legal aid system? In particular, would they result in less legal aid being available to the community?

—Mr President, I certainly do believe that the application of a 15 per cent GST to the provision of legal services in the Australian community would create intolerable burdens for many people who seek to use those services. It is an industry which is worth at least $3 billion a year. The imposition of a 15 per cent tax every time somebody has to purchase those services—whether it be for conveyancing for the family home, drawing up a will, getting advice in relation to a car accident or legal representation when one is facing the prospect of a heavy fine or imprisonment—would add hundreds of millions of dollars to the disbursements that a person would have to make.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Opposition senators, particularly those who sat on the Senate inquiry into the costs of justice really ought to examine their position. They are telling the Australian people that for everyday legal services—all those matters for which one would consult a solicitor, get the services of a barrister or whatever—they would have to pay 15 per cent straight into the Federal Treasury under the alternative being put forward by the Opposition. That seems to me to add an intolerable burden to the Australian community in respect of already very high legal fees. They are a disincentive to getting proper legal advice, and when one does get legal advice, one finds that the cost is crippling.

The assault on the legal aid system is the most appalling part of this particular package. The Opposition says that it will first of all strip $10m off the administrative costs of legal aid—legal aid commissions, community legal centres and the Commonwealth component—across the board. The administration of legal aid commissions costs $11.3m a year around Australia. To strip $10m off administrative costs would be to destroy them absolutely. These are the bodies which—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Durack has sent a sceptical glance in my direction. He would know, from his particularly keen interest in the provision of legal aid in Western Australia—and it is a good interest—that the stripping away of $10m from the administrative funds available for legal aid commissions would absolutely destroy them. It cannot be done. We know it cannot be done. The saving cannot be achieved.

PARA.TAB: Further, about 60 per cent of the expenditure of legal aid commissions consists of the purchase of legal advice from the private profession. If the legal aid commissions have to pay this 15 per cent tax every time they get services from the private profession, then they will be in a position where their funds are diminished to an extraordinary degree. The commissions will be required to pay 15 per cent of the legal bills presented by the private profession for advice on a custody matter or an access matter, or representation of an accused person before a criminal court, out of their already very tight funds, to the Federal Treasury—moneys that ought to be available to purchase further legal services for their clients, for the very poor people who apply to legal aid commissions for assistance.

The cumulative effect of the Opposition's proposals in respect to legal aid is that 15,000 Australians will not be provided with legal aid who ought to be provided with legal aid. That is the direct impact of the proposal to impose a 15 per cent GST on the provision of legal services. The poorest, the most vulnerable in our community, will not get access to legal aid—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense, and you know it.

—Senator Bishop says that that is nonsense. I do not usually make personal remarks, but she would not appreciate that we are dealing with a group of people who are in a very low income situation. In that situation, when they are confronted with the possibility of a criminal charge leading to imprisonment or a fine, or the need to get custody of their children, they need to get legal aid.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am well aware of what the Minister said in that answer. The point of order I am speaking to is that he has impugned my knowledge concerning those people who are suffering. I ask you to ask him to withdraw it.
—Order! That is a matter a for personal explanation at the end of Question Time. I call Senator Brownhill.
—I have not completed my answer.
—I must remind you, Senator Tate, that this is becoming a very long answer.
—Mr President, I think it is very important to—

—Mr President, if the Minister is going to continue I wish to raise a point of order. Other Ministers have refused to answer questions on the basis that, they said, they did not relate to the administration of their portfolios. Senator Tate is now seeking to debate our Fightback program. He can talk about his record and his failures on legal aid, but under the Standing Orders he cannot debate our program. I draw your attention to that standing order, Mr President, and I ask that you instruct that he comply with it.
—Mr President—

—Order! Resume your seat, Senator Bolkus. I am not going to have points of order ruin Question Time as they did last week. The Minister's answer was in order, but I have already reminded Senator Tate that he has gone well over the normal time.

—Mr President, I accept your direction and of course would not wish to contradict in any way your implied direction to me. I simply say that the imposition of a 15 per cent GST with respect to the provision of legal aid by the Legal Aid Commissions would return us to a situation where many thousands of Australians would not be able to get legal aid. I believe that would be a Dickensian Christmas present to those poorer sections of the Australian community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The former former Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, said in his 1990 Budget Speech:

QUESTION.PARA: In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

Given that last week's unemployment statistics show that 500 people a day are losing their jobs and that unemployment is now 10.5 per cent, does the Minister think the Australian economy is still on track, and does he believe that Australia ought to be pursuing that economic strategy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the honourable senator quotes correctly from what the former Treasurer said in the context of the 1990 Budget. In numerous Question Times since then, we have all discussed the consequences of the recession which have been very severe.
—Why don't you take responsibility for it?
—Can you not be quiet for a minute? I actually missed you while I was away last week.
—I cannot say the same for you.

—But if Senator Bishop interjects too much I will not miss her at all this week. We have debated these issues on many occasions during Question Time in the Senate. Of course, we can now say that the Treasurer was wrong in what he said in 1990. But there is no particular triumph in that for anybody. Senator Brownhill then referred to the unemployment statistics, the last published figures, which he suggests show 500 people a day losing their jobs. They are, of course, lag figures. I hope that situation is not continuing at the present time—I doubt that it is—but those figures are dramatic, unpalatable and sad both for a government and the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: As for the direction of economic policy, the Treasurer, Mr Willis, has made it clear that any review of economic policy settings will be conditional on the review of Budget forecasts. Senator Short has asked me in here about the Budget forecast on a number of occasions. A review of the Budget forecast—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is your fourth try in 12 months to get it right and you have not got it right yet.
—Senator Boswell's interjections on pineapples are better than his interjections on the economy; he ought to stick to pineapples.
—You have had four chances and you have not got it right yet.
—An intelligent chap like Senator Boswell ought to be interested in this answer.
—He wants an intelligent answer.

—I am trying to give one. As I was saying, Senator Short on numerous occasions in this place has asked about the Budget forecast. A review of the Budget forecast is currently taking place. Mr Willis has said he will publish in due course the results of that Budget forecast and, consequent upon that forecast being available to the Government, there will be an examination of the issues—not just because the Budget forecast is due but because of the seriousness of the current economic situation.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I notice from this morning's press that Mr Hawke said that he would have a mini-Budget in January. Would the same apply if the Government changed leadership?

—I have nothing to add to what I have said. As the Treasurer has pointed out, there is a current review of the Budget forecast taking place. Consequent upon that, if particular action needs to be taken, then it will be taken by the Government and the Opposition will hear about it in due course.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It relates in particular to the devastation recently caused in Samoa by Cyclone Val. I ask: what opportunities are being taken to give emergency assistance to our neighbours through the provision of skilled personnel to respond to natural disasters? Are Australian defence forces presently capable of providing useful assistance? Is disaster relief an integral part of the Australian defence forces' training and capability?

—I will deal with the last part of the question first. Yes, it is part of their essential training. Senator Bell would realise that when the defence forces get involved in various disaster activities it does not necessarily gain much publicity or recognition; nevertheless they continue to do it, be it fire, flood or any other disaster.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell asked in particular what is being done in Western Samoa. The Government has so far provided assistance totalling over $500,000 in emergency relief to Western Samoa. Four RAAF Hercules aircraft have been used to move the supplies to date and a fifth is planned for later this week. The first two aircraft arrived in Western Samoa on Thursday of last week. On board were an Australian Army Iroquois helicopter, shelter materials, water containers, large capacity portable water tanks and water purification tablets. The helicopter is being used for a number of tasks, including medical evacuation, ferrying of supplies to outlying villages and search and rescue activities.

The third Hercules arrived in Western Samoa on Tuesday morning. It carried a further consignment of large and small tarpaulins for temporary roof repairs, additional water containers and other equipment required for repairs to Apia's telecommunications and water supply. The fourth Hercules was scheduled to arrive this morning and carried seven tonnes of flour and 3.5 tonnes of rice, plus a small consignment of tarpaulins. These supplies were provided by the Mormon Church. A fifth Hercules flight will be required to pick up the helicopter when its mission is completed. This flight will carry food and other priority items requested by the Western Samoan Government.

The clean-up operation continues in Western Samoa and power and communications are gradually being restored. All areas of the country are being assessed for emergency assistance and many of the relief provisions are being distributed by road. The Western Samoan Government will be releasing a detailed damage report shortly. An Australian disaster relief coordinator is currently in Western Samoa and is liaising closely with the local authorities. The Government will sympathetically consider any further requests for emergency assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: was a Federal Government Cabcharge voucher used to enable two protesters to take a taxi from the Canberra AIDEX exhibition to Bega?
—I do not know. I will find out for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It refers to the fact that since October last year over seven out of every 100 full time workers in Tasmania have lost their jobs. This is on top of an already unacceptably high unemployment level at that time. Can the Minister give the Senate the Government's explanation of this tragic situation? In the consideration that will be given to the question of unemployment by the Cabinet on Friday, will Tasmania's special position be considered?

—In so far as Senator Harradine asked me to give an explanation of what he described as a dreadful situation in Tasmania, let me say that I have on numerous occasions in the Senate addressed the question of unemployment nationally. Tasmania has always had, or generally had, a higher level of unemployment than most States.
—Under Labor governments.

—No. I said always. Senator Harradine mentioned exacerbating an already high unemployment rate which has existed in Tasmania. That is because Tasmania has not been as successful as it might be, for a variety of reasons, in attracting industry to that State. Senator Harradine asks what the Government will be doing about these issues and whether special consideration will be given to Tasmania. I cannot answer that question, but I will bear it in mind in any deliberations.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can he assure the Senate that any changes introduced by the Government in any mini-Budget early next year will not be permitted to increase the Budget deficit?

—No, I cannot do that. The Government has not yet considered the issues arising from the Budget forecasts. It would be wrong of me at Question Time, and quite inappropriate, to pre-empt any decision making process of the Government. I am not going to do that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that Federal and State governments are already estimated to double their borrowings to $12 billion to cover Budget deficits in 1991-92, and that the Commonwealth will account for more than half of this amount? Does he agree that further additions to this public sector borrowing requirement will lead to higher interest rates? Or would any increased expenditure be matched by raising taxes?

—I am not aware of the precise figure that Senator Short has quoted in respect of public sector borrowing requirements. Until the recession bit deeply, the Government had reduced the public sector borrowing requirement significantly—to zero as far as the Commonwealth sector was concerned, as I recall it.
—One year only.

—It is an achievement that those opposite never attained in all the 27 years they were in government and it is something they would never attain if, unfortunately, they were elected to office, with this loopy blueprint they have for an alleged recovery for Australia. Quite apart from all the holes in it, that is what it is. At last there is a commentator, one in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, who is starting to wake up to the things I have been saying in the Senate for two or three weeks, that is, that the package is all about those opposite in the Liberal Party trying to prove that they have at last gained a little bit of virility, which they totally lacked previously in years of government. The package is about recovering from the spineless decision making processes of previous Liberal governments.
—Give us an example.

—Senator Knowles wants an example. She has asked questions in this chamber about tariff reductions. In 1978 those opposite had an opportunity with a review of the Industry Commission's recommending general tariff reductions across the board. Who walked away from it? It was the Government of the day, led by Mr John Howard as Treasurer on that occasion.
—Who walked away from option C?

—Senator Crichton-Browne asks: `Who walked away from option C?'. On three occasions those opposite, when in government, considered this magical cure to Australia's economic problems, and on each occasion they walked away from it. That will happen again, because to prescribe a so-called blueprint for the economic ills of this country, to be implemented in year one, two or three, irrespective of the economic circumstances at the time, is economic and political lunacy, which will be exposed as time goes by. The only thing certain about the Opposition's package is that the tax deductions for the rich will be huge and the tax deductions for the poor will be small.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer, who has shown that he has a knowledge of the set of proposals for the introduction of a consumption tax. Has the Government analysed the proposals and will it implement them?
—There is no question of the Government implementing these proposals because, apart from anything else as I said a minute ago, of the crass inequities in them.
—Isn't there something in the Standing Orders about repetition?

—Under such a proposal a person on $30,000 a year will get a tax cut—according to the Hewson package—of $30 a week. A person on $70,000 a year will get a tax cut of $124 a week. That is the essential thing of what it is all about. Senator Panizza says that what I am saying is repetitious. He had better get used to it. He will get used to it day after day, week after week and month after month. The Opposition has had the so-called package on the ground for three weeks now and during that time its popularity has gone down by 5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—I received a lot of mail last week about Question Time the week before, pointing out that it is very difficult for people listening to Question Time to understand what Ministers are saying because of the noise made by the rabble on the Opposition side. That is understandable. In cases where I have been asked to forward those letters to you, Mr President, I have done so. That is the fact of the matter.

PARA.TAB: In answer to Senator Beahan's question, this present Government has been about restructuring the Australian economy with some pain—something which the Opposition never attempted. One of the most important things in all of that is to raise the export profile of this country, to turn this country into a much bigger exporter than it has ever been. The worst possible thing for exporters is an increase in inflation of the kind which would accompany the Opposition's tax package. One by one, industry by industry, people will come to realise this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, how could you possibly say that?

—Senator Hill asks how I could possibly say that. I can say it because I am here and he is there. I noticed that when I was away last week for 24 hours he slipped into me in the Senate behind my back—something I have never seen before. This is the Leader that the Opposition has in the Senate—`In enterprise of martial kind, when there was any fighting he led his regiment from behind, he found it less exciting'. That is Senator Hill. That is the sort of person we have as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. That is the sort of thing he does. So I am here and he is here there. The fact of the matter is that this tax package will not be implemented by the Government for the sorts of reasons which I have described.
—Senator Short is very vocal today. He might interject and tell me whether I am wrong, because it will be on the record.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—You are wrong!

TALK.START.PARA: —Most members of the Opposition know about four legs good, two legs bad, and that is the category they are in. Senator Short, tell me whether I am wrong: the most important thing for exporters is inflation.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is directing his answer to Senator Short; he should be directing any comments through you. I ask you to call him to order or ask him to sit down.

—Senator Button should direct his answer through the Chair. However, there is no use complaining about the length of answers when there is constant interjection and a refusal by honourable senators to accept the order of the Chair and cease interjecting.

—I conclude by saying that this is supposed to be a blueprint. The Liberals are saying, `Irrespective of the state of the Australian economy we will introduce this blueprint because at last we have a bit of virility. We are going to do the things that we never tackled in all our years in government. This time we are going to tackle them because we are a tough bunch compared with all the wimps'. Or, to use Mr Smart Alex Downer's comments in the House of Representatives a fortnight ago: `We did none of these things before because we didn't have the guts'. That was said by the Liberals' own shadow Minister. He was right: the Liberals did none of these things before because they did not have the guts. Now this package is brought forward and it will be implemented come whatever in the Australian economy. They will do it to prove their virility. That is an absolutely pathetic situation for an Opposition to get itself into.
—This is a policy of vision. You cannot answer it.
—Senator Short says it contains vision. It contains the vision of a person who can see through a keyhole with both eyes—and I am sad to say that Senator Short is one of those people.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Button referred to one or two letters he had received, and I ask him to table the letters.
—That is up to the Minister.
—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
—Mr President, on the point of order—
—You know, Senator Teague, that it is a matter for the Minister as to whether or not he tables them.
—But he did not give an answer.
—That is not a matter for me to determine. Resume your seat.

—I know that Senator Collins has a very personal interest in the successful tourism and investment activities of the Gagudju Association of western Arnhem Land. Will the Minister confirm that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation has engaged independent investment advisers on the multi-million dollar financial restructuring and ATSIC loan applications of Gagudju's Crocodile Hotel at Jabiru? Is that investment and ATSIC officials' advice different from the advice tendered to Gagudju by the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding? What is the basis for a present member of parliament, and a former Minister, to interfere as an unauthorised consultant on a taxpayer-backed management and investment deal? Did Mr Holding personally propose the terms of the relevant minutes for Gagudju? Will Mr Holding also be automatically appointed as a director of the new operating company under the terms of the contract he is pushing?

—In so far as anybody could make any sense out of that question, it would be utterly improper of me to discuss in the detail Senator Tambling wants what are very important internal commercial matters for the Gagudju Association. I am aware that Gagudju has been considering the investments that it has in tourism infrastructure in Kakadu National Park for some time and that it has engaged, as in my view it should have, a number of external sources of advice. So far as Mr Holding's association with that matter is concerned, I am aware—and Senator Tambling knows this—that not only Clyde but also his wife, Judy Holding, have been close friends of many of the Aboriginal people, some in particular who are executive members of the Gagudju Association.

PARA.TAB: Those associations were formed when Clyde Holding was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. His wife, Judy, has produced some absolutely marvellous paintings from the Kakadu National Park. Both are regular visitors to the area. Senator Tambling is well aware that the association of Mr Holding with those people whom Senator Tambling has referred to is a personal one. I know that the only reason Mr Holding became involved in advising the Gagudju Association was that it asked him to do so.
The remainder of Senator Tambling's question, in so far as it is possible to provide information which is not commercial-in-confidence, I will refer to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister is seeking to ascertain that information with regard to the apparent conflicts between the advice of ATSIC and independent investment advisers and that of Mr Holding, I ask whether he would also ascertain whether, in his trips to Arnhem Land, Mr Holding is acting on behalf of any government interests and/or at government expense; whether the contract arranged by Mr Holding will result in less income and no guaranteed financial returns to Gagudju; whether this was the concern of ATSIC advisers and traditional owners, when compared with the other competing tenderers; or whether this is just another case of one of the Prime Minister's mates calling in past favours to obtain a new job after the next election?

—With the greatest of respect to Senator Tambling—which, of course, means with no respect at all to Senator Tambling—might I say that the sort of tail end that Senator Tambling tacked onto the last part of his question, unfortunately, as we in this chamber all know, is typical of the questions asked by him. As we also know, 90 per cent—just to pick a reasonable figure out of the air, and I think it is a conservative one—of all the assertions that Senator Tambling makes in this place about Aboriginal affairs turn out to be complete nonsense.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the conflicting advice that has been given to the Gagudju Association, it is my opinion and my experience over 25 years that Aboriginal people are proffered more advice than they generally need, and most of it conflicts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I draw your attention to standing order 168. At the end of Senator Button's answer to a question from Senator Short, in which he referred to some letters he had received, I asked that he lay the letters on the table. Standing order 168 states:

PARA.TAB: A document relating to public affairs quoted by a Minister may be ordered to be laid on the table . . .

SPEECH.PARA: When I asked that question, through you, Mr President, no answer was given by Senator Button. I now ask Senator Button to lay those documents on the table of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On this matter, it is for Senator Button to determine whether he will table the letters. He does not have to answer. As I recall, he did not quote from the letters; he only referred to them. I did not want to take up any more time in Question Time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving the following motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate calls on Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self imposed economic crisis and to urgently adopt the Coalition's visionary `Fightback' program in the national interest.
Government senators may well sigh; but this is a matter of great urgency with a million Australians out of work, with another—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will accept this without Senator Hill moving suspension and making two speeches.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate calls on Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self imposed economic crisis and to urgently adopt the Coalition's visionary `Fightback' program in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: One reason for the urgency of this motion is the incredible fact that within 24 hours the Australian Labor Party could elect as Prime Minister of Australia the former discredited Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating. I refer to the wise words of Senator Jim McKiernan, JP, Labor senator for Western Australia, who last week said, and I quote:

PARA.TAB: There are now 900,700 reasons why Paul Keating should not be elected Prime Minister of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The man who gave us the recession that we `had to have' should not now be rewarded for his accomplishment. It is amazing that the shell-shocked Labor Party, so determined to hold on to power at any price, would reward the architect of the recession, the person who has ruined so many thousands of Australian lives, and give him as a reward for that inept economic leadership the highest office in government. I remind the Senate of the words of Mr Paul Keating earlier this year on an SBS television program, when he said:

I think loyalty is the stuff of politics. Political parties are built on loyalty. Loyalty is the common thread, I think, which runs through the political organisation, and organisation matters. It matters to me.

Paul Keating has shown no loyalty to his leader, a leader who has described Mr Keating as treacherous, although at that time he was party to a treacherous act on the Australian people; he has shown no loyalty to his Party, and with Senator Richardson he has been helping to totally undermine and destabilise it; he has shown no loyalty to his principles, as we saw the other day when he was prepared to sell out those principles to the Labor Left down in Victoria, when he sought the support of those such as Wally Curran and John Halfpenny—for but a few votes; and he has shown no loyalty to the ordinary Australian people who have suffered reducing standards of living under his economic tutelage and who have now lost their jobs and are looking forward to a miserable Christmas.

PARA.TAB: This is the political manipulator extraordinaire whose only loyalty has been to `the family'—the New South Wales Labor Right, in relation to which one of its Labor Party colleagues, Mr Gayler, said earlier this year that this faction known for its particular form of thuggery is about the only loyalty that he has known and, with a continuation of that thuggery, it is now almost about to achieve its ultimate objective of putting Mr Keating into the Lodge as Prime Minister of this country. That would be a total travesty of justice, and that is why we have moved this motion this afternoon.

The Australian people will never forgive Mr Paul Keating, the architect of the recession, for the unnecessary misery he has caused so many hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians. They will never forget the Labor Party that rewards him for that disservice to the Australian people. Why is the Labor Party about to undertake this desperate act? Is it because it so despises the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, or is it because Mr Keating and his henchmen will undermine the Party, and continually undermine it, until they achieve their objective, no matter what the consequence? If it is the latter, it means that he is achieving that objective, despite the best interests of the Australian people.

It could not be his economic credentials that are moving his Party in this direction. I remind honourable senators that he said that there would be no recession; he then said that we were likely to skirt a significant recession; he then said that this was the recession that we `had to have'; and he then said that there would be a modest recovery, projected to emerge earlier in the year 1991. He was the Treasurer who gave us inflation rates constantly above the OECD average; he was the Treasurer who gave us interest rates a giant 5 1/4 per cent higher than the OECD average during his years as Treasurer; and he is the one who expounded the J-curve, which became an S-bend, with the collapse of the Australian dollar in 1986. No-one could stand and defend his economic record, at a time when a million Australians are out of work and when another 500,000 Australian have either given up looking for work or, alternatively, cannot get full employment.

If he does not have economic credentials, what does he have to justify the decision that it appears the Labor Party is about to take? The only answer can be that he has the capacity to manipulate. As the former Treasurer said, he has the capacity to flick to vaudeville if that is necessary to achieve his objective. Is his capacity in some way to convince the Australian people that something is true when it is clearly untrue purely the reason he is about to be promoted to this high office?

I said a moment ago that Christmas is but a week away—a time which should be a joyous celebration. For a country as potentially wealthy as Australia, with a small population, a country shielded from the conflicts that exist in so much of the world and a country, which Senator Button should know from his journey overseas last week, which many continue to envy as a land of unlimited opportunity, Australians should be feeling confident and hopeful about an exciting future in the fastest growing region of the world.

Because of the incompetence of this Government, the incompetence of both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating and of all the hangers-on from the Right, the Left, the Centre Left and other factions, it is appalling that it will be a Christmas of misery for so many Australians. As I said, there are one million Australians on the dole queues with another half a million Australians either having given up or underemployed. We have the highest unemployment rate in 60 years, since the Great Depression of the 1930s. There have been shattered hopes and lost dreams, all as a result of incompetent Government policy. The legacy of the Hawke-Keating years will lie in its recognition as one of the worst governments in Australia's history.

When Ministers were asked questions today about their loyalty to Mr Hawke, all they did was laugh it off and say, `We have no responsibility to Parliament. We are not going to answer those questions. We will continue to play our internal power game come what may. We will give no consideration to the misery of the hundreds of thousands of Australians over Christmas'. All the Ministers are interested in is their jobs and the job of their Prime Minister, and not the jobs of one and a half million Australians who are suffering so much.

This Government came into office out of a drought and an economic recession which was no fault of the then government. This Labor Government experienced the good times and the periods of growth. What did we then get from it? We got the accord, that special deal with the unions which gives the ACTU the right to expect wage increases irrespective of market expectations. We saw members of the Government, particularly Senator Richardson and Prime Minister Hawke, link themselves to that orgy of consumption and excess of the mid-1980s—the backslapping, the gladhanding and the passing of huge sums of money through to the leadership group and through to the secretariat of the Labor Party here in Canberra. We heard in the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters about the money flowing from Bond, Hancock, Goldberg, Connell, Dempster et cetera. As a result, this Government lost touch with reality. We then saw the inept economic policy of former Treasurer Keating which mercilessly crushed business through impossible interest rates. This was not just during his final year in office; from 1986 onwards we saw small business overdraft rates around 20 per cent. He was told time and time again that business could not survive in those conditions. He refused to listen, he knew better; he was out of touch. The legacy is now mass unemployment and the misery and suffering that has resulted from it.

In the spirit of this time of the year, we have said that our speakers will be brief, but it is important that we move this motion today because time is against us. This Labor Party in this Parliament has but a couple of days to make decisions. On the one hand, the Government could for the first time for months—some would now argue for years—concentrate on governing the country rather than conducting its own internal power play. It could bring the leadership issue to an end and say, `We are now going to face up to our responsibility as a government rather than simply look to our own jobs and our own interests'. On the other hand, the Government could allow this leadership issue to go on into the new year when the misery of Australians will increase or—the worst decision of all—it could reward the man who is so much responsible for the suffering within Australia, who is so much responsible for the economic demise of this country, and who has so nearly achieved his objective of turning Australia into a banana republic.

This is an important issue before the Government today. It is critical to Australia's future and to the ordinary Australians which those opposite claim to represent but so rarely do in fact. Members of the Government must bring this issue to an end. They must get on with the task of governing—that high responsibility which has been given to them by the people of Australia. The members of the Labor Party must put their factions and the leadership groups—the groups that have been tapping Hawke on the shoulder, then going to Keating and undermining their own side—on one side. It must be brought to an end. Those opposite must face up finally to their responsibilities as a government. If they are not prepared to do that they ought to get out.

We in the Opposition have on the table a new, comprehensive and integrated package that can provide new direction for this country and provide incentive to ordinary Australians to be able to achieve something, to bring benefits to their family and to themselves. Seven hundred pages of material are on the table as an alternative. The Government has put forward no alternative at all.

We have seen three attempts made by the Government during the year with the fourth soon to come up. We have seen the industry statement that was hijacked by Mr Hawke for his own political ends from Senator Button. We have seen a `do nothing' Budget. We have seen a jobs statement that included no new policy change at all but simply a boast that the Budget was on track—one million Australians unemployed and the Budget strategy is on track—and we will see yet another statement in January next year. It is not good enough. Those opposite have either to get on with the task of governing or to get out and give us the opportunity to implement our Fightback program, which will restore hope, opportunity and incentive to ordinary Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether the Fightback program restores hope and opportunity to ordinary Australians is a question which remains to be seen. There can be little doubt, however, that it restores some hope and opportunity to members of the Opposition to get over here—the first they have had in nearly nine years.
—Is this what you call leading from the back?
—I am obviously going to be interrupted by interjections all along.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—I shall give you proper protection, Senator Button.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure I can be assured of that from you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have known about it for a long time. Senator Hill said that hope and opportunity was offered to numerous Australians by the Fightback package and he referred to the 600 or 700 pages of the document. That statement reminded me of an article I read in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning which makes the point that one of the key elements relied upon by the Opposition in its Fightback program is that it will create two million jobs. The article, which is by a prominent former adviser to Liberal Prime Ministers, Mr Gerard Henderson, points out that in those 600 pages there is not one piece of evidence that the Opposition has a hope of creating two million jobs.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill comes in here and talks about hope and opportunity for ordinary Australians, the jobs that will be created and so on, but the only jobs that those opposite are interested in are jobs for themselves. As Gerard Henderson said, there is not a tittle of evidence in the Fightback package that the jobs will be created. The jobs that those opposite are interested in are the jobs over here. I can understand that. I have watched those opposite for a long time. The only time they ever get happy and excited is when unemployment in this country rises. The reason they are so allegro at the moment is that unemployment in this country is very high.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on you.
—There is nothing shameful about that; it is the truth.
—That is a shameful thing to say.
—Order!

—Honourable senators should settle down. I want to be fair about this article because there are several points in it which go to both sides of politics in this country. Not only does Mr Henderson say that the Opposition Fightback package is 600 pages of waffle on this central issue—
—He didn't say waffle.
—That is essentially what he said.
—He said substance.

—Senator Hill can select his bit if he likes; I will select mine. Mr Henderson also referred—and this led Senator Hill to move his motion—to the long-term risk in the coalition's policy strategy, but he goes on to say, `Right now the proverbial brown dog could defeat the Hawke Government'. I agree with that. If we had an election tomorrow, we would be beaten because we have a deep recession in this country, part of which has been contributed to by Government policy. But Senator Hill is less than fair when he lumbers the whole of this current recession on the present Government. We say there are a number of reasons for the current recession in Australia.
—Keating has claimed responsibility for it.

—It is no good uttering mindless slogans at me; listen to the argument. There are a number of reasons for the current recession in Australia. I want to remind honourable senators that the recession here is no worse in its consequences than the recession in most Anglo-Saxon countries in the world such as the United States, the United Kingdom and so on.

PARA.TAB: In the United Kingdom the recession was brought on under a government that followed the sorts of policies the Opposition espouses in the Fightback program. For years in here the Liberal Party argued the great virtues of Margaret Thatcher. What the Liberals really liked about Margaret Thatcher was that she had guts and the Liberals as an Opposition and a government lacked guts; a statement which is proved out of the mouth of the Opposition spokesman on trade, Mr Alex—Smart Alex—Downer, when he said a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives that that was why the Opposition had never done any of these things itself—the Opposition had never tackled any of the hard issues because it lacked guts as a political party.

So for years the Liberal Party espoused and admired the policies of Margaret Thatcher. Now the Liberal Opposition has adopted them as a blueprint solution to Australia's economic problems, which they are not. The Opposition has got very excited about that and about the fact that there is a deep recession in this country. I want to settle the Opposition down a little if I can.

The fact of the matter is that the Australian recession is, of course, distinct from the recessions in the United States, in the United Kingdom and so on for several particular reasons. Two of the particular reasons are access to markets for our rural products and the crisis in major rural industries such as the wool industry. Does any Opposition senator have the nerve to pretend that the crisis in the wool industry is the responsibility of this Government? Does any Opposition senator have the nerve to pretend that? That crisis is not the responsibility of the Government, and the Opposition spokesman, Mr McLachlan, recognises that. He had more guts than the rest of the Opposition senators when the wool crisis came along. There is a severe crisis in the rural industries, which are the great industries of Australia, and that has contributed significantly to the recession in Australia.

The third issue is the behaviour of the financial sector following the excesses of the 1980s which have imposed a credit squeeze on many businesses in Australia at present. Throughout these problems the process of adjustment to the Australian economy has gone on, and that is not an issue the Opposition really addresses at all in those 600 pages of the Fightback! document.

An exporter can look through that document to try to find out what the Fightback proposal will do for him. It may make a marginal difference to his input costs if the goods and services tax is introduced. If he is a rich man it will make more than a marginal difference because the rich will get big tax cuts under the Opposition's proposal; the poor will not. That is a fact which is spelt out in black and white in the Fightback! document, and that is something upon which people can rely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proportionately, that is not right.

—`Proportionately, that is not right', says Senator Hill. I am simply making the point that it is a regressive taxation system. There is no doubt about that. Looking at all the indicators in the Fightback program, which I will come to in a moment, one can see this similar pattern being revealed.

PARA.TAB: This motion talks about the leadership crisis in the ALP, which is a regrettable and sad thing. It secondly goes on to talk about the self-imposed economic crisis, which is half true. On numerous occasions at Question Time we have said that the application of monetary policy in 1989 and 1990 contributed to the depth of this recession. There is no doubt about that; we have said that on many occasions. So what the Opposition says about that is half true but the other half has to be considered, which is the peculiar circumstances of the Australian economy with its large contribution from the rural sector, badly damaged by access to markets, the crisis in the wool industry and so on and the quite extraordinary behaviour of the banking system in this country which is contributing to problems at present.

Senator Hill refers to those two issues and then he says, `Well, the solution to all of this is you say to the Australian people, "We have high levels of unemployment and we, the Liberal Party, have at last found our feet and this time we will be different from all earlier Liberal governments. We will implement this program come hell or high water because we are different from previous Liberals, we've got guts and they never had guts before"'. That is what it is all about.

Looking at the Fightback program and considering the question of unemployment, the first thing one must recognise is that this package, introduced in the sort of economic circumstances we have now, will lead to higher unemployment. That is admitted by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) who I concede has more brains than most of the rest of the Opposition senators put together. The Leader of the Opposition has admitted that this package will lead to higher unemployment.

What else will the Fightback package lead to? Very obviously higher inflation, and the Opposition knows that for certain because if the Opposition looks at its own predictions, that is quite clear. Even taking it out to the end of the decade, on the Opposition's scenarios given in table 19.1, very high levels of unemployment are predicted. But the very high levels would occur when this package is introduced because table 19.1 does not factor in the effects of the GST on these basic economic indicators.

I return to the Opposition's theme again; it is the Opposition's day—it is having its day in court with this motion. At the beginning when this Fightback package was launched, I said it was like a curate's egg, half bad half good and it would get badder and badder and smellier and smellier as time went by. A fortnight later some of the bugs in it are starting to emerge. Some of the criticisms from all around the place are starting to emerge.

The popularity of the Fightback package has gone down by 5 per cent. That is a pretty quick reaction to a program which the Opposition has hard sold for this period of time. The simple point is that Opposition members cannot prescribe these sort of blueprint solutions for the benefit of anybody in this community except themselves. The only jobs one can be sure might benefit from this program if the Opposition were in a position to implement it would be the Opposition's jobs, nobody else's. So that is what the Opposition is getting so excited about.

The Opposition has done tremendous damage to itself in overselling the Fightback package. Mr Gerard Henderson makes this point in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. It is illustrated, for example, by the Opposition's projections on the uncovering of tax cheating with this package and the suggestion in the Fightback package that $4 billion would be recovered from that process.
