Mr Reith and others are on record as saying, `Scratch an Australian and you'll find a cheat' and all that sort of stuff. It is not pretty nice stuff to say about the average Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true, either.
—Nor true. According to Treasury, the projections in the Fightback package are clearly wrong. Those opposite projected they would save $4 billion; Treasury says that is a gross exaggeration.

PARA.TAB: Two months ago Mr Reith was saying that $40 billion would be recovered from this. The alternative Treasurer of a potential Liberal government was saying that $40 billion would be recovered from Australia's black economy. It went down suddenly from $40 billion to $4 billion when those opposite hit the cold light of day and actually had to release it in black and white. This was said by the potential Treasurer of Australia. He is the man who multiplies projected figures by 10. That is how rubbery the figures of an alternative government are in this package.

The three issues are: one, the leadership. I am afraid those opposite cannot do anything about that; I guess we have to. The second is the self-imposed economic crisis. That is a half-true allegation. Over a period I have said that there is some truth in that. Thirdly, there are the great virtues of the Fightback program, which are a solution to all the problems which this country is presently confronting and which, I am sad to say, it will have to continue to confront for some time to come because of the need to adjust a whole range of firms and industries to compete in the world, which Australia was not used to doing. Most Australians who think seriously about it know that that is true.

Sadly, the old Fightback program does not address many of those issues. It is all about a tax-led recovery: a `greed is good' led recovery. These are the sorts of slogans and mental attitudes of the 1980s; they are not appropriate to a country confronting these problems in the 1990s. For that reason the solution foreshadowed is not a very good one.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are as tired as your Government; you haven't got much life.

—I know that Senator MacGibbon is a dentist, but he is totally unqualified to comment on my health as a general rule. Dentistry is normally regarded as the most anal-erotic profession in the world. That is what Senator MacGibbon should stick to; he should not comment about people's health. I am okay, thanks. I have limited qualifications in psychology, but I decline to use them in commenting on Senator MacGibbon; it is not appropriate. The Government rejects this motion. No doubt we will continue to discuss these issues for some time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The lack of clarity with which the Opposition approaches the future is well exemplified by the way in which Senator Hill approached his motion, the wording of which is as follows:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate calls on Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self imposed economic crisis and to urgently adopt the Coalition's visionary `Fightback' program in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of what Senator Hill had to say was really aimed at Mr Keating's performance, the presumptive Labor Party leader, should its leadership change. It is quite clear from that that the Opposition, in framing its motion, is not concerned about this country's plight as a consequence of the leadership wrangle but is far more intent on damaging the reputation of the person whom it sees as possibly the new leader of both Labor and this country within the next few days. That is really doing more damage to this country to the extent that it is effective. Unless the Opposition is capable of wording motions and speaking to them with greater clarity, greater precision, it is really not presenting itself in a way that will enjoin much sympathy or support from the Australian electorate.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Spindler pointed out the other day, the situation in Germany in the 1930s was not that dissimilar from Australia's situation today, in that there was then 30 per cent youth unemployment. There was a high level of unemployment. While inflation was high, which is not true in Australia, other economic factors made the plight of German people really quite desperate. It was similar to the situation in Australia today. If one looks at history one sees quite clearly that in times such as that the electorate turns to what appears to be a way out without looking too closely at what has been offered.

I agreed with Senator Button when he described the Fightback package as lacking substance. The Democrats also believe that there is a very considerable element of legerdemain involved in that package. When one looks at precise ways in which unemployment—Senator Button mentioned this—will be addressed and precise ways in which the economy will be improved, one finds an ideological belief in the operation of free and unfettered markets to deliver the goods, with very little substance in relation to precisely what goods will be delivered, to whom and when.

That brings the Democrats to a criticism which we make both of the Government and of the Opposition. I remind the Senate yet again that Mr Howard, then the shadow Treasurer, said that Mr Keating, then the Treasurer, had had his reform package accepted so easily precisely because the package that Labor was implementing was based on Liberal Party policy.

We have Tweedledum and Tweedledee, as a former Leader of the Democrats has described them. Labor has been pursuing deregulation, leaving it to the markets, with some slight reticence because it has been held back by some of its more traditional Labor forces. The Liberal-National Party coalition simply wants to take that same package further.

The circumstances which have led Australia to its present condition of high unemployment and massive foreign indebtedness will simply not be benefited by the Fightback package. Unregulated markets simply cannot deliver a vision; unregulated markets leave it to the very people who are, to a considerable extent, responsible for this country's plight. The Bonds, the Skases and the others who have borrowed massively overseas, who have bought well established Australian industries, have gone down the gurgler. Those industries have then passed into foreign hands.

Nothing in the Fightback package indicates that the Opposition, if it gets power, will re-regulate banking. Senator Button admitted that the deregulation of banking, together with the deregulation of foreign exchange, was one of the significant factors leading this country to its present predicament. Nothing in the Fightback package suggests that the Opposition will do anything different.

I am reminded of a piece which Ross Gittins wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald about 10 days ago. He pointed out that Dr Hewson was economic adviser to former Prime Minister Fraser and was providing the sort of advice that led this country to its predicament immediately before Labor took over. The Ross Gittins line—I agree with him—was that Dr Hewson is suggesting solutions to problems which were faced unsuccessfully through the 1970s and into the early 1980s. In other words, Dr Hewson is suggesting old solutions to old problems and is ignoring the fact that, as any observation would indicate, those solutions, even to the old problems, simply did not work.

Senator Button pointed out that similar conditions obtain throughout quite a number of countries in the Western industrialised world at the present time. He instanced the United Kingdom and the United States. Of course, it is absolutely true. The United Kingdom Government under Margaret Thatcher followed the same deregulatory ideology, the same leave it to the market ideology, as that which has been pursued by the Labor Government with Mr Hawke as captain and Mr Keating as navigator, and which has landed this country on the rocks. Again, I can only stress that accession to government by the Opposition, should that occur and should we see an attempted implementation of this Fightback package, would do nothing whatsoever to address the very serious problems, because fundamentally, ideologically and philosophically the Opposition and the Government are pursuing the same course, but simply with different degrees of vigour.

Senator Hill drew attention to the way in which the Government was presenting unreal solutions or no solutions to the present problems. Of course, one area in which that is absolutely evident, and one that indicates the abysmal lack of vision of both the Government and the Opposition at the present time, is the proposal to build a multifunction polis in Australia. The Government has maintained that the MFP will be the largest development ever undertaken in this country, running into multi-billions of dollars. The vision is that Australian research and development is no good, that we need to import our research and development from overseas and that somehow, through building this MFP over the next 15 or 20 years or so, Australian industry will be led out of the valley of desolation and destruction into which it has been taken.

Many Opposition senators recognise the MFP as a mirage. Yet, when I moved in this place a motion to remove the expenditure of millions of dollars on this mirage under the Budget allocations, the Opposition simply moved away from that. The Opposition is not serious about presenting an alternative vision, one in which much of the leading first-class research in this country is supported by government, not damaged by government, and turned into useful and productive enterprises. In recent days we have seen the neutralisis process in Brisbane, which is a way of dealing with urban and other wastes, put up for sale. This technology has simply not been supported. Despite the fact that it is eminently evident to anybody with eyes that it is a technology which not only Australia but also the world needs, it has been allowed to remain unsupported and the company will be lost to this country. Similarly, the Memtec technology has gone offshore, as has the solar thermal technology, where we have the leading technology in the world. These are the sorts of things which clearly direct our attention towards where this country, and where the world, needs to move—where we have leading-edge technology and where government needs to recognise the vision. But neither the Government nor the Opposition has either the vision or the economic policies which can lead to a fulfilment of that vision.

We need to move back from the brink towards the Government's putting its hand firmly back on the levers of economic control. We are the elected representatives of the people and we should not leave it to those naked, greedy market forces in the community to determine the shape of Australian society in the future—something which both the Government and the Opposition are driven to do by the ideological belief in the market as a way of relating people in a society.

The Democrats believe that many parts of the economy need to be selectively re-regulated and that government control should be imposed for the benefit of the people of this country. As long as we continue to go down the deregulated road and leave the Australian economy locked into those of other countries, we will lose control of our economy. We will simply throw up our hands, as Mr Keating often did as Treasurer, and say, `It is not my fault; it is the fault of the recession in the US or the recession in the UK' or `It is a failure of the markets here or the failure of the markets there'. We need to control the economy in this country for the benefit of Australians. We will only do that when this Government, or the government of this country, places its hands firmly on the levers of economic control once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to Senator Coulter very closely. I did not hear him address the motion that is before the Senate at the moment. Senator Coulter took us on a journey on some of the favourite hobbyhorses of the Australian Democrats. The Senate deserves to address the motion before it, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate calls on Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self imposed economic crisis and urgently adopt the Coalition's visionary `Fightback' program in the national interest.
I cannot think of a more important motion to be debated by the Senate than that put before it by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill.

PARA.TAB: This farce has been going on since May when Mr Keating first made his challenge. Effectively, this country has not had a firm government committed to getting Australia out of its crisis since that day. On that day we saw the debate switch. Mr Keating decided that he would make his run into the prime ministership. We saw Mr Keating put out in the press and the electronic media the story of his meeting with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), both having referees. Mr Keating told us that the Prime Minister gave a firm commitment that he would get the gong. Mr Keating was very upset when the Prime Minister reneged on his promise. I can understand why he would be upset; but that is not the issue at the moment.

Since that challenge was made in May, and lost, this Government has not had any effective leadership. It is stumbling around with its eyes fixed firmly on who is going to be the next leader. The knives are out. Every person has a position. The factions want their man up and they want the spoils of office that come from having their particular faction member in the prime ministership. That is all that is being debated around this place at the moment. It is all that is in the press; it is all that is on the television; it is all that is on the radio; and, as I say, it is all that is being debated in the back rooms and corridors of this place, when there are more important issues to be debated in this Parliament.

If ever Australia needed a firm hand on the Government tiller, it needs one now. Every person in Australia is worried about the crisis that Australia is in. It does not matter one iota what section of industry we are talking about, whether it be the farm industry, small business or big business. The whole of Australia is in a crisis. That crisis is not being helped at any time by a government that will not face reality. We have seen the foreign debt figure grow to $168 billion and the trade account deficit figure grow to $15 billion. What was Senator Button's answer to that? It was to cut tariffs when every other nation was increasing subsidies. When every other nation was increasing protection, we cut our tariffs. The effect of that was that Australia became a net importer of more and more goods, and that drove the trade deficit up every year. The latest rural figures, released today, reflect a sad state of affairs for rural Australia. Incomes will be reduced by 75 per cent on last year's figure, and last year's figure came from a very low base.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your policies will cut these tariffs even more.

—Our policy will certainly get economic reform before any tariffs are cut. We have the worst unemployment figures, with one million people unemployed. It is now recognised that we are in the worst depression since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Our youth unemployment is growing. Thirty-one per cent of our young people cannot get jobs. I have said time and time again that it is a disgrace when this nation cannot provide a future for its young people. All we are seeing is a continuous fight—the Hawke faction versus the Keating faction. That is all that is being debated. There is no focus on the problems of the 500,000 young people who will be seeking a job next year. No-one is worried about them. All Government members are worried about is getting their man up.

PARA.TAB: Last week we saw a group of six people trying to persuade the Prime Minister to step down, to remove himself from office. They were the people who supported Hawke. They marched into his office and demanded that he resign for the good of the country and for the good of the Party. He told them where to get off, that he was going to pull the temple down irrespective of what that did to Australia.

Last week, we saw Mr Beazley, Mr Duffy, and Senator Evans go in and tell Mr Hawke that he had to get out of office. Today we saw another group of Ministers go in—Mr Dawkins, Dr Blewett, Senator Cook, Mrs Kelly and Senator Richardson. They are from the other side. I wonder what they told Mr Hawke today. This great nation of Australia is struggling to survive without any effective hand on the controls of government. No-one is doing anything. We are going from one crisis to another. We are seeing government policy being raffled off.

On the main page of the Australian, Senator Crowley is reported as saying that she was going to go for Mr Keating because he would abolish the Medicare surcharge. We are raffling off the future of this country to the highest bidder. Whether Mr Hawke will give some carrot to the Left or whether Mr Keating can outbid him and give something more to the Left, the whole policy of Australia is being raffled off.

Today, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) said that we had to make Australia competitive. No-one disagrees with that. That is what it is all about. One thing the Government has done is get inflation down. The new Treasurer, Mr Willis, has come out and said, `We are not going to worry about inflation any more. That is a thing of the past. We have put too much emphasis on inflation. Let's prime the pump. Let's get it going'.

There is a direct conflict between the man who leads this Party in the Senate, Senator Button, and Mr Willis, the Treasurer in the other place. Only today, Senator Button said that we have to make these decisions so that Australia can become more competitive. Mr Willis has said, `We are not going to worry about inflation. We are going to be an interventionist government. We are going to increase intervention and get the economy going'. That is typical of what is happening in this Parliament at the moment. There is conflict, indecision and we have a government in paralysis. We are not going anywhere. Australia needs some sort of certainty. This Government is not able to give that. We need certainty; we are getting paralysis.

It is no wonder that support in the polls is going up for the coalition and going down for the Government. The coalition is now 19 points in front. That is a total vote of no confidence in the Government by the people of Australia. The Prime Minister is hanging on and saying, `I'm three times more popular with Labor voters than my opponent, Mr Keating'. He may be, but the number of Labor voters is shrinking. The Labor Party cannot get a base much lower than 30 per cent. Every party must retain or hold some base. The Labor Party's base is 30 per cent. One would not think that it could go any lower than that, but I am certain that it will go lower unless Australia gets effective government.

The Government has had four attempts to get it right. There have been four major economic statements. The reply has been that there has been an increase in unemployment, an increase in bankruptcies, an increase in people being forced off their farms and an increase in the despair confronting the whole nation. The March industry statement was supposed to be the blueprint for building a competitive Australia. That did not get very far. Then we had the Budget. The Government turned a $9 billion surplus into a $1.8m deficit. That is a pretty effective government.

This year we are facing a $4.7m deficit. Only a couple of months ago the Government released an unemployment statement that just did not go anywhere. Now the Prime Minister is saying that if the economic forecasts in mid-January are bad—and confidential Treasury figures say that the Budget forecast of 1.5 per cent economic growth will reduce to one per cent—the Government will have another try. What will we do? Where is the plan when every three months this Government brings in another economic policy to get it out of some sort of mess, to lift its polls and to lift its popularity? No wonder the people of Australia have absolutely no confidence in this Government. The Government has had four attempts to get it right and it has had four failures.

Mr Willis has now said that the Government will be interventionist. It is going to prime the pump and it is not going to worry about inflation. Senator Button says that we have to make the nation more competitive. Where is Mr Hawke? Is he somewhere in between the two positions? Where is Mr Keating? Mr Keating will design a policy that will get him the numbers he needs to get into government, and so will Mr Hawke. The whole policy of this Government is being driven by who can get the numbers in Caucus. Surely this nation deserves better than that. That is effectively what is happening in Australia at the moment.

This Government has said that its main achievement has been controlling inflation. Even today it says that this has been achieved at some cost. But it is a terrible cost—one million people unemployed, 30 per cent of primary producers probably having to leave their farms and a 58 per cent increase in bankruptcies. That is the cost we have had to pay to get inflation down. But the Government is now going to abandon that policy. It is going to walk away from that position and not worry about it any more. After making all these people suffer pain, after destroying not only their jobs but also their social welfare and ability to go out and meet other people—they are becoming introverted—the Government is going to abandon that policy.

I often wonder what the union movement thinks. What do the people who pay $180 a year to belong to, for example, the Building Workers Industrial Union or the carpenters union, think about this Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll tell you what. They're joining the Democrats.

—I think they will be terribly misled and terribly disappointed. But I understand the frustration of backing a government that has turned its back on them and destroyed their welfare, their ability to pay their houses off and their ability to get jobs. Why would they not walk away from this Government? They have done so because the Government has walked away from them and has not given them a thought. How can any government say that it supports the family when it increases interest rates on homes? How can it say that it supports rural industry and small business when it has allowed interest rates to run at 23 per cent and imposed a 3 per cent surcharge? Very few businesses can sustain those interest rates. The Government has run along with that policy. How can anyone export, be it a primary producer, a small business person, a manufacturer or a mining company, when the Australian dollar is running at US81c? That is the confusion and paralysis in which this Government finds itself. It has given no leadership whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: When the coalition comes out with a package that includes savings of $9 billion from the abolition of wholesale sales tax, $6.6 billion from the abolition of petroleum tax and $5.9 billion from abolishing payroll tax—which is a tax on jobs—and reduces freight costs, it is no wonder that we have risen in the polls and that we are in front by 20 per cent. We are offering some hope and are giving some direction. We have a plan and a blueprint. People will say that any decision is better than no decision. That is what we are doing today.

Compare that with what the Government has done to business. The Labor Party has imposed compulsory training and superannuation levies and this has resulted in record bankruptcies. So the difference is one of a coalition with a plan and a government that is racked by paralysis and leadership challenges. I believe that this is a very good motion and it should be supported by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this motion. In doing so, I am reminded of the story of Lady Astor and Winston Churchill. When told by her that he was drunk, Winston Churchill retorted that he might be drunk but she was ugly. He then went on to say, `I will be sober in the morning but you will still be ugly'. I am reminded of that story because today we are presented with a motion which is critical of a government for going through a process which I am sure we would all rather not be going through. But at the end of the day the Opposition will have to live with its policy prescription for the duration of this Government's term and into the next election. It is one that I am sure the Australian public will not find attractive.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Button has indicated, we are going through a recession; that is not denied. It is part of a worldwide recession; that is not denied. In some respects, we are different from the rest of the world in that we are doing two things: we are having to live through a rural recession and, importantly, at long last, structural change is occurring throughout our community. We are now going through change that should have evolved over the years.

Our challenge is to respond to the recession and particularly to unemployment. All of us in this place have to realise that we should not expect the Australian people to believe that there is an easy answer. There is no easy answer. To the extent that parties in this place suggest that there is, I tend to agree with Senator Coulter that they will be exposed and are being exposed for their dishonesty. As a consequence, maybe minor parties are picking up voters and supporters. This is reflected in the polls as well as in other areas.

The question we have to ask is: who is best able to take us through this recession and who has the best policy prescription? On our side there is not only a commitment to getting out of the recession and meeting the challenge of unemployment but also a commitment which is based on the principles of social justice. We believe that those who suffer in this recession should be protected as much as possible as we fight our way through it. I say unequivocally on behalf of this Government that it is our priority to get through this recession and reduce unemployment in a way that best suits our social justice policies. (Quorum formed)

What a fraud! Opposition senators came into the chamber and raised a matter of urgency. They then called a quorum but not one extra Opposition senator came into the chamber. Not only that, just before the quorum was called Senator Knowles looked and made sure—we all noticed it—that four Liberal senators walked out of this chamber, including the person who raised this matter of urgency. They vacated the chamber in order to ensure that a quorum could be called. If this matter is so urgent, let us have consistency. If it is so urgent, let us not have this sign of hypocrisy. If it is so urgent, why are Opposition senators not here in the chamber responding to this matter of urgency? They are a fraud and, as I was saying at the start of my contribution, they will be exposed as such through their package.

The Opposition has offered the Australian people nothing more than a poisoned toffee apple. There is lots of toffee and gloss on the outside, but the people are licking at it to their disaffection. They are finding that it is riddled with poison on the inside. Let us have a look at this package. What is the Opposition offering? It is offering an economic miracle; an economic vision. But this proposal has been tried before; it has been tried and it has failed. It was tried in the UK and it failed; it was tried in New Zealand and it failed; and it was tried in the US and it failed. If one talks to any leading world statesmen about this package of consumption tax, one will find that they do not believe a party could be so foolhardy and inequitable in its policy projection as to do what the Opposition is doing.

What is the Opposition doing in its proposal? It is reducing the tax on guns, perfume and jewellery but increasing the tax on food and clothes. The Opposition is reducing the tax on Audi GLs, Mercedes and those sorts of cars, but it is increasing it by the same amount on a family home. Under the Opposition's proposal, Australian workers and the Australian business community will be worse off. There is no vision for them in the package as it has been proposed. What vision does it offer for the Australian workers who will have their rights totally dismantled; what vision does it offer for migrants, students or the women in our community; and what vision does it offer pensioners and country people? I am offended by Senator Boswell coming in here as the Leader of the National Party of Australia—a country-based party—and denying the fact that his constituency will be worst hit by this package.

In terms of the broad areas, what vision do we find for the arts or the environment? Absolutely none; only cutbacks. What vision for industry is in the package? There is the vision of being bound in red tape. Let us talk about efficiency: 2.2 billion companies will have to fill out forms as a result of the Opposition's little idea of a consumption tax, of which 70,000 may in the end have to pay tax.

It is a computer-driven policy, the main beneficiaries being those in the computer industry who will have to sell their computers to something like two million companies in our community. Those opposite may babble over there, but the people who will be hit most will be the small businesses and they are finding that out.

There is no vision in this policy proposal. But I will go through a number of economic parameters. We are accused of conceding the fight against inflation at the expense of unemployment. Those who are making that accusation in the community and those who are making it in here ought to understand full well that our commitment has brought inflation down to 3 per cent. Those on the other side will blindly, mindlessly and cold-heartedly reduce it to 2 per cent. How much more unemployment is implicit in that proposal? One then needs to take into account the Opposition's high road proposal, as set out in its package, for two million more jobs by the year 2000. That alternative has already been disowned by the Opposition. In fact, it was disowned in the Opposition's policy document where it says that a job creation program of two million jobs in the next 10 years does not purport to portray the outcomes which would be achieved by implementation of that package.

We are criticised for keeping interest rates too high, but every decrease in interest rates over the recent terms of this Government has been criticised by Dr Hewson as being `politically motivated'. I do not think his blind, mindless and ill-based policy to remove the Reserve Bank of Australia from any influence of government will do anything but lead to higher interest rates. I am sure this is recognised in the community, and those opposite understand that as well.

We are criticised for allowing the Budget deficit to increase to the tune of about $5m this financial year. I am saying these sorts of things because it indicates how hard the job is. It also indicates that there is no miracle answer to these problems. We are criticised for allowing the Budget deficit to blow out, but at the same time we are criticised for not ploughing enough funds into infrastructure. This is the twin attack from the Opposition. There is no consistency; it is full of hypocrisy.

I have mentioned unemployment, but the Opposition's document gives a lie to the sort of promotion that was given to the package at the start. It was promoted like a US basketball game, with probably less social utility. The Opposition's employment objectives have already been exposed as being inadequate. We are also criticised for our policies in respect of the manufacturing sector and its protection against imports. We have a phase-down policy. The Opposition has indicated very loudly and very stridently that its policy is not phase-down; it is total phase-out.

As I have said, there is no vision in this policy, for a number of reasons. The basic reason is that this policy is based on inequity. Secondly, it does not stand up in a macro sense. It is in fact a con for most workers in the community; the jobs claim is a con. More importantly, we are talking about a policy which has been well promoted, well packaged and well pushed by the Opposition, but it is a package which has some major gaps. The Opposition has no wages policy, but it has a very direct high inflation policy and a very direct high interest rate policy. It is no wonder that social commentators such as the Catholic Weekly and Archbishop Peter Hollingworth from the Anglican Church in Brisbane are on record as indicating that this policy is inequitable. But, more than that, it has major holes at the macro level and major holes at the micro level.

We will get over our particular problem—and the sooner we do the better for this country. It is very much the objective of everyone on this side of the chamber to go to the next election with an honest policy to redress the recession. But we will not wait until then; the wheels are in motion to achieve that aim before we go to the next election. Senator Knowles may be happy here today being a parasite on our problems, but we will get over those. We will sober up in the morning, but she will still be ugly with her package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) meant his last comment metaphorically.
—Metaphorically.
—Thank you, I would like that to be recognised on the record. The urgency motion we are debating today states:

PARA.TAB: The Senate calls on Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self imposed economic crisis and to urgently adopt the Coalition's visionary `Fightback' program in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: We are meant to be talking about the leadership farce within the Australian Labor Party, yet Senator Bolkus and Senator Button, in both their contributions, have made a lame duck attempt to try to say that our policy—the Fightback program—is inadequate. However, we have asked constantly for three to four weeks, `What is your alternative?'. Not one Minister has been able to come into this chamber, not one Minister has gone public and not one member of the Government has gone out to the public to say, `This will be our policy'. Yet last week people from the Government said time in time out that they needed a redirection of policy.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite are absolutely rudderless. They are wasting taxpayers' money trying to blow our package out of the water, yet at no stage have they got Treasury to concentrate on re-evaluating the direction of this country or on redirecting their own failed policies. The latest Treasurer, Mr Willis, has admitted that the policy direction is wrong and that it will have to be revamped. But what do those opposite have Treasury doing? Treasury is sitting over there trying to blow our policy out of the water, although those opposite do not have one policy alternative to put to the people of Australia. They do not have one policy alternative to put to the more than one million people who are out of work. They do not have one policy alternative to put to all the people who are going bankrupt. They do not have one policy alternative to put to all the people who are struggling this Christmas and who face absolute uncertainty in the new year.

Is it not time that this Government solved this leadership crisis and got on with the job of redirecting and changing its policies to come up with something different as its vision for Australia? Senator Bolkus's contribution was nothing but absurd. He talked about hypocrisy. Let us look at the hypocrisy. He claims that our vision in the Fightback package lacks detail. But where is the Government's detail? We have produced nearly 700 pages of detail. But all those opposite are worried about is the Labor Party; all they are worried about is Mr Keating and Mr Hawke.

On not one occasion, in all the interviews that every member of the Labor Party has been prepared to give in the last week about the leadership crisis, have I heard one of them talk about the need to solve this problem for the sake of the country. They have talked long and hard about Mr Hawke; they have talked long and hard about Mr Keating; they have talked long and hard about winning government; they have talked long and hard about the Labor Party; but not once have they talked about the sake of this country. Is it not about time they started to do so? This Government is just a scandal and a national disaster. The country's future has simply been sacrificed for Mr Keating and Mr Hawke—both as bad as each other; both with egos one could not even jump over—while the numbers are being played.

Senator Bolkus chucked a tantrum because a quorum was called on him this afternoon. The reason I called a quorum was that there had not been one Labor senator in this chamber since Question Time. The Leader of the Government in the Senate had to speak to an empty chamber—other than Opposition senators—because not one person was prepared to support him. Senator Bolkus was exactly the same. We just thought we would test the waters to see how many of his colleagues would come in to support him. Sure, they came in to make up a quorum, but they left 30 seconds later.

Those opposite should not talk to us about the need for this urgency motion. We see cowardice at the moment in Ministers who will not stand up for what they believe in. The Prime Minister has a huge ego. In his words he is still the greatest; he is still the one who can win; he is the only one with policies—we would like to see them, would we not?—and he is the one who will not go. Senator Bolkus was one of the wimps who went along to the Prime Minister the other day and said, `Come on, Bob, I think it's time; I think your time's up'. Yet the Prime Minister just pushed the six of them aside and said, `Not now, sonny boys; I am staying because I am the one who can win'.

What is Senator Button on about? Why does Senator Button not stand by his convictions? Why does Senator Button not do something? It is Senator Button who gave Mr Hayden the flick in favour of Mr Hawke eight or nine years ago. The irony of it is that when Senator Button saw fit to give Mr Hayden the flick, Mr Hayden was 17 points above where Mr Hawke is today. Why does not Senator Button go to Mr Hawke and say, `Shove it, sonny boy, you are off'? It is about time that Australians were able to get a clear policy direction. It is about time that this Government took stock of what it is doing, got all this rot out of the way and started governing the country. But no, the numbers game is more important.

Quite frankly, Australians have the right to question the judgment of the Prime Minister and the judgment of Mr Keating. Back in March last year the Prime Minister said that there was no need to fear a recession in any sense. What an outrageous statement that was. Then, of course, he promised a recovery by mid-1991—this year—and we know what happened to that. He promised to hand over the leadership to Paul Keating; another broken promise. He breaks promises as far as the electorate is concerned and he breaks promises as far as his colleagues are concerned. Where is the propriety of this man?

Neither the Prime Minister nor his Government are capable of leading this country out of the depression we are in today. What sort of loyalty is he commanding from this Government at the moment when 12 out of 15 of his Cabinet colleagues say that he should walk the plank? Quite frankly, for this country, the sooner the better. But where is the courage of the convictions of the Ministers who sit on the front benches of both Houses of this Parliament? It is not to be seen.

Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, is quoted as saying that the Prime Minister is `just sand on the highways and byways of politics', and `Bob will show respect for the Labor Party' in the end. Is that not nice? How about respect for the people of Australia? Is it not about time that the people of Australia were shown some respect by these people? No. All they are worried about is the Labor Party; all they are worried about is Mr Keating; all they are worried about is Mr Hawke.

The Minister for Land Transport, Mr Bob Brown, said that the only way the leadership crisis can be resolved is by the elevation of the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Keating. Where does that all end? It seems quite acceptable for a Minister to say that his leader should go, yet not resign himself. That is what we have seen across the front benches of both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Minister sitting here now, Senator Collins, has said that the Prime Minister should go. It is absolute disloyalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not. Balderdash!

—That is exactly what the Minister said on television as he was waddling to his plane last night, and he knows it. The thing is that not one of these Ministers has even dared to offer his resignation, because they want their jobs. Senator Bolkus knows that he would be without a job with Mr Keating as the leader.

PARA.TAB: An unnamed Minister—someone who was not even courageous enough to be named—stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The entire Cabinet has either asked him to go or voted against him. This Government has been reduced to hopelessness by the normal operations of the Opposition.

At least that Minister had the honesty to acknowledge that the normal operations of the Opposition have reduced this Government to the hopelessness that we are seeing today. Yet is there one member or senator in the Government who is prepared to do anything about it? Let us see. Perhaps Mr Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, will be prepared to do something tomorrow. But will anyone else have that courage? I doubt it. Then, of course, we have the great alternative: Mr Keating. Where do we end up with Mr Keating?

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, is sitting opposite flapping his gums, but I cannot hear what he is saying so it is not worth responding. He declared that it was unthinkable for the leadership issue to drag on into the new year. But what is he doing about it? Absolutely nothing; not one thing. Yet he stood there on television, then waddled off to his plane saying, `It's unthinkable that it lasts; it's unthinkable that he stays on'.

What is the alternative? Mr Keating is the alternative. What a wonderful choice we have! The double-crosser of his leader while he was Deputy Prime Minister, and he has consistently done that from the back bench. He is prepared to pander to the left wing to get the job at any cost. He does not care. He will do anything to pander to the left wing. He is the architect of all our woes and the worst recession in 60 years.

There are more than one million people unemployed. I always say `more than one million people unemployed' because whilst theoretically it may be 700,000 or thereabouts, there are people who are deemed to be not unemployed because they work one hour a week. What absolute rot! Those people are very much unemployed. Paul Keating has given this country well over one million unemployed people and, of course, the highest rate of bankruptcies that it has ever seen.

This is the person who is the alternative for this Government. If it is that bankrupt for ideas and possible leaders, where is the opportunity for this country? This is the man who said in March 1990, `We won't let there be a recession'; the man who, on 30 November 1990, boasted that we were having the recession that we had to have. Let nobody seek to cast the responsibility elsewhere. On 11 March 1990 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: before 1985 Australia was run by the bureaucracy. This Government runs the whole outfit. I run economic policy—and the Government.
They were Mr Keating's words.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we're in trouble.
—That is exactly right. He was not denying his responsibility for our economic fate 12 months ago when he proclaimed:

SPEECH.PARA: I have the Treasury in my pocket, the Reserve Bank in my pocket, wages policy in my pocket—the financial community, both here and overseas, in my pocket.

Quite frankly, I think he also had his hands in his pocket. To say that we know who is to blame for today's recession is stating the obvious. He knows, we know, he has admitted it and we have to cop it—we have to accept it. On 6 December last year he stated:
we've used the levers to pull Australia into a slowdown, now a recession. We will also use the levers to pull it out.

We are all waiting, are we not? It is about time that this Government got its act together, resolved this leadership farce and started to look at the real options and the real policies that the coalition has put together in the Fightback package, because the Government certainly is not capable of putting any alternative politics together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The one issue on which the Opposition and the Government are in absolute agreement—as can be seen from this debate and others—is that the central problem with the Australian economy at the moment is that tragic human problem of unemployment. It was the major problem—
—Then you ought to be concentrating on that rather than the internal leadership struggle.
—I did not interrupt your speech, Senator Hill, and I only have—
—You weren't in the chamber.

—That is why I did not interrupt. As I only have 10 minutes, I would ask Senator Hill to bear with me as it is his debate. The Opposition and the Government do agree that the central problem is unemployment. It was the tragic unemployment that this country was driven to under the previous conservative government that we inherited—
—We are in the 1990s.
—And which, I am perfectly happy to concede, was the most significant election issue that won government for the Labor Party.
—A decade down the track and you are still blaming us.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, if Senator Knowles would like to wash her ears out, as well as her mouth perhaps, she would in fact have not been able to get that inference—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek to have the Minister withdraw that statement. I have not said anything that is requiring the washing out of my mouth. Because I take offence to the comment, I would seek the withdrawal of that statement.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President; nothing I have said is even approaching being unparliamentary. I ignored—and the Hansard will show it—the personal reflections that Senator Knowles made against me during her speech. As I said by way of interjection at the time, if personal reflections are to be the order of the day, I can accommodate Senator Knowles on that ground as well as anyone can in this chamber.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like to speak to that point of order because I do think there was an unfavourable reflection on Senator Knowles. I distinctly heard the Minister say she ought to wash her ears out. If that is not a reflection on her personal hygiene, I want to know what is.
—With respect, that is not a point of order, but I would say, Minister, that the phrase is less than elegant.

—I often am, Madam Acting Deputy President. In this debate, the Opposition and the Government appear to agree that unemployment is the most serious problem we have and it is the one which we both should responsibly address. That is why I believe the Opposition stands utterly condemned, in a way that no other political party has deserved to be condemned in recent years, for being as deceitful as it has been in its statements made about the employment prospects that it would create under this Fightback! document. The reason I make this point is that I have pointed this out to the Senate already; it has not only not been denied by the Opposition—
—It has so been denied.

—But we know, of course, that it is fundamentally true. My own office, in fact, contacted Access Economics and established the truth of the assertions made in here about the employment projections of the Opposition's document. Considering how important, indeed vital, the subject of creating more employment for Australians is at the moment, the Opposition truly stands condemned for offering what is in fact a false hope to Australians in terms of what its Fightback package is likely to achieve.
—That is not what the experts say.
—I will tell honourable senators what the experts say, in response to that—
—You have found some to support your case, have you?

—No, not at all. It is just a matter of fact. The Opposition has consistently claimed that the Fightback! document demonstrates, and in fact asserts, that the Opposition will create two million new jobs by the year 2000. If we refer to supplementary paper No. 1, which is the employment paper attached to the Opposition's document that contains those projections, and if we go to option C, which is the higher road scenario, the maximum employment to be generated, we find that the Opposition's own documents assert that 1.527 million jobs—I think I am correct—that is, one and a half million jobs, will be created by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: It is quite okay for the Opposition, of course, to just tack another half a million jobs on top of that scenario and simply say two million. But the fundamental deceit contained in that document—and it is a cruel deceit to pull on the Australian people—is that those projections are not an analysis of the Opposition's document at all, and that is a matter of fact. What those projections are—and a cruel deceit it is—are an analysis—

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't purport to be.

—I am delighted that we now have some truth in the debate. Senator Short interjects and says, `They don't purport to be'. Madam Acting Deputy President, I refer you and, indeed, any other honourable senator in this chamber to the endless public statements made by Opposition spokespeople on the GST package and suggest to them—I am delighted at that interjection, Senator Short—that if those figures do not purport to be, and they do not in the document purport to be, then it is about time Opposition members who speak on it publicly, and I can produce 100 statements without any difficulty, `fessed up' to the electorate and admitted publicly, as Senator Short now has, that they do not purport to be based on any analysis of that document.
—Read page 123.

—I have read the document, Senator. Listen to what I am saying. The document does exactly what Senator Short says. It identifies those figures as not being an analysis of the employment projections of the Opposition's document. Senator Short is correct. It is about time that the people who are representing the Opposition—and I will get on to a couple of spectacular examples of this in terms of talkback radio in a minute—admitted that publicly and stopped trying to fool the Australian people into believing that their document comes to the conclusion that two million new jobs will be created because of their proposals.

PARA.TAB: That employment document, supplementary paper No. 1, is in fact a computer analysis of the projections of Industry Commission reports, not the GST package at all. That is breathtaking deceit on the part of the Opposition when both the Opposition and the Government concede that the fundamental key question is, in fact, employment. To try to fool the Australian people to that extent is a cruel deceit, indeed. The entire package—and this is where it falls down—is not based on real life at all. We have already pointed out a number of substantial errors in it. The Opposition's package is a computer model generated on a computer by Access Economics in Melbourne. The cruel deceit in that document is that the Opposition has not produced, and I challenge it to do so, because it has an obligation to do so, employment projections that are actually based on its package that include the impact of a goods and services tax, that is, a VAT tax which many, many British migrants in this country know the realities of and know how wonderful it is for people on low incomes! That has not been included in the Opposition's analysis of its own document.

So those employment projections are false, and I am delighted that Senator Short has been so helpful to me in this debate by putting on the public record in the Hansard that those projections are false and are not based—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the page.

—I have read the page, Senator. I would ask Senator Short to point to the last occasion when any prominent spokesperson on the Opposition's front bench has publicly acknowledged that the figure of two million new jobs being bandied around to the Australian electorate is based on an analysis which is not of its own document but of Industry Commission reports. It is a disgrace. I will point to the other huge hole in the Opposition's package. It has two huge holes.

PARA.TAB: When we have a look at the 700 pages of garbage the Opposition has produced, this so-called detail, we see that the success or failure of it depends fundamentally on two things: firstly, that the Opposition will actually make the public savings that it has said it is going to make—if it does not, it cannot give the tax cuts it has promised; and, secondly, that the inflation figures that it is projecting remain. It will fail on both counts.

Firstly, as we have pointed out and will continue to do so to the Opposition's discomfort next year, there is a huge hole in the savings. Take for one—and time limits me in this debate—the nonsensical proposals that it has put up, and I would be interested in Senator Reid's contribution to this debate, in shifting Commonwealth Government departments out of Canberra to the population-deprived centres of Sydney and Melbourne; God help us all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had AMSA here and it should have been in Newcastle.

—The Senate was previously engaged in a debate about the movement of a very small body, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. I refer Senator Tierney to Senator Reid's views on that subject. It did not make economic sense and that decision was reversed. But that is the reality of how much money is going to be saved by these people opposite. They will not save it.

PARA.TAB: The inflation rate will not remain at the 4 1/2 per cent, which the Opposition already concedes. And we need an increase in inflation of 4 1/2 per cent like a hole in the head, and we need a new tax like a hole in the head. New Zealand has proved that. That is our closest example. New Zealand is a GST country, and it is now in its fourth consecutive year of recession, which is the longest period of recession in any OECD country. This Opposition document is a deceitful document.

I will conclude, because of time restraints, by pointing out how much the Opposition knows about its own document. I refer to just two brief examples, and there are more every passing day. Senator Macdonald demonstrated in an earlier debate how much he knows about the Opposition package on the crucial question of electricity prices in northern Australia. Senator Macdonald well knows how crucial that question is to the cost of living in the north. That is why he chose to deal with that subject. Senator Macdonald claimed that the Opposition's tax package would reduce the cost of important items like refrigeration and air-conditioning for northern Australia because the current 30 per cent sales tax would be replaced by a 15 per cent Opposition tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order. The motion that we are debating is the need for Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self-imposed economic crisis and to urgently adopt the coalition's Fightback package.
—I know what we are debating. What is the point of order?

—My point of order is that not one word of Senator Collins's quite emotional, rabid contribution today has been directed to the leadership farce that is dividing this nation, that is dividing this Government, that is dividing Australia and is putting more and more people out of jobs every day.
—There is no point of order.

—As Senator Short knows only too well, because in his disgraceful attempt to burn up some time he read it out himself, the latter half of this motion calls on this Government to urgently adopt the coalition's visionary Fightback! document. I am explaining precisely why we will not do so: because it will be a disaster for this country if we do.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am addressing my remarks through you, Madam Acting Deputy President; I am ignoring the interjections.
—Order! Senators on my left will tone it down a little.

— The reason we will not do this is that the Opposition's public portrayal of its document has been riddled with absolute deceit. Senator Macdonald, as I said, has claimed that the Opposition is going to reduce the prices of important items like refrigeration and domestic air-conditioning because the 30 per cent sales tax that is currently imposed by this Government will be replaced by a 15 per cent retail tax. In fact, as Senator Macdonald has now conceded publicly on radio—today, I think, in northern Australia—he was wrong. The items he has mentioned have a 10 per cent wholesale sales tax on them, which the Opposition is going to remove and replace with a whopping 15 per cent retail tax, which is a tax not just on the wholesale price of the product but on the retail mark-up as well. That shows that the claim by the Opposition is totally deceitful. The prices of these important items for ordinary domestic consumers in northern Australia are going to increase, not decrease. But have a look at Dr Hewson's knowledge about the impact of his own proposals in respect of zone allowances in northern Australia. In conclusion I will quote—
—Why don't you debate this with Dr Hewson? He would make mince meat of you.

—I am glad that Dr Hewson's acolyte has, on his behalf, offered me that opportunity. In response to that interjection, I will be glad to debate with Dr Hewson or anyone else in the Opposition in northern Australia the impact of this tax on northern Australians. Any time he likes to name the date and the time, I will be there. I am glad Senator Tierney volunteered Dr Hewson on his behalf. Any time he likes.

PARA.TAB: This is what Dr Hewson says about zone allowances. The Opposition has promised to increase zone allowances by 25 per cent in northern Australia and has touted this as being a really big benefit to people in northern Australia. Let me tell them what it actually means for people in northern Australia. Residents in zone B, which is the most populous zone—that is, the zone in which most people get paid—currently are paid $45 a year in zone allowances, and that is going to increase under the Opposition to $56.25. That is an increase in taxation zone allowance of $11.25 per year. Well, hold the back page! In a transcript from ABC radio on Tuesday, regarding zone rebates, this is what

SPEECH.PARA: Dr John Hewson said about his own package in northern Australia:

Well I'm not sure on the number but a minimum 25% increase in Zone Rebates and we've also looked at Isolated Children's Allowances and you know Asset Tests on Isolated Children's Allowances and Boarding Allowances for Isolated Children and so on they've been increased quite significantly. Now you put all those things together I think that's very important that we recognise that we have been very conscious of the problem with Far North Queensland. On the $48-00—
it is not $48; it is $45—
I'm not sure what that number is but I'm talking about the Zone Rebates offered in the personal tax.

Announcer: Yes yes that's what I'm talking about it's $48-00 if you live in Zone A and it goes up to something like I'm not sure I think its about $450-00 if you live in Zone B which is really isolated. . .
John Hewson: I thought it was much bigger than $48-00.
Announcer: In Zone A no I live in Zone A and that's what I claim every year but
John Hewson: I'll have a look at that I'm happy to follow that through but what we've said is there will be a 25% increase in the Zone Rebates across the board.

Dr Hewson must have been well briefed, because this is a key subject in northern Australia and has been for years, but he indicated that he knows nothing about the current regime of zone allowances up there and was totally ignorant of the fact that this wonderful gift that the Opposition is giving us in northern Australia amounts for the majority of us to a total increase in zone rebates of $11.25 a year. The reality is that this deceitful document offers no hope to Australians at all.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has falsely claimed employment projections that are not related to its document. It has falsely claimed that it will make substantial savings in the Public Service, upon which depends its ability to give us taxation cuts. The Opposition will not make those savings. It has falsely declared that it will peg inflation at a one-off 4.5 per cent. The fact is that this country needs any increase in inflation like a hole in the head, and it needs a new tax like a hole in the head.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we need a new government, and that is why we have the motion before us this afternoon, as we stand here in the despair and the detritus of an absolutely failed and bankrupt administration. The Senate is debating the need for Labor to end the leadership farce which has left Australia without effective government at a time of self-imposed economic crisis and to urgently adopt the coalition's visionary Fightback program in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: It is a failed government; and failed governments are never pleasant sights. The penalties being borne by Australia are enormous. What is the Government's sense of responsibility? It puts in the Z grade debating team to defend its record—the leader of the Government, Senator Button; a tired never-was, Senator Bolkus; and Senator Collins. What a team to defend the Government!

Senator Button is the person who has a reputation for going into boardrooms of this country, into industry, and agreeing with everyone that things are bad, that things need to be done, that labour relations need to be improved, and that taxation measures need to be introduced. He has been agreeing with people in industry conscientiously, with crocodile tears running down his face—and coming out of boardrooms and not doing a thing for them. He got away with it for some years, but he has not got away with it for many years. This is precisely the same attitude Senator Button takes to his Leader. The man who stabbed Mr Hayden in the back—held the knife, ran it in—is doing the same thing now to the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. It is great to have people like that in responsible positions at the top of the Government.

As for Senator Bolkus, I do not think we need to spend much time on him. And as to Senator Collins, I would invite him to read the Fightback package. If we published it in braille, he might be able to read it; but it would stretch the imagination too much to imagine that Senator Collins would comprehend it. So we will leave the issue at that.

Zonal allowances are a very real thing in rural Australia, particularly in the northern parts. Senator Collins might recollect that this Government has been in office now for nearly nine years. It has never done one darn thing for zonal allowances, and never has an intention of doing so. We have this Government which is detested and distrusted completely by the Australian community. It is no longer seen as a capable government; it has not been seen as a capable government for many years. It is seen now as a totally irresponsible government in the literal sense where the leaders of the Government are squabbling like small children over the toys, which to them are the fruits of office.

We have a Prime Minister who does not now enjoy the support of his colleagues, and we have a pretender to the throne who is clearly no better placed at all. All the time Australia is swinging deeper and deeper into a major depression. There is real pain and hurt out there. If people such as Senator Collins took themselves out onto the footpaths of the cities of Australia—Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne—and went through the country towns, and talked to people, they would realise the pain and agony that is out in the community with the failed businesses, the huge rate of bankruptcies, the failed careers, the failed marriages, the failed families, and even the suicide levels that are tragically now so much part of the Australian scene; and they relate to the policies of Senator Collins—who is now slinking out—his Government and his colleagues in the Cabinet.

Internationally, we have a country which we can no longer be proud of with the business practices of the great mates of Hawke and Keating, and the rest of it, held in unbridled, unconcealed contempt in the business capitals of the world. The country is seen to be directionless. It is a mendicant country with a huge debt; it is absolutely helpless. This Government is seen to have squandered the immense resources of the country and frittered away the golden opportunities we had. What do we get? There is not a word of constructive inspiration out of these Ministers who sit on the leather on the other side. We just get squabbles over who will be the leader and who will be in the Ministry in the changed leadership. We have a government that is absolutely incapable of being able to learn from its mistakes or even to recognise that it has made mistakes.

The Government is blind to the fact that it is the custodian for the time being of the national interests of Australia. It is exhausted morally, intellectually and politically. We have a Ministry that is unable to govern. Look at Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence: he has been so busy this year trying to protect the Prime Minister that he has not devoted his not inconsiderable talents to his Ministry at all. He has left it all to that lightweight in the other place, his junior Minister who lacks the intellectual and professional background to understand the portfolio. The many policy decisions that Senator Ray should have taken have not been taken because he has been too busy looking after the back of the Prime Minister.

Senator Ray had a few cheap shots at the Liberal Party in Question Time today. I would like to take him down a little bit of an historical path also and reflect on the history of Labor governments. The history of Labor governments in Australia is a history of catastrophic failure—not peccadilloes anywhere along the line but major failures. Look at Whitlam who gave us the great inflation and unemployment of the post-Second World War era. Look at Chifley. There were four years after the Second World War of absolute misery, of price control and all the black market rackets that went with it. There was petrol rationing, and austerity, which is what it used to be called.

While the rest of the world was booming away in those years, 1946, 1947, 1948 and 1949, Australia was just wallowing in the misery of a Labor administration. Before that, in the 1930s, we had the marvellous Scullin Government which gave us the biggest depression this country had ever seen, with 30 per cent unemployment. The Labor Ministry now preens itself that unemployment is only 10 per cent, running up to 11 per cent. But the facts of life are that youth unemployment at present is near 30 per cent. In many parts of Melbourne and the industrial towns of Australia the unemployment level would be nudging what it was in the Great Depression. That is a history of Labor governments in Australia. At the end of the day, Labor can run an economy only when times are good, when there is money in the bank and when it can rob the larder and spend money recklessly.

Let us look at where we are in Australia today. The mood out on the streets and the footpaths has not come about in the last three or four months; it has been building for about three years. Over the past three years when I have talked to families in my own State, Queensland, who have been in business for four or five generations and who are financially secure and who have no overdraft or anything like that, they say that they simply do not see the point of staying in businesses that are profitable, albeit at a reduced level, because they just despair at the policies of this Government and the way those policies have been foisted on the Australian community.

The key words to describe the Australian community today are despair and disillusionment. The atmosphere is very different from the end of the catastrophic Whitlam regime in 1974-75. In those years there was a great deal of anti-Labor feeling in the Australian community but it was one of anger and fear because we had all those loony, unexplained, irrational changes being foisted on Australian society with great rapidity by the Cairns, the Connors, the Creans, the Khemlanis and all the other luminaries who flocked to Whitlam like moths to a bright light. The view then clearly was that it was the inmates who were running the lunatic asylum, and the public got rid of them. But now the view of the community is that the inmates are running the morgue and they want to bring back the undertaker. Why ever would the Labor Party want to bring back Mr Keating? He is the man who gave us the recession we had to have; the man with the lovely set of figures, as each month's balance of payments blew out further and further; the man who promised us we would have a soft landing.

The only person who got it right in the Government was Senator McKiernan when he went on television the other night and said that there were 900,700 reasons why Mr Keating should never come back. But the Keating campaign has been supported by two groups of people. The first is the press. For a reason I do not understand, the press of Australia adores Mr Keating. It has waged the vendetta, the character assassination, against Mr Hawke that has brought him down. In the fullness of time it will get its reward, I imagine. The other group includes Senator McMullan, Senator Schacht, Senator Richardson and Senator Loosley who are looking after their own interests. They recognise that when this Government fails—as it surely will at the next election—the interregnum before another Labor administration comes along stretches into infinity because Mr Hawke has carefully destroyed the whole of the ethos and the base of the Labor Party.

The reformation of the Labor Party will be an extraordinarily difficult and protracted business. This country is absolutely fed up with this Government. Today we had the Morgan polls released where a staggering 21 per cent lead is held by the Liberal-National parties. I cannot recall, since polling started in Australia, a margin as great as that. I believe the Labor Party now is in an absolutely terminal state. In Brisbane yesterday one of the large radio stations, 4BC, did a poll with this question, `Do you want a say in the Prime Minister's survival? If so, do you want an election to show them what you think?'. Of the people who phoned in to 4BC yesterday, 65 per cent wanted the Labor Party out of office because they wanted to end the leadership squabbles that are going on.

That is an accurate reflection of the Australian community at present. The Australian community is fed up with this bankrupt incompetent Administration which has cost us so much financially and in human terms in lost jobs, shattered families and shattered careers. That is why I have very much pleasure in supporting the motion before the Senate and calling on the Government to do the sole decent thing that needs to be done—that is, go to the polls and put itself before the judgment of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Parliament at its worst—when it gathers to talk about something important instead of doing something important. The sad situation is that people fail to distinguish between the two things. They think that because they have talked about an issue that is important they have actually done something important. There is a fundamental difference between the two. Nevertheless, the debate is now before us. I do not want to take much time. It was agreed that we would try to deal with this as a brief debate. I want to get on to legislation as soon as possible. But I do want to say a few things.

PARA.TAB: There is a whole range of good arguments for why the current leadership debate in the Labor Party ought be resolved as quickly as possible. One of them is a link that is made in a very convoluted way in Senator Hill's motion. I would like to get the leadership debate out of the way so that the debate about the Opposition's alternative economic manifesto, its election manifesto, can properly focus on that and not upon these diversions, which are very frustrating for the people of Australia, particularly for those of us in the Federal parliamentary Labor Party. I want to see more attention focused on that election manifesto.

I think the Australian people would be well served by increased publicity about a number of elements in the package—more than I can talk about today. One of them is the fundamental nature of the goods and services tax. One of the great misleading aspects of this package is the attempt to deny that the massive transfer from direct to indirect tax is regressive. There is no way in the world that we can argue that making a major shift in the tax mix in Australia from one that is fundamentally based on income and upon capacity to pay to one that is based on expenditure, regardless of capacity to pay, is other than unfair. The unfairness is exacerbated when the income tax changes reinforce and enhance it by giving the greatest compensation to those who are already better off. The percentage increases flow not to those on middle incomes but to those on $75,000 a year—the absolute amounts even more so. There is a great fraud in the tax area.

The greatest fraud of all is in the jobs area, where absolute lies are being told. People get up in this Parliament and say that the package will create two million jobs when they know that it does not purport to say that. There is an economic scenario in the package which Access Economics thinks would create two million jobs. I am not sure that it is right but, nevertheless, it is a legitimate scenario. It bears no relationship to the package which the Liberals have put down.

One of the interesting unanswered questions is: why was Access Economics not asked to assess the actual package that was put forward and its consequences? It may well be that the answer is that it was asked to assess it, it did model it and the Opposition did not like the results so it did not publicise them. There are three economic scenarios assessed in the package, but none of them are the scenarios put forward by the Opposition. The Opposition has not assessed that. It has consciously decided to assess three other options.

The biggest fraud is the jobs fraud. What Senator Button said absolutely correctly—Dr Hewson has acknowledged this, to his credit—is that the package will create unemployment. It will cost people jobs; it will not create jobs at all. To say otherwise is an absolute fraud and people have been lying in this place in saying that they believe it will. Another thing that is starting to come to light and that should come to light more were we not—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is unparliamentary to accuse parliamentarians of lying.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—I am not certain that you were directing your comments to anyone in particular, Senator McMullan, but I am sure if you were you will apologise accordingly and withdraw your remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not directing them to anyone in particular, unlike Senator Kemp, who has made such allegations about parliamentarians in the past. I accept that it would have been unparliamentary had I done so, but I did not. The other aspects of the program that is before us—
—Whom did you say were lying?
—I said that some people who came in and said that this program will create two million jobs were lying. I reiterate that.
—He said that they were lying, and I ask that it be withdrawn, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—The Acting Deputy President was explicit and correct, in my view, in saying that I was not relating it to specific senators, and I was not. Another aspect of the program that is starting to emerge, and that will emerge from the analysis that will flow when we get these diversions out of the way, is what is not covered. For example, there is no attempt to match the Government's commitment to remove pensioners from the tax system by 1995. There is no reference to that in this package at all. There is no allowance for any costs involved in that. I assume that means that under a Hewson-led government pensioners could look forward to paying tax on their pensions, which, under a Labor government, they will not have to do by 1995. As time goes on, we start to focus on the things that are not in the package as well as the misleading elements of the things that are there.

PARA.TAB: Different people are concerned most by different aspects of this package; that will create a debate that will take place in Australian society over the next 18 months. The matter that causes me most concern is the overall economic effects of the package. It strikes me as amazing that when looking around the world for a role model—on which economy the Opposition will choose to base the future vision it has of the Australian economy—the Opposition has chosen New Zealand. Of any economy in the world I could choose to base the future of the Australian economy on, I would not choose the New Zealand economy, which is in continuing recession. Several years after a package like the Opposition's program was introduced, there seems to be no end to that recession. It is continuing and all the predictions are that it will get worse. The Prime Minister of New Zealand, on the basis of the implementation of that package, has an approval rating of 8 per cent.

In New Zealand we have a little picture for Australians to look at. We say, `This is the Australia that is being offered to you by Dr Hewson. Do you want it or not?'. It is a program based upon industrial relations confrontation, on unfairness—both in the tax system and in the social welfare system—on forcing the economy into recession and on the creation of more unemployment.

There are many other aspects that I would like to refer to, but time will not permit. One of the key elements of this package—it has not yet had the coverage that it deserves; it does not get much coverage in the package—is the industrial relations element.
