That is a matter for another debate on another day. It is a very important and fundamental aspect that will make Australia less fair. Even the high road—the most optimistic road in the package—is based upon a reduction in real wages. All the scenarios assume a reduction in real wages. It is an administrative nightmare both for the Government and for small business and it will significantly increase the percentage of the resources in the economy being used in the administration of the tax system both in the public and the private sectors. We still have to see the full analysis of the consequences of the $3.9 billion hole that the Treasurer, Mr Willis, has put through this package on the expenditure and revenue sides.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of the tax administration is costed.

—There is an allowance there; whether it is sufficient is a very valid ground for argument. On the basis of the experience in other countries, it is probably not. The $3.9 billion hole is a clear indication of the macro-economic consequences of this package. The consequences are that we have a fiscal policy set in concrete five years in advance, whatever the economic circumstances, we have the abandonment of any wages policy whatsoever and we have a massive boost in prices that all the competent economists in Australia recognise can only lead to a massive credit squeeze and an increase in unemployment.

PARA.TAB: What we are having advocated to us here today is a prescription for industrial relations confrontation, for making Australia less fair as a society and for increased unemployment. That is why the motion should be rejected—not because it says we should resolve leadership problems in the Government, because, obviously, we should, but because it advocates a vision adopting the Fightback program which would take Australia back to the bad old days when it was riven by confrontation in industrial relations. It would make it a less fair society for our children to grow up in and it would increase unemployment in a way that is absolutely against the national interest, the interests of our children and the interests of the people we were elected to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In winding up this debate, I particularly thank Opposition speakers who have supported the motion. Even the contributions of Labor senators were interesting, in that there seemed to be a universal acceptance that Labor should end its leadership farce. There seemed to be a reasonable acceptance on the other side of the chamber that Australia is not being properly governed during this period, in which all the Labor Party's energies and concentration have been upon its internal leadership conflict rather than its responsibilities, particularly the enormous number of unemployed in this country.

PARA.TAB: There was some acceptance that the problems the country now has were, at least in part, as a result of poor government policy. There now seems to be almost a recognition of the importance on the part of the Government that it should debate the Opposition's alternative Fightback program and the detailed prescription that we have put down for a lift in incentive and, particularly, the creation of some two million jobs. If that is so, we are pleased to hear it, because debate is what we want. The package is on the table; it is there to be debated. An enormous amount of work has gone into it to produce a different direction for Australia, an alternative direction, which can produce jobs and give people better hope for the future than they are getting from Labor.

If that indicates a difference in attitude from what we have experienced in recent times, that is pleasing, because Mr Hawke, rather than being prepared to debate it, called for our program in order that he might blow it out of the water. When he failed to do that, the Keating sycophants called for the return of Mr Keating because he would be more effective in blowing it out of the water. The Opposition was not against the coalition at all; rather, it was a macho contest between the factions as to whose spokesman would be more effective in attacking the Opposition. That is not what the Australian people want.

Even Labor Party members do not see Mr Keating as offering anything more. They certainly do not claim his economic credentials as a reason for his leadership and they do not claim that he offers vision. They hardly could. They claim that he would be the most effective attack weapon against the Opposition. That is regrettable. Therefore, I hope that today's debate indicates a change of attitude and that they really do want to debate ideas and enter the battle of ideas for a change rather than simply trying to retain power through personal abuse.

The Australian people are sick of that. They are sick of self-serving leaders who think of nothing but their own personal glory; they are sick of the gutter approach to politics that has been perfected by Mr Keating; they are sick of the thuggery in politics that we see from the New South Wales Labor Right and all the business of show and tell ballots, threats to preselection or even more serious threats if one does not do as one is told; they are sick of deals whereby Ministers are determined not on ability but by the factional deal-doers; and they are sick of the special relationships between this Government and the rich and powerful, the union heavies and any vested interests which can better serve Labor's interests.

Australians want a return to principle in politics; they want leaders of vision; they want debate on ideas rather than personal abuse; they want some real leadership and they want it urgently. It is in that spirit that we put down this comprehensive package, our Fightback program, for debate. We welcome that debate and we are confident and sure that at the end of that debate the Australian people will see that the package offers them so much more than this Government has offered in the past and, in particular, what it can provide in a new direction is jobs, jobs and jobs. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented. In my absence from the Senate on 12 December, during Question Time Senator Collins answered a question from Senator Faulkner with regard to electricity charges in north Australia and related it to the Opposition's proposal for a goods and services tax. Senator Collins said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I have to say that Senator Tambling, on a radio debate with me this morning in the Northern Territory, had to concede it—that territorians will be paying somewhere between $70 and $100 a year more in Federal taxation on their domestic electricity accounts.
Senator Ray interjected:
Senator Tambling said this?
Senator Collins then went on:

Senator Tambling conceded this morning on ABC Radio that territorians will have to pay between $70 and $100 a year more in Federal taxes on the same amount of electricity that is used by consumers in New South Wales.

I contend that the statement by Senator Collins is patently incorrect. I will read from a transcript of the ABC radio program of 12 December. I have Senator Collins's endorsement to table the document later. In that interview I said:

What I think the most important thing to address in this, Clare, is we're talking about a total package and certainly the electricity is a component of it. But very importantly, the most important thing about why people can't pay their electricity bills is either they haven't got enough cash in their pockets, if they're an income earner, or they haven't got a job.
The reporter asked:
So you don't deny that indeed they will go up quite substantially?
I responded:

There will be adjustments of course to all services. But at the same time there will be very substantial personal income tax cuts, zone allowance rebates, family allowances go up, there'll be 7 business taxes taken out and of course very significant savings to the household budget in the area of freight costs and transport.
Further in the same interview, the reporter asked:
Do you reject the figures that Senator Collins just provided?
I responded:

We can get into a lot of detail on those very specifics, but when Senator Collins uses a figure like $70 on an electricity bill, what about the hundreds of dollars savings in an average petrol bill for the family, the thousands of dollars for tax savings and the tremendous advantages to business and to export industries that are going to create jobs and are going to put much more cash in every household's pocket? People that are on pensions are all going to be compensated very adequately for their overall cost of living.

I believe those quotations illustrate very dramatically that Senator Collins was incorrect in his contention in answer to the question. He agreed earlier today that it was appropriate for me to table the full transcript of that radio interview for the information of the Senate, and I seek leave to do so.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also refer to a statement by Senator Collins in answer to a question on 11 December on a similar issue in which he made the point, relating to my absence from this chamber, `He is only getting a nose job'. For the record I put it straight that the operation I was absent for, in medical terms, was a submucous resection and reduction of turbinates. It certainly was not a cosmetic nose job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a brief personal explanation as I also claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Collins. During the debate which has just concluded, Senator Collins basically said—I did not write down the exact words—that I had denied the coalition's Fightback proposals will create some two million jobs by the end of the decade.

PARA.TAB: I did not say that. I said that the three scenarios outlined in chapter 19 of the Fightback documents do not fully reflect the impact of the coalition's specific proposals. Contrary to Senator Collins's assertions, I point out that the document makes that quite clear. Indeed, page 333 of the Fightback! document states:

SPEECH.PARA: While a number of elements of the policy change underlying the "High Road" Scenario are similar to those embodied in the Coalition's social welfare policy package, the analysis does not purport to portray the outcomes which would be achieved by implementation of that package.

Indeed, since the extent and scope of reform contained in the Coalition's policy package is without precedent in post-war history, it is unlikely that models based on economic performance over that period would be able to capture accurately the outcomes which might be expected to flow from its implementation.

The Access Economics analysis summarised below must be seen primarily as providing a framework for the debate about medium-term solutions to our economic problems which must occur if we are to avoid a further decline in our living standards.
In relation to the analysis of these scenarios, page 345 of the document states:

Most important, faster economic growth—by 0.9 percentage points per annum—under the "High Road" scenario and the lower real unit wages costs outcome lead to the creation of over 2 million jobs. This is enough to produce a return to full employment by the end of the decade. Unemployment falls to 5.2 per cent by the year 1999-00.

Contrary to Senator Collins's assertion that I said that the Fightback! document would not lead to the creation of two million jobs, given that the scenario analysis contained in the Fightback! document is very conservative about the jobs that would be created under the proposals, it is quite clear from all the evidence and the economic modelling that is available that more than two million jobs will be created under the fightback proposal.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! During the earlier debate Senator Hill took a point of order that Senator McMullan claimed Opposition senators were lying. I should make the point that collective reflection is no mitigation. My understanding is that Senator McMullan was hypothesising about what honourable senators from the Opposition side may or may not have said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report before the Senate today is the first report of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The report shows that the work of the Authority is commendable and essential. The work undertaken by the AMSA ranges from the provision of navigational aids, to coordination of maritime research and rescue, to provision of a planning and response capability appropriate to the threat to maritime pollution from shipping in the Australian region, and to provision of a vessel registration service. These services are obviously necessary and I commend the Authority for the provision of them.

PARA.TAB: I find it absolutely astonishing—this has been stated in this place before—that the Authority is located inland, here in Canberra, hundreds of kilometres from the nearest drop of salt water. Surely, it would make more sense for the Authority to be located in a port city, a city such as Newcastle. How can this Authority properly and efficiently carry out its defined duties from a location in the Australian Capital Territory? This amazing situation has arisen due to the incompetence of the Labor Government, which has allowed the bureaucracy to run out of control and become self-serving, rather than serving the taxpayer.

This Authority was originally to be based in Newcastle. Newcastle is a major port city and, by being based in that city, the Authority would have had greater communication access to the industry that it proposes to serve. In fact, the proposal made so much sense that Labor's own Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the decision to locate AMSA in Newcastle was based on objective reasons. Newcastle was the best location . . .

Given that this was the situation, it is truly bewildering that the decision was reversed in one of the worst cases of a snow job by the Public Service over the Government that has occurred in recent years. The decision was reversed by a new and inexperienced Minister, who was hoodwinked by the people in his Department by a fudged cost blow-out—including a four-day visit to Newcastle by 211 staff and their families to ascertain whether they wanted to move to Newcastle—which convinced the Minister to leave the Authority in Canberra, a long way from any maritime links.

PARA.TAB: This left public servants happy in Canberra, wrapped in red tape without the perspective that would have been obtained by the Authority had it been located on the coast near the ports where communication and liaison with maritime sectors would have been more productive. This walkover of the Government by the public servants reads like something from an episode of Yes, Prime Minister. In an episode with remarkable parallels, Jim Hacker, PM, tries to relocate some of the armed forces to the north of England. It was made perfectly clear to the Prime Minister, however, that one simply could not ask senior officers to live permanently in the north.

The Government and the public servants have forgotten the Australian people and the needs of Australian industry because they are not out there where the activity in our society is occurring. The sorry result of this attitude by the Hawke Government is that areas of the country are denied the economic stimulus that is so desperately needed. This occurs while the bureaucracy in Canberra just keeps expanding with no real benefit to the nation's economy.

Newcastle's economy needed the extra impetus that the Authority would have brought, especially when it was the ideal location for the AMSA. However, the city was ignored yet again by the Hawke Labor Government in the tradition of the submarine, frigate and mine hunter contracts that were refused to Newcastle. This Authority, AMSA, is to be commended for the work it carries out. It provides essential and vital services that are of benefit to Australia. The sad thing is to think of just how much more could have been achieved had the Authority been located in a position where it was best suited: on the coast near the ports where the action of maritime industry is—at Newcastle, as was originally planned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to speak to the annual report of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Like Senator Tierney, I also compliment the Authority on its excellent work. We have heard Senator Collins many times in this chamber relaying to us the new technology being used by the Authority. I would particularly like the Senate to take note of the activity report of the Authority where it says that it is responsible for planning and coordinating search and rescue in an area covering some 20 million square nautical kilometres, about one-ninth of the world's surface.

PARA.TAB: When we realise the facilities that we have and our small population, we must conclude that this Authority does a first-class job. It is noted in the report that the Authority was involved in 1,321 incidents. Of those, 25 were major incidents. In fact, 43 lives were saved at a cost of about $920,000.

I wanted to comment on this report today because it does have some relevance to my own State of Tasmania where, I suspect, we have an above average number of accidents and maritime problems. There has been a high loss of life in events such as the Sydney to Hobart yacht race, for instance. Many fishing boats have been lost because of the violent weather from time to time on the west coast of Tasmania.

I wish to make some comments on that particular area today. I was going to ask a question of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) but, unfortunately, it seemed impossible to do so today and I doubt very much whether I will get an opportunity to raise this matter tomorrow. However, there is a lot of concern in Tasmania, particularly about the proposal to abandon the high frequency receivers that are placed on Bruny Island and which relay signals to Melbourne radio. They will cease operation at the end of January 1992. We are in a new generation of satellite communication, and Senator Collins has said many times how efficient the EPIRB detection system is; but I point out that the report notes:

SPEECH.PARA: A total of 308 detections were received during the reporting period. Of these 227 were of undetermined origin, 65 were non-distress and 16 were real distress. . .

So of 308 detections there were 16 real distress signals. I know that the EPIRB system has caused some problems in America. In fact, there are so many false alarms that the safety authorities do not actually act on the first call on the EPIRB system. Although we have all this new technology and the proposal to shut down some of the smaller HF systems in Tasmania, I believe this will lead to a diminished service which will jeopardise the safety of a lot of fishermen and private boat owners in Tasmania. I have been made aware of that by people who are involved in search and rescue operations in Tasmania. I know that the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry, the Hon. David Llewellyn, has had quite a few meetings with the Minister here and has voiced his concern about that.

PARA.TAB: He has pointed out, as has been pointed out to me, that with the receptive capability of Melbourne radio at this time, and even with the new HF system, we will not be able to provide the service that should be provided in Tasmania. In fact, distress calls on channels 2 and 4 will be disbanded, and it will be impossible for a 24-hour service to pick up distress calls, particularly from the west coast. We know, as Senator Tate would know very well, that this is of concern in Tasmania. People are talking about going to higher frequencies, 6, 8 and 12, but at the moment it is often impossible for even the HF signal 6 to be received on the west coast. So, whilst the Australian Maritime Safety Authority has done a great job, I believe it should look again at what it is doing in Tasmania. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Australian Honey Board on its annual report and on the work that it does in trying to maximise the returns to Australian honey producers from the export of honey by generating a greater demand for Australian honey both here and overseas. I note from the report that it has not been a good year for the production of honey in Australia, just as it has not been a very good year for any rural industry. Page 6 of the report notes:

PARA.TAB: Following a fall in production of honey of 1.7 per cent for the 12 months ended 30 June 1989, production fell a further 6.3 per cent in the 1989-90 financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: This fall in production obviously has a significant impact on prices. The report also states that the decline in production was most significant in New South Wales and Queensland, whereas other States such as Victoria recorded an increase in production on the previous year. Total recorded production of honey for the 12 months ended 30 June 1990 was 21,198 tonnes. This figure is based on all returns received by the Australian Bureau of Statistics irrespective of the number of hives kept. Owing to the diversified origins of honey, actual commercial production is estimated to exceed that figure by up to 5,000 tonnes. Consequently, the Board's estimate of production for 1989-90 is approximately 26,000 tonnes. Exports of honey for the year under review totalled 11,328 tonnes.

PARA.TAB: The domestic scene in the honey industry is becoming quite exciting. The range of honeys on the Australian market is staggering. Created exclusively from a combination of bees, flowers and sunshine, honey is one of the few truly natural foods remaining. Australia's long hours of sunshine and its great selection of native trees and ground flora have given us a marvellous selection of unique floral honey varieties. However, because the beekeeping industry is relatively small in size and number, it is often ignored by the Government. It is not a large industry and it does not have a lot of money. We therefore have to be ever vigilant in keeping an eye on the industry, to ensure that the beekeepers stay in business and look after the agricultural crops for which we need them so desperately. At home we grow kiwi fruit, and if we do not get hives of bees from the honey producers in our district and put them in amongst the kiwi fruit vines, we can be quite sure that we will not get any kiwi fruit at all.

A healthy beekeeping industry is absolutely essential, but it is very much tied to circumstances out of its control. It is vital, therefore, under the adverse conditions that rural Australia is now experiencing that we do all we can to maintain the strength of the industry by watching the effect of economic factors and of the importation not only of honey produce but also of diseases. I note that during the previous year the Board expressed its concern about imports of honey from countries where the chalk brood disease is endemic. This disease is of some concern to beekeepers and it is regarded as a serious exotic disease by the Australian beekeeping industry. However, the Government has continued to stonewall, claiming that internationally chalk brood is not regarded as a major infectious disease of honey bees. Of course it is not, and the Government knows it is not. However, nearly every other country in the world has the disease. Australia does not have it, though, and our beekeepers do not want it. It is a quite nasty disease and it affects the effectiveness and profitability of beekeeping.

I am pleased to see, as detailed on page 3 of the report, that this year the Government finally came to acknowledge what a number of my colleagues and those in the beekeeping industry have been telling it. Imports of honey from countries affected by chalk brood are now subject to effective treatment protocols. This includes imports from New Zealand.

As we know, there has been a dramatic turnaround in the fortunes of all those associated with the Australian rural sector. It does not matter whether we produce the goods, factors outside the farm, such as disastrous government decisions on rural issues, in addition to its economic policies, mean that being on the land is just not profitable. In order to lower the difference in costs between Australia and its competitors we should look at the imposts placed on the small rural business and farming families by bureaucracy, big business and pure economic theory. Australia has a golden opportunity to become the world's greatest agricultural exporter with its pollution free food. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the second full year in which the current Soil Conservation Advisory Committee has operated. It refers to the fact that it has been a very busy year. Obviously, if we are to be successful in looking after our soils, future years will become even busier for the Committee. I want to make special mention of some of the members of the Committee. Mr Bob Junor has been the Commissioner of the Soil Conservation Service in my home State of New South Wales. I believe that he has been an outstanding Commissioner for the New South Wales Soil Conservation Service, which now comes under the Conservation and Land Management—CALM—Department. Mr Michael Tooth, a former President of the New South Wales Farmers Association, is also on the Committee. He lives in New England, and he has done an excellent job on this Committee.

PARA.TAB: The report tells us that in my home State of New South Wales the growth of Landcare has been most impressive. In fact, New South Wales has had the most rapid increase of any State in the number of groups involved in Landcare. All the farming communities of New South Wales can take their hats off. I am very proud that they have led the way in land care. Looking after our soils is most important.

One of the other points brought out in the report was the concern expressed within the farming communities that increases in the national soil conservation program budget allocation were being used to fund an expanded bureaucracy rather than significantly increasing on the ground soil conservation activity. That matter is something I have raised in this chamber at other times. If we are going to have bodies looking after the soil, or any other part of our environment, the money has to be spent at the coalface—that is, right at the ground where it counts—and not in expanding the bureaucracy, which eats away at the money allocated.
The report also mentioned the rural downturn, which Senator Bjelke-Petersen also alluded to in her remarks. The report mentions:

SPEECH.PARA: The way in which the landcare movement responds to low wheat and wool prices in a period of high interest rates and rising input costs. . .
It says that low wheat and wool prices in a period of high interest rates and rising input costs were:
. . . the basic ingredients of the current rural downturn.

Of course, that is what we have all been talking about in this place. We have been trying to make the Government understand that it is those high interest rates and the rising input costs which have caused such great problems to the rural community. However, on top of that, we have also had the drought this year, which has had a big impact for the future of looking after our soil. Drought puts greater pressure on those on the land because it causes financial problems as well as affecting the soil.

PARA.TAB: The report mentions that the number of Landcare groups in Australia continues to grow at a faster pace than the capacity of State government land conservation agencies to fully service their needs. This is an area that has to be looked at in the future.

In conclusion, in New South Wales we have 12 State Landcare group support officers, 70 officers in technical project support for State soil conservation activities, 12 officers in Landcare groups and 19 officers in education and training positions and administrative positions. That makes a total of 113 officers for New South Wales out of a total of 407 around Australia. Obviously, the growth of Landcare groups has increased at a greater rate in New South Wales than in any other State. I feel proud of the way the challenge has been taken up to look after land, a precious resource; this chamber should feel proud of the people of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin my remarks about the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee 1990-91 annual report by congratulating Gary and Jan English, from the Esperance district in Western Australia, who won the primary producer category of the awards in the Landcare program. They come from the soil conservation district in which I farm. They are very worthy of the award because they have set an example in practical management and control not only in Western Australia but in Australia as a whole.

PARA.TAB: The other group I would like to congratulate for its practical work is the Jerramungup land conservation district committee, which I understand was the third land conservation district committee established in Australia. I would particularly like to congratulate its president, Rex Edmondson, who has been one of the driving forces behind the soil conservation program for Australia in general and Western Australia in particular. That district happens to be alongside the Esperance district.

Depending on where one comes from, I know there are claims and counter-claims about the soil conservation program, but it was in my State of Australia that the first real effort was made in soil conservation. This related particularly to the impact of wind erosion, which is a problem in much of Western Australia. It is worth noting that in WA there are now 142 land conservation districts and 70 catchment groups; the pastoral areas have also been covered. Practically the whole State is now covered by soil conservation and land management groups. The number of groups has increased from 109 last year.

I have raised before in this chamber what I see as duplication between the national soil conservation program and the Landcare Australia Ltd program. Unfortunately, I did not get to speak on the annual report of Landcare Australia Ltd when it was tabled the other day, but I do question, as Senator Brownhill did in his speech, the necessity of having these two groups operating side by side. During the Estimates committee hearings I heard the reasons given for this duplication—one group being involved more in commercial activities than the other one—but it seems to me that, having two programs, both with bureaucracies behind them, there should be some way of combining the operations of the two groups. It is also worth noting that the Landcare report generally seems to be about 12 months behind in its summary of events, but unfortunately I do not have the time to go into that in any detail today.

In Western Australia this year, assistance was given to some 80 projects in the land care program. One important aspect, which I raised last year, is that we now have a Decade of Landcare coordinator which has been jointly funded by the national soil conservation program and the State Government. I congratulate them both for putting those funds together, because it means that there can now be overall coordination of the program.

I want to raise another point in the time remaining. I refer to the current proposals in Western Australia to change the role of the division of resource management and have it incorporated under the auspices of some of the operations of the Department of Agriculture in Western Australia. The existing situation is that while the division of resource management is within the auspices of the Department of Agriculture it is in fact independent within it. As such, the division has a much narrower focus, which has largely been brought about by Graham Robinson, who is the Commissioner for Soil Conservation. I congratulate him on the way he has put the whole operation together since 1982 and focused the attention of pastoralists and farmers in Western Australia on the importance of protecting our most important resource—the soil.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Working of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Cultural Heritage Committee is an important organisation because it is the body that recommends to the Government whether items of significance to Australia's history should be allowed to be exported. There has been a volume of applications—32 in the last 12 months—for permits to export what are classified as moveable cultural heritage. Nine of those applications were for permanent removal and 23 were for temporary removal. There were no refusals of any applications, although six applications were withdrawn but only because they were unnecessary as the items were not within the ambit of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act.

PARA.TAB: I am not in a position to say whether it is appropriate that all applications were approved, but it is significant to go through the list and to recognise the items that have been allowed for permanent export. There was a Marc Chagall painting, `Little Red House'; an oil painting, `Au Docteur Forest-Dep Paye & Soit Reconnaissant' without a painter's name on it; a Rover 12-horsepower 1912 motor car; a Vinot and Deguingand 12-horsepower Special Torpedo motor car; two ships, which were coal-fired bulk carriers; two African Congo fetish objects—rather curious; and a group of military orders and medals. It is important to have such an organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Male and female.
—I thought it was left and right.
—Senator MacGibbon may be interested to know that an application has been made to this organisation to stop the export of one of the few Lancaster bombers still—
—Which the Government turned down.

—As Senator MacGibbon has said, the Government has turned it down even though this is one of the few Lancasters extant. The view was, when refusing to block the export, that it bore no special link with Australia, even though many Australians did, in fact, fly such bombers during the Second World War.
—And about 6,000 Australians were killed.
—As Senator MacGibbon says, about 6,000 Australians were killed in those ventures. I have no capacity to judge whether the decisions made were right or wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 17 of 1991-92, entitled Aggregate Financial Statement prepared by the Minister for Finance for the year ended 30 June 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak very briefly to the Auditor-General's Report No. 17 entitled Aggregate Financial Statement prepared by the Minister for Finance year ended 30 June 1991. I wish to express to the Auditor-General the appreciation of the Senate, and particularly the Opposition members of the Senate, for the outstanding job that the Auditor-General has been undertaking in pointing out to the Parliament those matters which merit close attention and those matters where the standards of accounting by government agencies and departments have not been adequate. Unfortunately, there are many instances where improvements are capable of being made. The Auditor-General has been fearless in his statements. At present, with the new roads legislation the Government will clearly have to do something—as was evident from the response at Question Time—to accommodate the concerns that the Auditor-General has quite properly raised.

PARA.TAB: In this report he makes a few remarks which summarise some of the problems that he has detected in the financial statements of a number of departments over the year. These refer to breaches of legislation, non-compliance with the financial statements guidelines for departmental secretaries and other matters. The significant matters he refers to include:

SPEECH.PARA: .Parliamentary Reporting Staff—Receipts to the value of $207 315.88 were accepted, and payments to the value of $14 459 142.81 were certified and approved, by officers acting in positions without delegation under. . . the Audit Act 1901.
.Parliamentary Library—A breach of section 83 of the Constitution involving expenditure of $222 532.90 in excess of appropriation.

.Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories—Exceeded appropriation for the National Film and Sound Archive by $105 831 on 22 October 1990 and $134 639 on 3 December 1990 in breach of section 83 of the Constitution.

.National Capital Planning Authority—A material proportion of expenditure was not evidenced as having been approved by an officer delegated by the Minister to approve expenditure with his power under section 64 of the Constitution.

.Department of Employment, Education and Training—Recipients of payments and benefits may not have been entitled to them in accordance with program legislation or established criteria especially in cases in which payment is dependent on voluntary compliance. Receipts totalling $11 970 407 were not processed by the Department's accounting systems before 30 June 1991. The department was unable to locate sufficient documentary evidence to support the expenditure relating to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989.

.Department of Finance—bank fees and interest charges have been netted out against interest received. Consequently, failure to pay receipts of $11.22m into the CRF was in breach of section 81 and payment of $11.22m without appropriation was in breach of section 83 of the Constitution. Separate records in respect of Commonwealth superannuation scheme contributions could not be maintained leading to breaches of the Audit Act 1901.
The Parliament thanks the Auditor-General for drawing those matters to its attention.

PARA.TAB: Quite late in the report, on page 37, the Auditor-General points out a matter which is of real significance to this chamber, that is, the extent to which the Commonwealth guarantees the borrowings of government instrumentalities. We have had a disagreement in this place with the Government over whether government instrumentalities which do not receive an appropriation can properly be questioned in Senate Estimates committees. Government Ministers have claimed that unless an appropriation is made, there is no basis on which those organisations can be queried in Senate Estimates about their expenditures.

That is demonstrated to be self-evident nonsense in this Auditor-General's report. He points out, for example, that there were borrowings by the Australian Industry Development Corporation at 30 June 1991 which were subject to a Commonwealth guarantee totalling $2.8 billion—that is, $2,780m.

That is a guarantee by the Commonwealth. To suggest that this Parliament does not have the right to cross-examine people from government instrumentalities where such guarantees exist, simply because there is no Commonwealth appropriation, is a clear distortion of reality and a clear breach, in my view, of the requirements of this Parliament. Those sorts of enormous guarantees—as I said, almost $2.8 billion—clearly merit the existence of a capacity by the Parliament to cross-examine government instrumentalities. With respect to Austrade, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth guarantees the due payment by AUSTRADE of money that is, or may at any time become, payable by AUSTRADE to any person other than the Commonwealth. The contingent liability under contracts of insurance, guarantees and loans, including contracts on the Australian Government's account, totalled $5,787 million.

There is no doubt that the Auditor-General has, in that little exercise, demonstrated the proprietary of our claims that all government instrumentalities, particularly those where there are guarantees in place relating to borrowings which are guaranteed by government, should be properly available for thorough examination in Senate Estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by once again thanking the Auditor-General for his outstanding contribution to the workings of this Parliament over the year and for his assistance in ensuring that there is adequate scrutiny of the financial accounts of this Government and its instrumentalities. We on the Opposition side resist with great vigour any attempts to diminish the Auditor-General's right to audit the books of government instrumentalities. I hope that the Government will deal with this matter effectively in its roads legislation, which is soon to come before the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senaor Cooney, I present a background paper, entitled A Survey of Reforms to the English Legal Profession, prepared for the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs as part of its inquiry into the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have a short statement, which I know will be of interest to Senator Tate, incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper I have just tabled has been prepared by a consultant to the Committee, Dr Stephen Parker. Dr Parker is a Senior Lecturer at the Faculty of Law of the Australian National University and practised as a solicitor in the United Kingdom before moving to Australia. For three years he has taught a course which examines the nature of legal practice in Australia and the ethical rules which govern it.

Since June 1991, Dr Parker has been a Visiting Fellow at the Centre for Socio-Legal Studies, Wolfson College, Oxford. He is thus admirably qualified to write this paper, not only because of his academic qualifications, but also because his stay at Oxford has allowed him ready access to the source material necessary for its preparation.
The Committee thanks Dr Parker for his work, and notes that a further paper which he has prepared for the Committee, entitled `Legal Ethics', will be tabled in the near future.

The Committee considers that it is important for it to examine the recent developments that have occurred in the United Kingdom concerning the regulation of the legal profession. Dr Parker's paper outlines the changes that have taken place in the United Kingdom in the last fifteen years which have culminated in the passage of the Courts and Legal Services Act 1990, as well as the further changes that are yet to occur.

I would like to emphasise that by examining these recent changes in the United Kingdom the Committee is in no way foreshadowing the recommendations that it will make in its final report. The Committee simply considers that it should inform itself not only of Australian developments in the provision of legal resources, but also of methods being used overseas to attempt to ensure that justice is accessible to all.

The Committee would welcome submissions concerning, for example, whether or not it would be appropriate, or feasible, for aspects of the new regulatory framework for legal services in the United Kingdom to be implemented in Australia. It appreciates that there are significant differences between the legal systems of the two countries, but hopes that the release of this background paper will further the current debate concerning the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia today.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1991INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1991INCOME TAX (DEFERRED INTEREST SECURITIES) (TAX FILE NUMBER WITHHOLDING TAX) BILL 1991TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the third time I will speak on the second reading of this package of Bills—and I anticipate that this speech will be briefer than the last two. I had reached the stage when speaking before of talking about the effect of the fringe benefits tax on rural Australia. I was pointing out that the effects were quite severe and were not appreciated. Many rural enterprises in Australia today simply cannot bear the added impost of a fringe benefits tax on staff who work on a property. Quite simply, that means that employment opportunities for people in the country are reduced. Also, there is a diminution, to some degree, in the productivity of the property.

PARA.TAB: In my lifetime there have been very great changes with respect to rural enterprises in Australia. Once upon a time—say, 30 years ago—there would be quite a community around the homestead of an average sized cattle or sheep property. There would have been the owner and his family; at least two married couples doing work around the place, living in accommodation on the property; and perhaps two or three station hands. It was quite a community. That situation has been run down very severely, principally through the application of union rules, rates of pay, overtime and all of the things which were never taken much notice of in country areas.

Before someone on the other side of the Senate jumps to his feet to talk about the exploitation of the human race, having been involved in this sort of life over quite a long time I have no hesitation in saying that there are a number of people in the Australian community who like to live on a property and in a rural environment. They find it both very satisfying and very rewarding to work as members of a group of people running a property.

TALK.START.PARA: —They worked together.

—As Senator Brownhill has said, they worked together. I suppose the Labor Party would say that it was a patriarchal or a patronising system. I do not think it was. I think people sweated together to achieve a common goal. In some cases a degree of exploitation was exerted but they were very much in the minority; they were very minor events. Basically, these communities operated quite happily.

PARA.TAB: It is true that some of the accommodation on the properties was not five-star—but neither was the main homestead. Most of those places were pretty spartan 20 or 30 years ago. The difference in accommodation between the main homestead and the quarters, or the houses on the property, was only minor. But that has all changed.

The imposition of the fringe benefits tax had a marked effect on the number of people employed on properties, reduced though it might have been. It meant that everything that the property owner provided became liable to be taxed. This included the accommodation which was provided and a number of other things which were shared, such as the telephone, electricity and portable gas for heating or cooking. It was always normal practice to share a beast killed on a property with whoever was living on the property. That now attracts fringe benefits tax.

The imposition of this tax is really quite pointless. It has led to a loss of employment opportunities in country areas of Australia and that has not helped our rural industries at all. As I said earlier, the rural industries were the second largest export earning bloc in this country. To get ourselves out of the huge debt that the Labor Party has left us, we will certainly have to maximise our export capabilities. During Question Time today the failed Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) gave a fatuous answer when he spoke about how he was changing Australia into an export economy. I can tell the Senate that he is not doing much for the rural areas.

In conclusion, I wish briefly to touch on two points. First, inserted into this Fringe Benefits Tax Act is a series of provisions requiring FBT to be paid on the cash component of the living away from home allowance where it is applied to offshore oil and gas workers. This bad precedent was challenged in the Attwood Oceanic case and the judge threw it out. The Treasury has now amended the Act to make the cash component of the living away from home allowances subject to FBT.

The Opposition fears that this provision will not be quarantined and restricted to that point. We do not even agree with its being put on at that point. We do not think that that satisfies the reasons for which a living away from home allowance was awarded in the first place. There is the risk that it will spread through other areas of employment in Australia where a living away from home allowance is paid. Of course, there are a very large number of those.

In my own State of Queensland, some of the shires have been hit and have been protesting when they have to pay camp allowances for their shire workers. In rural shires it is not uncommon to pay a camp allowance to people who live on the job when they are building a road or a bridge somewhere remote from the centre of the shire where they have their principal place of residence. To now impose on the shires, semi-governmental authorities as they are, the requirement to pay fringe benefits tax is simply increasing the costs of operation in the community. At the end of the day that cost filters through to the ordinary taxpayer, who has to pay for this nonsense. I find it absurd that government enterprises should pay fringe benefits tax, but then I also find the whole concept of the fringe benefits tax absurd and quite unjust, as I have said on every occasion that I have spoken on it, starting from 29 May 1986 when the legislation was introduced into the Senate. My final duty, at the request of Senator Short, is to move an amendment to Senator Short's amendment to the second reading motion on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. I move:
At end of words proposed to be added, add:

SPEECH.PARA: "and the Senate expresses concern at the indication that the Government, in a panic move to attempt to shore up the Prime Minister's crumbling leadership, is about to further destabilise and damage the economy by yielding to pressure from its Left wing to introduce pump priming unfunded changes to its 1991 Budget".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to the amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon on behalf of the Opposition. At this time, it is very appropriate to move this amendment, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "and the Senate expresses concern at the indication that the Government, in a panic move to attempt to shore up the Prime Minister's crumbling leadership, is about to further destabilise and damage the economy by yielding to pressure from its Left wing to introduce pump priming unfunded changes to its 1991 Budget".

It is particularly appropriate that this amendment was moved just a few minutes before the commencement of the event that some Australian Labor Party politicians today have dubbed as the event that will prove to be `the last supper' for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), namely, the Caucus dinner at the Lodge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Keating going?

—Senator Teague asks a very good question. I would like to be a fly on the wall tonight to see who is there and who is not there. I have no doubt that it will be a very interesting event. However, this matter is much more serious than that. This Government has engendered unprecedented confusion over its economic policy stance and the state of the economy.

PARA.TAB: Only last week the new Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Government representatives here, notably Senator Evans as Acting Leader of the Government, were telling us that signs of economic recovery were under way and there was no need to change course in the Government's policy direction. Three or four days later, just two days ago, the Treasurer held a press conference, which was ostensibly another opportunity to attack the Opposition's Fightback proposals—the Treasurer's second attack in a week—at which he laid nary a feather, let alone a glove, on the Opposition's proposals in Fightback!. Indeed, I wonder whether the Government is ever going to get into the ring on this Fightback proposal attack.

It was only two days ago that the Treasurer said that the Government's Budget forecasts may not be met to a certain important degree, and that there is to be a major review of the Budget forecasts and Budget parameters. The Treasurer appeared to signal that there could be a change in direction of Government economic policy in the new year. There is unprecedented confusion which is causing enormous destabilisation in the financial markets, in the investment world and in the productive sectors of the economy, particularly in manufacturing and the service industries where investment decisions will have to be made very shortly if we are going even to start to climb out of the deepest recession—the Government imposed recession—that we have had for 60 years.

We have had three Treasurers in the past seven months. The way things are going, it is very likely that we will have a fourth Treasurer within the next few days or weeks. All this comes at a time when we have seen the greatest of deterioration in a Commonwealth government's budgetary position, and where, in the past two years alone, we have seen an unravelling and a deterioration in the Budget situation of no less than $13 billion, even on published figures. When appropriate adjustments are made to those figures so that one is comparing like with like, the deterioration is more likely to be $16 billion to $17 billion. It is no wonder that the financial markets have been unsettled. It is no wonder that we have seen a series of records chalked up by this Hawke Government. Some of those records are worth putting on the Senate record.

We have now had the highest level of unemployment since the Depression. If we add to the number of officially unemployed people those who are unable to find the volume of work that they would like—those who are not shown as unemployed because they are working for one or two hours a week, the underemployed—we have a situation in Australia today where about 15 per cent of the work force is unemployed or underemployed. Even on the recorded statistics, one out of every three young persons in this country is unable to find a job. So that is one record of the Hawke Government that is indelibly imprinted on the minds of every Australian and every Australian family. We have seen a record loss of jobs in any 12-month period since the Depression.

Over the last couple of years we have seen record real interest rates, surpassing anything we have seen in our history. There has been a record low in corporate sector net profitability since the collection of these figures commenced more than a quarter of a century ago. I interpose to say that yesterday, in an extraordinary comment, the Treasurer said that the current relatively high level of corporate profitability was going into rebuilding balance sheets rather than investment.

It is quite clear that the Treasurer has not even read his own Government's Budget Papers for 1991. If he had read page 2.24 in Budget Paper No. 1, he would have seen a graph showing that gross operating surplus—at least that is a term that the current Treasurer understands; the previous Treasurer did not even know what it meant—net of tax and interest payments is the lowest that it has been since collection of that data commenced. Indeed, it has declined progressively in every year that this Government has been in office, with the exception of the first year. So much for the Treasurer's quite spurious statement yesterday about corporate profitability!

As a result of this Government, we have seen a record number of quarters of falling investment and negative economic growth since the Depression of the 1930s. The Prime Minister has today created a new record, namely, a record low in his approval rating as measured in the Morgan poll.

As I said, we had an indication of another policy rethink earlier this week during what was meant to be a press conference by the new Treasurer on the Fightback proposals of the coalition. If that goes ahead, we could be facing our fourth review of the Australian economy in less than 12 months. A so-called major review culminated in the industry statement of March 1991; three months later we had the Budget; and three months after that in November we had the so-called employment statement by the Prime Minister. With the exception of the Budget, each of the four statements—there are potentially four—have been totally politically motivated. In each instance the motivation has been the need to shore up the Prime Minister's leadership.

The March 1991 industry statement was all set to be a statement on industry policy. It was going to be made by the appropriate Minister—namely, Senator Button—but the Prime Minister got a fright and gained advice that his leadership was slipping. So he grabbed the ball, ran with that industry statement and turned it into more than an industry statement. It turned out to be a completely inadequate and totally politically motivated statement as to the state of the economy.

The mickey mouse employment statement of November 1991, last month, was delivered again only because the Prime Minister's supporters told him he had to do something to thwart Mr Keating's destabilisation campaign against his, the Prime Minister's, leadership. That statement went down like a lead balloon. As a result, the confusion generated in the economy by the Government's approach to economic policy making simply compounded what was already a very confused situation.

We now seem to be facing another thwarted Keating thrust, but I believe that this one is more serious and dangerous. That is why I wanted to speak on it briefly today. It looks as though this next policy rethink will be a policy U-turn that will out-Keating Keating. As we all know, Mr Keating has been wooing the Left very hard in a desperate attempt to win Caucus votes on the leadership. The Left want a much more expansionist and interventionist policy thrust by the Government—the old fashioned pump priming approach so beloved by generations of socialists and so-called social Democrats that has been rejected by virtually every other developed nation in the world. I had thought and hoped that it was an approach that had been largely rejected by even the Australian Labor Party.

As a result of the current political machinations involving the job not of the million and a half people who are unemployed and underemployed in Australia but of one person—the Prime Minister—it appears that we will run the risk of seeing a major and very damaging and dangerous U-turn in economic policy. It is dangerous for a variety of reasons. At the moment, the combined Commonwealth and State governments throughout Australia are in a total deficit position this year of something like $12 billion. They are drawing on national savings to the tune of about $12 billion net. Of that, the Commonwealth's contribution accounts for a little more than 50 per cent. So at a time when governments should be contributing to national savings they are drawing on them.

If the Government is to have in its policy rethink an interventionist and, more importantly, an expansionist economic policy which will add to the already very large public sector deficit this financial year, that can have only one consequence, which is, as I say, drawing on the national savings and competing for funds with the private sector and, therefore, forcing up interest rates. If the increased deficit is financed by government borrowings, that would be the impact.

Two other things could happen. One is that the Government could meet the increased expenditure of a pump priming nature by increased taxation. That is what State governments have been doing around the nation by and large this year in an attempt to shore up their deteriorating economic budgetary positions. So we face the prospect of increased taxation if we were to have a policy review leading to an expansionist, pump priming approach early next year.

The alternative and third option is to do what wrecked this country back in the 1970s under the Whitlam Government, which is to turn to the printing presses and have more money printed via the Reserve Bank. A reversion to the printing presses, as the Whitlam Government did, would re-create the structural damage done to this economy in those days, from which I believe we have never fully recovered.

A very serious issue is at hand in the statements by Treasurer Willis in recent days that the Government may well be doing a policy rethink. I was very alarmed today to hear Senator Button say, in response to my question about whether any changes would be funded if there were a mini-Budget next year, that he was not prepared to give that guarantee in any shape or form. That is a very dangerous portent for the future.

There is only one way to get this country out of the dreadful mess we are in. We will not solve it by going back to the old days of socialist pump priming; we will do it by picking the country up, giving it a shake and saying to all that we have to tackle the whole matter in a different way. We have to make ourselves more productive, competitive and lean. We have to have more independence and reliance on ourselves as individuals, firms and families and rely less on the welfare mentality that has been built up in our country over many years.

That is what the coalition's Fightback proposals are all about and why they are so fundamentally important to everything that happens in this country over the next decade. If the approach outlined in the coalition's Fightback proposals is not adopted, we will face more intractable problems which will become increasingly much more difficult to tackle. The matter is vitally urgent. If we were now to see a government stepping back even further from its current position, the problems would be tremendous. I hope very much that that will not be the case.

We do not mind the Government picking up some of the Fightback proposals and running with them. It has adopted two proposals already: the abolition of the coal export levy that we have put forward and some measures in relation to isolated children. They are both very good measures. We applaud the Government's decision to follow us. I hope that it will follow us further down that route, because if it does not, as I said, the problems will be compounded. Christmas should be a time of joy, happiness and beneficial reward to people. To have the amount of human misery that is facing this nation and every person and family at this time of the festive season is, in my view, an absolute disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support fully all that Senator Short has said and all that is in the amendment that the Opposition has wisely brought to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991 and allied Bills because it is about time that the Labor Government was brought to its senses and did something about the problems before this country. Caucus members are having Christmas dinner at the Lodge tonight, which I am sure will be quite a merry pickle. I will continue my remarks after the suspension of the sitting for dinner.
—The Opposition has proposed an amendment to the second reading motion of the tax Bills and the levy Bill that are in front of the Senate which, in part, says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate condemns the Government for its economic policy failures which have resulted in one and a half million Australians being unemployed or underemployed in the worst recession for 60 years, and urges the Government to adopt the Opposition's `Fightback!' package of proposals to provide hope, and a vision for the future, for all Australians. . .

It then includes a number of particular points. Adoption of these points is urged very sincerely and strongly by Opposition members as the only way forward—not only in tax reform matters but also as a way of getting this economy onto its feet again.

PARA.TAB: There is no hope left now for the Labor Government and there may be less than 24 hours left for this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has entertained the honourable senators opposite at Christmas dinner—which all day around this chamber has been called the `last supper'—at the Lodge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be sacrilegious.

—I will not speculate as to what will happen in the next 24 hours. I just make the serious point that, while the Government members were having their last supper—their Christmas pudding—at Prime Minister Hawke's Lodge this evening, one million Australians were unemployed and the whole of Australia was crying out for some kind of Christmas present in terms of an economic approach that will work in this country; and that can be found only in the Opposition's proposals, about which not one criticism has struck home in the four weeks since they were announced.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I see Government members in despair because they know that there has not been a feather placed on the decisions that have been announced, including, as is referred to in the amendment that is before us, the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history, which amount to $13 billion. That is not being offered by the Australian Government, by the Labor Government; it is what is being offered by the Liberal and National parties' Fightback package.

It will only be when we are elected to government that we will see a turnaround and the creation of two million extra jobs in the remaining years of this decade, the largest ever income tax cuts, the complete abolition of excise on petrol, diesel and other fuels, the abolition of all wholesale sales tax, the abolition of all payroll taxes, the abolition of the superannuation lump sum tax, the abolition of all Customs duties, the abolition of the training guarantee levy and the coal export duty and so on. These are the matters that are referred to in the amendment because it is the only good news that can be offered in the Senate chamber when we are debating this aspect of the economy, that is, the tax measures that the Government has placed before us.

I wish to turn now to one particular Bill, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2). I make the observation that Bills for double taxation agreements between Australia and other countries often do not receive much attention when they come before the Parliament, I think because they are regarded as highly technical—and they are—and because they are matters of such careful negotiation between Australia and other countries that it is only if some major principle is being transgressed that we seek, in the Parliament, some amendment or some change. I wish to refer to the two agreements that are before us in this legislation, one with Poland and the other with India.

To make the obvious point, such tax agreements are indeed a positive measure when they are worked out to serve the national interests of Australians. They give a greater incentive for Australians to engage in commerce from Australia into these other countries, yet double penalties will not be suffered in paying tax in this country and in the other country. It is to this aspect I wish to refer in addressing the Bills before us this evening.

Australia has developed a system of such agreements with quite a number of countries, and the Bill now before us extends that system to include Poland and India. So I welcome the Bill, and I hope that these agreements will assist the blossoming of trade and investment between Australia and Poland and between Australia and India. There is certainly plenty of scope to increase our economic links with both these countries.

In 1989-90, for example, our exports to Poland totalled $109.3m while our imports from Poland were worth $38.7m. That is a total trade of only $150m, or a bit less, between our countries, which is not very much at all. There is certainly a great deal of room for improvement. Indeed, many Polish Australians, or many Australians of Polish descent—and many others besides—are urging Australians to become a part of the investment pattern that will lead to something of an economic rescue through overseas investment in Poland; that is what is argued is needed in that country. Certainly it is my view that we can increase the commercial relations between Australia and Poland to the mutual benefit of the Polish people and the Australian people; we must take all measures so that we can do that.

Of course, our trade with India is on a much larger scale but it is still well below the potential that I believe is achievable. Senator Maguire is here tonight in the chamber. In 1989 he and I were both involved in a major Senate inquiry into Australia's relations with India, including our trade relations. We brought before the Senate a series of recommendations that would see an increase in trade between India and Australia, and that report was very positively responded to by the Australian Government.

The present level of Australian exports to India is little more than the 1989-90 figure of $589.9m, and our imports from India in that year were worth $278.4m. That is less than $1 billion worth of trade with India. In fact, against a background of trade around the world, 51 per cent of Australia's exports—that is, just over half of all our exports—is to the Asia-Pacific nations, east Asia and the ASEAN area, and only one per cent of our trade is with south Asia. That trade of a little less than $1 billion—the figure I have just rehearsed—is mostly with India. It is my view that the majority of our trade in the decades ahead will continue to be with east Asia and the ASEAN area, but we still can increase substantially our trade with India and south Asia.

Having outlined or introduced my thoughts to that extent, given the enormous amount of material we are to consider in the Senate between now and our rising tomorrow, I seek leave to incorporate the balance of my speech on these matters in the Hansard record.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me early in my remarks commend those who were responsible for preparing the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill. It is very clear in setting out and explaining what the Bill does and what the various clauses of the two agreements mean. It is a memorandum in the newer style of "plain English" that is now sometimes forthcoming from the Government. I welcome it, and commend the public servants responsible for drafting it.

Rather than deal with the complexities of these two agreements, I want to reflect on the broader context of economic development in Poland and India and consider how Australia's economic interests can best be furthered in light of that development, a part of that process being, of course, the establishment of these double taxation agreements.

In the case of Poland, the economy is now dominated by the transition from communism to capitalism, with all the pressures and difficulties that that is bound to involve. We saw in 1989 the overturning of numerous communist regimes in eastern Europe, and in that process Poland played a significant role. It led eastern Europe in the holding of partially democratic elections and the bringing to power of a government led by non-Communists. It is worth reflecting on the nature of those changes, as we seek to understand better the relationships a country like Australia can now have with Poland and its neighbours. We have seen the ending of communist tyranny and the launching of political democracy and economic liberalisation. The old Marxist and Stalinist formulas failed the peoples of eastern Europe. Their rigidly planned economies failed to either furnish a satisfactory standard of living or provide a viable industrial base that was efficient and could trade competitively in an open world market. This economic failure of communism has meant that the people of those countries have suffered lower standards of living than needed to be the case. They have been denied opportunities to develop entrepreneurial flair and make economic decisions for themselves. Not only were each of these countries suffering from having a centrally-directed economy, they were nearly all subject to a significant level of pressure from the Soviet Union as to what they could and could not produce and as to how they should trade with the Soviet Union and other countries. Coupled with this economic oppression was political oppression, which was essential if the economic oppression was to be implemented. Basic liberal freedoms such as freedom of speech and freedom of association were denied to people much of the time, and there was no mechanism for the people to use to force a change of government. The lack of choice and competition between differing political views meant a denial of what we consider to be essential democratic rights. The oppression of people by these communist regimes was even wider than merely economic or political, in my view. There was a deeper malaise, a breakdown of civic trust, a breakdown of confidence in the governing institutions of a country. People could not be sure whether they could trust family or friends or neighbours, for these might be agents of secret police forces. There was little value placed on truth. Even the economic statistics produced by these regimes were sometimes suspect, which made economic decision making all the harder. In other words there was what I would term a spiritual malaise. It meant the denial by the regime of values of justice. Little wonder that in the end these regimes imploded. The people were no longer prepared to put up with the conditions in which they had to live their lives.

The way in which communism fell varied from country to country. Poland, happily, was among those where the move was bloodless. The challenge since then for Poland has been to devise policies that can best manage the transition to a market economy. Bold moves were promptly taken, and a vigorous reform program began from 1 January 1990. For that boldness Poland is to be commended. I believe that when such massive changes need to be undertaken, with the undoubted pain that these will bring for the people of the country, it is better to tackle them quickly rather than gradually. The big shifts in Polish policy from the start of last year is therefore, in my view, the right approach. The move to more realistic pricing of goods and services meant changes to economic difficulties. Instead of many queues at Polish shops for goods that were in short supply, the shops before long became well-stocked with many goods, although these were often at higher prices which put them out of the reach of many consumers. Unemployment, not surprisingly, rose, but there was success in keeping the inflation rate down. This year has seen an agreement with the IMF and the cancellation of a significant portion of Poland's foreign debt.

PARA.TAB: For much of the last two years the Government has kept up its thrust of economic reform, with a continuity of key economic ministers in the government both before and after President Walesa took office. There is at the moment some uncertainty about the future because of the result of the recent parliamentary elections and the large number of parties elected. There have been reports in recent weeks of a slowdown in the privatisation program. I hope that this will prove to be a short term hiatus, and that before long there will be a government formed which will press on with policies of economic reform. One step forward has been the opening of a Warsaw Stock Exchange last April. It is located in the former headquarters of the Communist Party, an irony that appeals to me.

SPEECH.PARA: There are opportunities for Australian firms to become involved in ventures in Poland. This double taxation agreement will help to provide a framework of confidence that will encourage further investment. I note, as examples, some press reports in the last year or so of instances of Australian investment. The Financial Review of 29 August 1990 reported the success of Seafood Products Gdynia, a joint venture which is 51% owned by a Melbourne company and which has enjoyed success in the food processing market in Poland. The Sydney Morning Herald on 8 July this year reported that an Australian firm has won the rights to operate duty free shops at the new Warsaw International Airport. The Australian on 12 August reported a joint venture of Telecom, a Perth firm and Polish investors to set up a telephone network in rural Poland. The Financial Review on 30 July this year noted that Western Mining Corporation was interested in the possibility of involvement in a large Polish Government-owned copper producer when it is privatised. So there are possibilities for Australian interests in Poland, and I hope that the passage of this double taxation agreement will help to encourage other Australian firms to consider Polish opportunities.

I turn now to the agreement with India. Senators will not be surprised that I refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the subject of Australia-India Relations, a document that we presented to the Senate in 1990. It was a good report, and it dealt with the economic relationship as well as other aspects of the bilateral relationship. That relationship has not been as close in recent years as it could be, and that includes the economic aspect. India has had a history of caution and even suspicion about foreign investment. There has been a considerable effort in the past to aim at a high degree of industrial self-sufficiency. There has been a rigid system of industrial licensing and price control, along with a high level of government involvement and ownership in key industries. These have not been good circumstances in which to develop Australia's economic links with India. However, there has more recently been a change of approach in policy-making circles in India, just as has been happening in many parts of the world. There is now a desire on the part of the Indian Government to move to an economy with a less dominant public sector and an economy that is more open to international competitive forces. The first budget of the government of Mr Rao, introduced on 24 July, made clear moves towards economic liberalisation. Foreign investment is being made easier in many industries. The domestic deficit is being cut back.
