Australia can do more to take up opportunities in trade and investment in India, and at the same time India must be doing its part in making those opportunities. I believe that we are now more firmly set on that path of mutual economic benefit than for a long time.

It seems quite appropriate that this double taxation agreement was signed in the same week as the Rao Government's liberalising budget was brought down. This agreement will add to the framework of measures that will encourage Australians and Australian firms to become economically involved with India. The Senate Committee report in Chapter Two discusses export prospects in a number of fields, including coal, power and steel; wool; wheat; lead, zinc and alloys; and computers and associated technology. It gives instances of opportunities already being taken up by Australian firms. There are further opportunities opening up.

Let me refer to a paper recently given by Paul Barratt, a Deputy Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, when he addressed the Melbourne South Asian Studies Group and the Melbourne Branch of the Australian Institute of International Affairs. He refers to a paper prepared by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and says: "The paper argues that Australia should more systematically exploit market opportunities in India, especially in the minerals and energy, agriculture, services and development project sectors. These are the sectors where Australia already has substantial commercial links and expertise. . . India's chronic capital shortage and moves to promote foreign investment could lead, however, to further policy changes intended to open the mining sector to overseas private sector investors. Gold, diamonds and non-ferrous metals are the resources offering greatest potential reward to investors in this sector. The signing in July 1991 of a Double Tax Agreement between Australia and India should facilitate investment procedures as the opportunities become available. . . In the agriculture sector, Australian pulse exports provide a substantial share of India's price-sensitive import market for this commodity. . . Prospects for consultancy services are sound in mining, environmental management, agriculture, telecommunications and energy. . . Opportunities exist to win commercial contracts for large-scale development projects, particularly in mining. . . India's critical need for power generation should provide opportunities for Australian energy projects linking the supply of steaming coal to seaboard thermal power plants." I make this reference to Mr Barratt's paper as it is a current summary of the possibilities open to us with regard to India.

I take particular note of Article 24 of the agreement with India. This provides for "tax sparing", a means of encouraging particular foreign investment where India under its own laws forgoes tax, and the Australian-resident recipient of income will obtain tax credit relief as if the Indian tax had been paid. This is a sound provision that ensures that the agreement does not over-ride particular Indian incentives for development.

I conclude on the note that I am optimistic about what can be achieved by Australia in both Poland and India. These agreements are a significant part of improving our opportunities in those countries, and so I welcome their passage through the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see our Government friends over there back from the last supper. If they seem happy, I presume it is because they have had some Dutch courage to get them over their hard times. Judging by the way our friends over there have been interjecting, they have perhaps had a `Merry Christmas' with Bob tonight at the last supper and will no doubt have a happy New Year with Paul.

PARA.TAB: However, as to the main issues of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill and associated Bills now before us, I will be addressing the fringe benefits tax on living away from home allowances, general mining exploration productivity expenditure, and the capital gains tax cost base of provisional tax amendments. These initiatives have come out of the March statement.

At the risk of being accused of repetition, we are now in December and the measures contained in the industry statement were announced on 12 March. The Government was to provide incentives for Australians to increase productivity and employment. Here we are today, 18 December, and we are only beginning to debate many of these measures. I admit that a lot of good could have been achieved if these measures announced in March had been put in place far earlier. However, I presume it is better late than never. A prediction was made on the radio this morning that another statement would be handed down in February. I always thought that might be the case. It may be that the initiatives in the March statement will not have been implemented by the time the next statement is handed down.

The basis of the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991 is to amend fringe benefits tax law to ensure that living away from home allowances for people working on offshore oil and gas platforms are treated as fringe benefits tax. I have said many times in this place, and I will say many times again, that fringe benefits tax is mostly a restriction on enterprise, production and incentives, especially when it comes in the remoter areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you getting rid of it?

—Yes. If Senator Tate looks at the Fightback package, he will see that it will be reviewed and altered where it is not a fringe benefit in remote areas. If Senator Tate reads the Fightback package, he will see that. The tax is restrictive and is an impost on production.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting when it comes to the oil platforms, and I will come back to this later. How can it be said that accommodation supplied on an oil platform—a man-made platform—is a fringe benefit? The workers are in a captive situation. Where can they be accommodated except on the oil rig? If they are not accommodated on the oil rig, there will be no workers. If there are no workers on the oil platform, the oil rig will not produce. It is as simple as that; there is no alternative. At least mining and oil exploration companies in some of the more remote areas can employ local people, and they do not have to pay fringe benefits tax because they are not supplying accommodation, but on an oil platform they can do nothing else.

When it comes to zone A or zone B rebates, the Taxation Office specifically denies them to taxpayers who work on oil rigs. Taxpayers who spend far more than six months on platforms and apply for rebates are told that they are not in zone A or zone B because those zones finish at the shoreline. The rebates do not apply to man-made objects. They apply to offshore islands which are part of Australia's jurisdiction, but not to man-made platforms. At least three rulings that I know of have gone against taxpayers who have applied for rebates in those circumstances. Incidentally, I have a private member's Bill, which will be brought on later, prepared to remedy just that situation.
The workings of the living away from home allowance and fringe benefits tax are described in the explanatory memorandum as follows:

LAFHAs are defined in section 30 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 (FBTAA) as being allowances paid to compensate an employee for additional expenses incurred by the employee or additional expenses incurred by the employee and other additional disadvantages that the employee is subject to while required to live away from his usual place of residence in order to perform his work duties.

Some LAFHAs paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers are paid solely to compensate the employee for additional disadvantages of living away from home. Because these allowances do not include a component for additional expenses incurred by the employee they do not fall within the definition of a LAFHA in section 30 of the FBTAA.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation makes sure that it will work in that way. I will now move on to the general mining, exploration and prospecting leases. Deductions will be allowed for expenses incurred in the maintenance and exploration of those areas. To date, there has been no allowance for the grassroots sort of exploration where there are large areas, but not necessarily mining leases. People can just fly over the areas using a magnetometer, or travel along the roads taking samples. There are no definite mining leases, and that will be fixed up in this legislation. On behalf of the mining industry I welcome the move. The legislation will allow deduction on mining tenements, and a mining tenement covers a prospecting lease and an exploration licence, only on a specified piece of ground or a general purpose lease.

PARA.TAB: Now I will move to deal with capital gains tax. Under the new legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you supporting capital gains tax?
—What did you say?
—You have always opposed capital gains tax. Are you now supporting it?

—I am just coming to capital gains tax. There are certain provisions in the Fightback package, if Senator Maguire would care to read them, showing how we are going to deal with it. It certainly will not be the capital gains tax that this Government brought in, even though it said there would be no capital gains tax. We will allow costs such as interest, repairs, rates and taxes, insurance premiums and land taxes in calculating capital gains tax. One important point is that capital gains tax has been a boon to accountants. Nowhere in this legislation have accounting fees been mentioned as deductible. As I said, that has been a big boon to accounting firms which keep the records, especially when people in property are in for the long haul. Capital gains tax should not apply where some property is held for a very long time. There is provision in the Fightback package to even that out.

PARA.TAB: It only applies to assets bought after 21 August 1991. In other words, assets bought between 20 September 1985 and 21 August 1991 will always be taxed without having these deductions. I ask: why is this? It is totally unfair because anyone who bought after 20 September 1985 to the present date must be termed a long term investor. Short term investors would have been out in the first 12 months. I believe it is totally unfair. In the Hewson package we will allow certain measures. For instance, we will allow an option to pay capital gains tax at a flat rate, so a person will not have to keep the normal paperwork that is required in these cases.

I now move to provisional tax. For 1991 and subsequent years, taxpayers will be liable to pay provisional tax on salary and wages if they satisfy both parts of a simple test. I think it would read better if people paid provisional tax when they failed a simple test. The two conditions are that the balance is to be paid by a salary or wage earner if the assessment is more than $3,000 and, secondly, if PAYE deductions from salary or wages income are under deducted by $3,000 or more. Why these changes? Obviously, it seems to me, the present system gives rise to an inequity where some members of a class of taxpayers, liable to provisional tax, will escape the liability simply because provisional tax was raised in the previous year. The second reading speech provides:

SPEECH.PARA: To resolve this inequity the Bill will split the provisional tax credits into two components:
(a) provisional tax on income other than salary or wages; and
(b) provisional tax on salary and wages income.

What other angles is the Government going to use to make sure that more flows to the taxation department than should be the case, and then it is a person's good luck if he happens to get it back later on? The problem is this: if provisional tax is raised the year before, and there is a tax credit, why is that not made available without a person having to incur further tax and then, hopefully, to get it back, if the person fits into the situation?

PARA.TAB: While I am on provisional tax, there has been nothing said in the explanatory memorandum on what the uplift is going to be. I thought the uplift was legislated for every year but I understand it is still at 10 per cent. How can we say that around Australia this year, in the worst recession in the last 60 years, there is going to be an average uplift in profits of 10 per cent? I know that I am going to be told later by the Minister or someone else that there is provision for readjustment, and I know that. But once people ask for a provisional readjustment they are wide open to penalties if they do not happen to do their accounting properly and get within plus or minus 10 per cent. They should have the right to pay provisional tax at the rate it was paid the previous year—presuming that it was last year. Then, if people find it is below that figure, it is up to them. For many years, there has been an uplift of 10 or 11 per cent. In the good years I suppose that was fair enough, but in this case I cannot see too many businesses around Australia having an average uplift of 10 per cent.

I come back to the tardiness of this legislation. We dealt with the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) the other day. It was introduced way back in March. It was rushed through so quickly I could not ask any questions about its inequity—whether its provisions start in March or in December when the Bill was passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was backdated though.

—The whole lot is backdated now. It must have changed since last week, because the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) said he was going to answer my question about the other Bill when this Bill was passed. That is totally unfair. I will not go back to the Sales Tax Bill at present.

PARA.TAB: I support the good measures of this Bill. I certainly disagree with the measures provided in the fringe benefits area, because it is totally unfair to impose a fringe benefits tax on captive people on a platform where they can do nothing else. Yet at the same time, those people are not allowed to claim the zone rebate because they are offshore and not regarded as being on the Australian mainland. At least within the jurisdiction that Australia has over its waters, they should be treated the same. If people spend over six months on a fishing trawler in zone A or zone B off those shores, they should be treated the same. I said that the Hewson package is eliminating seven taxes. The Bills we are debating tonight raise three new ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot support a VAT.
—I will come to Senator Maguire later. I support the amendment moved by my colleagues this evening and look forward to speaking more in-depth in the committee stage.

—Tonight the Senate is debating a number of taxation Bills cognately. In the first section of my remarks I want to outline the proposals contained in those Bills and then I want to concentrate on some of the issues that the legislation addresses. The first Bill, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991, proposes to implement the Budget decision to increase the minimum income thresholds which apply to the Medicare levy. People with income below the various thresholds are exempt from the levy. It is annual practice to increase the thresholds and to announce the increases when delivering the Budget.

PARA.TAB: For 1991-92 the threshold for individuals will remain unchanged at $11,745, while married couples and sole parents with income under $19,674 will be exempt. The threshold is increased by $2,100 for each dependent child or student. Thus a sole parent with three children will not pay any Medicare levy if her or his income is less than $25,974. The level of tax instalment deductions will not be adjusted because the administrative costs of adjustment are quite substantial. These costs include things such as the cost of printing and distribution of millions of pay-as-you-earn deduction forms.

The people who are currently paying the levy but who will be under the threshold when this Bill passes will continue to pay the levy but this will be refunded at the end of the financial year. Provisional tax will also not be adjusted to reflect the minor changes in this Bill. Again, the cost and the complexity is too great to warrant such a change.

The Australian Democrats support this legislation. However, I think it could be improved by also increasing the $2,100 allowance for each dependent child or student in line with inflation to maintain the real value of this concession. Perhaps the Government might consider this in next year's Budget or in its economic statement in the new year.

The next Bill in the package before us tonight is the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991. Fringe benefits tax applies to fringe benefits, as defined, which are provided to employees by employers. This tax is based on the New Zealand model, which imposes the liability on the employer and not on the recipient of the benefit. Obviously, it is argued that this is very efficient for collection purposes and ensures high levels of compliance. It is also politically astute, because the tax burden legally falls on the business sector, even though salary packages are reduced to take account of the tax.

Fringe benefits tax is levied at the top personal marginal income tax rate of 47 per cent. This is because fringe benefits tax applies to benefits which would normally accrue to high income earners and, hence, would be taxed at this rate if the benefit were paid in cash. I believe that this is a sound principle. However, it ignores the fact that the Medicare levy is added to this 47 per cent rate, thereby making the actual maximum marginal rate 48.25 per cent. There is still a minor incentive to take benefits in the form of fringe benefits instead of cash. This Bill proposes to increase the rate of fringe benefits tax from 47 per cent to 48.25 to eliminate that small anomaly which I have just mentioned.

This measure was originally proposed in the two alternative Budgets that the Democrats have so far released, so obviously it would be hypocritical of us not to support it. We costed this proposal in our alternative Budget as raising $25m per annum. Treasury has estimated that it will raise $35m per annum for the April to April full year. This measure will commence in April 1992. Despite the protestations we often hear, particularly from the Opposition, about Democrat proposals to raise revenue, I think that this measure is a good example of how the Australian Democrats are responsible by seeking to raise in an equitable manner the additional revenue we wish to spend. This Bill will add to the progressivity of the taxation system. That is a fair principle, and I think it is good to see the Opposition supporting this Bill.

The next Bill in the package is the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991. This Bill is the formal imposition Bill, which is necessary under section 55 of the Constitution when a tax is imposed. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which I will be discussing later, contains a provision to impose an interest withholding tax on securities which do not pay interest. This proposal is not controversial; it is simply closing a loophole in the tax file number provisions. It was announced earlier this year in the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan). This separate Bill is necessary for constitutional reasons. I will deal with the policy of the decision to impose this withholding tax on certain securities in my discussion on the third Bill. Of course, the Democrats support this Bill and will not oppose its second reading.

The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) proposes to give the force of law to two double taxation agreements recently entered into by Australia. The agreements, which are with India and Poland, follow the ordinary structure of double taxation agreements, with some minor variations where this has been insisted upon by the other nation. For example, the Indian agreement has a special treatment of royalties which is different from that normally followed by Australia in its treaties; indeed, it is different from the royalties provision in the Polish agreement, which is also contained within this Bill.

The Indian Government has insisted upon a broad definition of royalties, which includes fees for the rendering of technical or consultancy services. In addition, the rate of the royalty withholding tax is to be set at 20 per cent for the first five years for private sector payers, dropping to 15 per cent, which is the rate that applies for government payers. I am not criticising the Government for breaking with tradition, because I am aware of the importance of this treaty in terms of building stronger trade ties between India and Australia.

I am also aware that the United States took years to negotiate a similar arrangement with India and that it is an achievement on the part of our negotiators to have succeeded in obtaining a similar outcome to that achieved by the United States. The Australian Democrats support the two double taxation agreements which are before the Senate tonight and will be supporting that Bill.

Notwithstanding the variety of matters that I have already referred to, the major piece of legislation in the package is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). This Bill is the usual end of year massive omnibus income tax Bill. There are 26 categories of amendments covered by the Bill, none of which is controversial, although the Opposition will be moving some amendments. The measures proposed include taxing the living away from home allowance of offshore oil workers as a fringe benefit instead of as income. There will be an exemption from income tax for the pay and allowances paid to Defence Force personnel who served in the Iraq war. Investment related lottery winnings will be taxed. Petroleum rent resource tax is to be deductible for income tax purposes when it is paid, and not in the subsequent year. The 125 per cent deduction for research and development will be extended indefinitely beyond its sunset date of 30 June 1995.

A register of cultural organisations, donations to which will be tax deductible, will be established. Expenditure on environmental impact statements will be tax deductible over the lesser of 10 years or the life of the project. Imputation credits will arise only when company tax is paid instead of when it is assessed. A new method of calculation of provisional tax is to be introduced to eliminate an anomaly in the existing system. New rules are to be introduced to impose withholding tax on deferred interest investments where the investor has not provided a tax file number. There will be an overhaul and a standardisation of objection and appeal provisions for all taxation matters. All registered organisations will be removed from the dividend imputation system and the existing franking credits which have been accumulated will be eliminated. There are amendments to delete redundant references in the provisions which deal with income earned in overseas employment.

Quite clearly, the areas covered in this Bill are enormous. I will spend a few minutes dealing with some of the more contentious ones which concern the Democrats and some which concern the Opposition. The first matter relates to the Medicare levy exemption. The proposal to limit the Medicare levy exemption to those social security beneficiaries who are in receipt of a sickness benefit and the blind pension will affect some health care card holders who were receiving the sole parent pension and other pensions and benefits which have employment transition packages. The exemption would also have applied to some people who would have received a partial family allowance supplement. As I understand it, the Government is arguing that this is an unintended consequence of the drafting of the original proposal and that, therefore, the measure must be amended to reflect that earlier policy.

In some ways it is quite difficult for us to support a measure which seeks to remove retrospectively an advantage to those obtaining assistance under our often unfair social security system. Over the years I think the Democrats have sat in this chamber voting alone while the Government and the Opposition have combined to erode the rights of those in this community who are the most vulnerable and most in need. It is quite a nice irony that for once a legislative anomaly has arisen in our taxation law which does not assist the rich and powerful but actually benefits some beneficiaries of the social security system. This Bill will close this loophole. As I said, we considered opposing the measure, but we decided to support it as the existing situation may confer an unwarranted benefit on someone who has ceased receiving the benefit and who has obtained employment with a high remuneration.

The proposal in the Bill to alter the timing of the creation of franking credits in a company's franking account is not opposed by us. Ironically, it appears that the change to a system where franking credits arise only where payments have been made has inadvertently eliminated an anomaly which existed in section 160ARX of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This section provides that, where a company overfranks a dividend during the year and the company's franking account is in deficit by more than 10 per cent of the total of the franking credits arising during the year, then a penalty of 30 per cent of the franking deficit tax which applies to the company will also be imposed.

The current system involves the crediting of company tax instalments and then the crediting of the actual tax payable, with the previous company tax instalments being debited to reverse the earlier credits. Hence, the level of franking credits arising during the year is higher under the current system, which has a degree of double entry, even though the net balance in the franking account will not be affected by the proposed move in this Bill to a payment-only based system of franking credits.

This means that companies will be liable to pay additional tax under this section on a much lower deficit in their franking accounts than is currently the case. We think that that outcome should have been legislated for in the first place. However, it is important to put on the record the fact that, although it appears that this change was not deliberately pursued by the Government, it is nevertheless a fortuitous consequence of the alteration of the timing of the creation of franking credits under the dividend imputation system. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary would confirm this.

I want to refer to another important income tax matter, and this is the exemption granted to community service organisations. The Australian Democrats support income tax exemption for the community service sector and we voted for the existing exemption provision when it was introduced by the former Treasurer, Mr Keating. This exemption quite properly does not apply to bodies that have been established for political or lobbying purposes, including standing candidates for election or campaigning for changes to the law or to government policy. However, a community service organisation will not lose its exempt status if its political or lobbying activities are merely incidental to its main activities.

The Australian Democrats agree with this exclusion of `political organisation'. However, the critical matter is how to define when a community organisation is a political one, or when any organisation is a political one. One such case has come to my attention, and this is the case of the Valentine Progress Association, in the Lake Macquarie area of New South Wales. The Newcastle branch of the tax office has determined this association to be taxable. We raised this matter in the chamber on 18 June. Senator McMullan responded that the tax office had issued a pamphlet which was over-general and said that it had been withdrawn. So we told the association this, and it was happy and confident that renting out a community hall to local groups would not be classified as a political activity.

Unfortunately, the tax office did not agree and it levied a tax and a fine on the association. A member of the committee was, understandably, a little bit upset when he received a political advertisement in his letterbox in which the candidate made the point that he was a member of the local Rotary club. As we know, Rotary, Apex and Lions are all tax exempt, and so they should be. But I think that progress associations should not all be deemed to be political bodies when they are only providing services to the community which would not otherwise be provided. I would ask Senator McMullan, when he is here, to give a commitment to get an answer to this dilemma, as his original statement about this—although made in good faith, I am sure—does not appear to have fully covered the situation pertaining in the Newcastle area.

The final income tax matter that I wish to raise tonight concerns a recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision, and the reference is 22 ATR Case 4 October 1991. The case involved a taxpayer who manufactured tobacco products. In the 1988 tax year, the company paid almost half a million dollars to an industry association to fund a public relations campaign against the passing of legislation then pending in the parliaments of Victoria and South Australia. The legislation was to restrict tobacco sports advertising and to increase the State tax on tobacco products. I do not need to go into the technicalities of the decision, but the outcome was that the taxpayer won.

This means that the Commonwealth, in effect, subsidised the campaign of the tobacco company to fight the advertising restrictions and the creation of the health promotion funds. The Australian Democrats believe that this is bad public policy and that no tobacco advertising expenditure should qualify for an income tax deduction—with no exceptions. This is especially so in a case such as this. I call on the Government to change the law so that such an expenditure is not allowable as a legitimate tax deduction.

The new Treasurer, Mr Willis, said recently that the Government was considering a change in economic policy. While this is probably motivated by the intrigue of the leadership struggle, nevertheless it is a positive sign that the Labor Party is starting to recognise some of the damage that its policies have caused. I hope we will see a significant move away from the economic rationalist policies which have so significantly harmed this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating a package of taxation legislation, including the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991. Owing to time constraints, we are restricted in our contributions to this debate because we are now supposedly on the second last day of sitting for the year. As usual, the Government could not manage its way out of a telephone box, so we are now debating important pieces of legislation at the eleventh hour.

PARA.TAB: The Bill that I wish to concentrate on is the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991, because in the overall context of this record taxing Labor Government the increase in fringe benefits tax for 1992-93 from 47 to 48.25 per cent may be considered almost trivial. It is certainly considered trivial by the Government, which has done very little, if anything, to help people in remote parts of Australia to be more profitable and more productive. It may do no more than bring the FBT into line with the top marginal rate plus the Medicare levy, but what we are really looking at is the overall impact of such a decision on remote Australia.

The amount of $1.3 billion to be raised through this tax in 1991-92 constitutes just under 2 per cent of total income tax revenue and 1 1/2 per cent of total taxation revenue. The coalition does not dispute the need to ensure that the more highly paid members of the work force are not able to avoid tax by receiving benefits in lieu of income, but we suggest that there be some fairness and equity in the way in which taxes are administered.

It is for that reason that we have put out our Fightback package in recent weeks to try to focus on those particular areas. Under the reform package of the coalition—the next government of Australia—the principle of FBT remains, because it will continue to be levied at the top marginal rate of tax plus the Medicare levy. But there is one major difference in our package: the top marginal tax rate will be reduced. This will properly be reduced ultimately to 43.25 per cent as we provide a top rate that will encourage incentive and make it worth while for people to work harder and longer. That is a marked difference between us and this Government, which is talking about a top rate at 48.25 per cent.

More importantly, what the next Liberal and National Government will do is review the impact of this tax particularly on the mining, pastoral and tourist industries. This undertaking is of great importance to the north of Western Australia where, unquestionably, the fringe benefits tax has impacted on normal working and living conditions to the detriment of that and other remote regions of Australia.

I only wish that the Government knew and understood exactly the impact of many of its policies. This afternoon some of us had the displeasure of hearing Senator Collins's utterances about how meek and mild our offers were to increase the zone allowance. But, of course, Senator Collins judiciously decided not to respond to any interjections, questions or queries about what this Government has done about the zone allowance in all the time that it has been in office. The answer, of course, is nothing. So how hypocritical can one be to accuse the coalition of not offering enough increase in the zone allowance to people living in remote Australia when this Government has done precisely nothing?

The current application of the fringe benefits tax is a very real disincentive to the growth of stable population centres in remote, inhospitable, but nevertheless vitally significant, areas of Australia. Today, iron ore companies pay a $20m tax on the continued provision of community infrastructure in the Pilbara—the mining towns that were a direct consequence of agreement Acts passed by the Parliament of Western Australia. I find it rather staggering that this Government can continue to tax industries such as the iron ore industry at $20m and then turn around and wonder why they are not flourishing to the extent that they should be.

I would defy anyone to argue that home ownership schemes, holiday travel from isolated regions, subsidised power where air-conditioning is an absolute necessity of life and not some sort of fringe benefit that one can opt for, or a bus service to a mine site constitute benefits as a form of income minimisation. None of those is a form of income minimisation. They are simply forms of trying to make people more comfortable in remote Australia; they are also forms of trying to encourage people to go to the more remote areas of Australia. These are areas of the tax that require careful examination. These are areas that the next Liberal and National party Government will totally review.

The fact that accommodation and travel are subject to 50 per cent remote area discounting is an acknowledgment by this Government that they are not in fact fringe benefits but necessities. But that acknowledgment aside, the reality is that the Government taxes them as fringe benefits and not as necessities. Logically, it is fair to ask why they should be taxed at all. But, of course, as we know from this Government, `If it moves, tax it; and if it doesn't, you may as well tax it as well'.

While many executive perks prior to the introduction of the FBT were liable for taxation in the hands of the recipient, the Commissioner of Taxation did not then regard remote area travel or subsidised township services as taxable benefits. It is time that they were reviewed, and that is what the Opposition has given a commitment to do when it is the next government.

We talk a lot in this Parliament about level playing fields. Quite frankly, this is a term that I cannot stand because most of the people who talk about level playing fields really do not mean what they say and do not say what they mean. But members of the Hawke Labor Government often pay lip-service to this principle. Some, like Senator Walsh, actually believe in it. I ask, therefore: where is the equity in taxing mining companies for, in effect, providing infrastructure? It is to their financial advantage in the 1990s to build no new towns but rather to operate projects through fly-in, fly-out arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even existing towns.

—That is quite right. Even existing towns, of course, are now being confronted with this problem. It is expected that new projects in the Pilbara will operate the bulk of their work forces in this way.

PARA.TAB: It would be a jolly good idea if members of this Government, particularly the Minister and the Prime Minister—if we had a Prime Minister who was really an incumbent of the office—had a look at some of these areas to understand the full impact of the fly in, fly out arrangements and what they have done to the towns that are affected. It is not a matter of governments encouraging decentralisation through a larger Pilbara population, by interfering with the market, but rather of reviewing and reducing an existing distortion caused by the tax system.

It is of concern to me as a senator for Western Australia just what a detrimental effect the FBT is having on the health and viability of Pilbara communities. The FBT is raised with me every time I visit the north-west or every time I talk to anyone from the north-west. The FBT is slowly doing to these towns what the withdrawal of service personnel will do to Exmouth, further west in Western Australia. There would be absolutely no need for the FBT to be imposed on the people of the Pilbara if some logic and understanding of the real necessities were put in place.

We need only consider the fact that, in the four years between 1986 and 1990, while the population of Western Australia rose 12 per cent, by some 174,800 people, the population of the four Pilbara local authorities fell by 1.2 per cent, to 47,700. That is not a development which we would naturally expect when resource industries are healthy. We also have to look at the fact that this Government has pandered to the Greens and to every interest group so that in a time of need the Prime Minister can call up his debts and ask those interest groups to write nice letters to members of the Caucus asking them to keep him on as Prime Minister. The reality is that, unfortunately, people in remote Australia are suffering as a consequence.

It has been of advantage to the growth engine of the Pilbara and indeed of Western Australia, the iron ore industry, that the provision of company housing stabilised the work force so that an initial turnover of 100 per cent reduced to only 15 per cent. That is a very significant change. The Government now provides a tax disincentive that would loom far larger if value added industries were to be established.

Should steel making ever begin in the Pilbara, with the consequent need for a larger and more permanent work force, it has been estimated that full FBT would impose a production cost of $3.75 for each input tonne of iron ore. This Government thinks that is okay. Surely this is a time when we need more development and more employment—there are over one million people unemployed in this country—yet every possible barrier is put in front of companies which provide employment and income for Australia.

A Liberal-National government would not only review FBT, but would also bring about the abolition of payroll tax which penalises large employers and small employers alike, particularly the large employers in the Pilbara, such as mining companies and those who provide many jobs in the area. In the opinion of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures 175,000 jobs will emerge in the Pilbara as a result of this reform. It needs change; it needs reform. What is this Government offering with respect to a change in direction of policy, a redirection of policy and a reassessment of policy? It is offering absolutely nothing. The reason is that Treasury is locked away trying to blow the Fightback package out of the water and, therefore, the Government is unable—it is paralysed—to provide any change in direction.

I do not apologise for emphasising this situation of the Pilbara, but the misapplication of the FBT is far from being a purely Western Australian problem. In April last year, CRA informed the Industry Commission that overall the mining industry in 1988-89 had paid $15m in FBT for over 22,000 dwellings. BHP-Utah Coal stated in its submission that since 1986 it had paid $14.5m in FBT on the employment of 4,600 people in inland central Queensland, including $6.6m spent on housing.

It is the same story in the Pilbara, with FBT levied on the provision of infrastructure where costs and conditions are unfavourable. In particular, from 1986 to 1990, $1.4m in FBT was paid for the provision of a bus service from a mining town to two mine sites 55 kilometres and 61 kilometres distant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they supposed to ride pushbikes out?

—That is a very good question from Senator Panizza. Perhaps the Government would prefer to see them ride pushbikes, but then, of course, the pushbikes would also be subject to FBT. This supposed executive perk does not even attract the 50 per cent remote area discount. It defies logic for this Government to claim that this is a fringe benefit when workers in metropolitan centres have their public transport subsidised by the taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: If anyone questions that, let it be known that TransPerth admits to the Government of Western Australia that fares recover only 26 per cent of the cost of commuter services. When we can travel four kilometres across the Perth central business district for free, why should a Pilbara mining company pay full FBT on the full contract price of a company bus service from town to mine where, of course, there is no alternative transport other than private vehicles? I am certainly confident that we will look very carefully at such anomalies because they are a total and utter disincentive to the work force and to companies.

In its report of 25 February on mining and mineral processing, the Industry Commission acknowledged that FBT had increased the cost of providing remote area housing. It took note of the argument that this was necessary to prevent rapid labour turnover, and of the difficulties in compensating employees through the wages system. I regret that the Commission did not follow the logic of the evidence and recommend at least an extension of the remote area discounting. Once it is conceded that some form of infrastructure incentive is appropriate, why not allow it to be provided in the most efficient and workable manner? The Commission, like this Labor Government, missed the essential point that these so-called benefits in remote areas were never intended as a means of wage minimisation.

The big difference between the approach of the coalition and the approach of the Labor Government towards the fringe benefits tax is that we have undertaken to review its impact in those areas where it is operating beyond its intention, to the detriment of Australian export industries and remote communities. This is just one more example of who is in touch with reality and who is looking for solutions.

We have come up with the positive policy alternatives. When and where will the Government's policy alternatives appear? Certainly, to date, we have not seen any indication of a policy change, and this country is going further and further backwards with the passing of every day that the Government fights over leadership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991, the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991, and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. This collection of Bills is, in part, the legislative response to the 12 March statement by Prime Minister Hawke—I think it was Prime Minister Hawke at that stage; it is still Prime Minister Hawke tonight, so I presume it was. The statement contained no solutions for the economic development of Australia. Since the statement was brought down in March, the economy has deteriorated very quickly. In March, the level of unemployment was 8 per cent; it is now over 10.2 per cent. The rate of youth unemployment at the moment is over 30 per cent, and 25 per cent of Australian families have none of their members employed.

PARA.TAB: Since March we have had a Budget and yet another pep talk from the Prime Minister, neither of which has set the course for Australia's recovery. That is an indictment on the Hawke-Keating, Hawke-Kerin and Hawke-Willis Labor governments.

The figures released a few weeks ago suggest that the recovery that was just around the corner is now further down the track. This Government seems to think that throwing another tax on the taxpayer amounts to a policy and a direction. We should compare the adhockery that we have endured in Australia for eight years with the coalition's offer of a massive tax reform package for Australia.

The coalition is offering Australia not only tax reform through a goods and services tax but also labour market reform, efficient infrastructure, a reform of government operations, privatisation, industry reform and environment and development reform. In fact, we are offering a vision that will provide opportunities to all Australians instead of throwing them onto the scrap heap, as this Government has done. Our package is genuine and thorough in its attempt to address many of the serious economic, social and geographic problems. Senator Knowles alluded tonight to geographic problems in the north-western parts of Western Australia and how the residents there are being taxed out of existence with the fringe benefits tax. The Australians who live in those areas are not being given the incentive to get out and develop Australia. The coalition is making an honest attempt to face up to Australia's problems, and that is the difference between us and the Hawke-Willis Labor Government.

The Government was absolutely mute a couple of weeks ago when we tried to get the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to debate the package in the House of Representatives, which they would not do. We have had some small debates here, to which some of my colleagues have already alluded. There have been some skirmishes with the Government occasionally saying, `We have found some holes in your goods and services tax package'. In the last few weeks since we came out with our goods and services tax package and our vision for Australia the Government has been absolutely obsessed with trying to knock holes in our package instead of saying what the Labor Government will do for the current million and a half unemployed and the 30 per cent youth unemployment figure.

Nothing is currently being done by this Government. It is an absolute indictment on the Hawke-Keating-Kerin-Willis-Beazley- Crean or whatever Government one would like to have at the moment. One could perhaps include anyone else who is throwing his or her hat into the ring. There is now an absolute blatant grab for power instead of care for the unemployed, including unemployed youth, in Australia.

The Prime Minister has claimed in various media in the last month or two that he would destroy the goods and services tax that we have come up with. He also said that he might even borrow from it. I believe that the Prime Minister has been trying to have a bob each way for too long. We have seen how successful that approach has been; it has been absolutely abysmal.

Our approach is up-front and, above all, it is equitable because it wipes the slate clean of seven taxes which have been added to and taken away from for years. Tonight we are again debating another change to the tax system and another little touching of the edges. This fiddling at the edges has increased inequities, unbalanced the economy and made our tax system one of the most cumbersome in the world. The latest increase in the fringe benefits tax from 47 cents in the dollar to 48.25 per cent is just another example of the Government's higgledy-piggledy approach to taxation.

This legislation will not stop any problems that the Government might think are presently occurring with the FBT. As our package suggests, under the existing tax arrangements there is an incentive for employees and employers to structure remuneration packages to take advantage of the gap between the fringe benefits tax rate of 48.25 per cent and the corporate tax rate of 39 per cent. Our decision to lower the fringe benefits tax rate and align it with the top corporate rate will significantly close any loopholes in it and will make it a much more fair and equitable way to handle fringe benefits.

For those in the business world, the tax package will mean more incentive to explore, employ and create work. The Liberal-National Party will abolish payroll tax. Fuel excises will go, tax on business inputs will be rebated and business will be back in the business of creating work and generating jobs. The depressed economy that we have at the moment—caused by former Treasurer Keating and the Labor Party—our growing unemployment queues, rising bankruptcies and soaring interest rates have all inhibited business in Australia for perhaps the last eight years, ever since the Labor Party came to government.

Earlier in this debate, Government senators suggested that the Opposition package meant that greed was good. I do not think they quite understand that productivity and incentive must be encouraged in industry. They have been missing in Australia for much too long. I think the latest balance of payments figures show that. The drop in housing approvals of 2.4 per cent means that Australia is another $1 billion plus in debt this month. It means, quite simply, that the Government has not stopped the rot and that it does not have control of the economy. While the Hawke Labor Government is able to engineer us into a recession, it is now finding the reverse is not so easy to achieve.
I will read a few of the quotable quotes of ex-Treasurer Keating. On 28 February 1990, he said he was trying to restructure the Australian economy so that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we emerge once again as a modern, sophisticated economy and not just as a backward place shipping a bit of wheat and wool.

Obviously that is what he thought of the rural communities. On 7 March last year at an Australian Financial Review luncheon, Mr Keating declared, `We won't let there be a recession'. On 22 March 1990 on radio 3LO, Mr Keating declared, `We won't let there be a recession'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish he were right.
—I wish he had been too, but he was not; he was far wrong. I will read the Senate a few more of his quotes. On 2 May, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: You either have a recession or you don't and the place doesn't look like we're having a recession.
On 29 November 1990—not that long ago, only just over a year ago—Mr Keating finally acknowledged the recession. He said:
It is a recession Australia had to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had to have it as long as he was Treasurer.

—That is right. But the beautiful—or horrible—part about it is that he continued, `It is entirely probable that the worst impact of this recession is in fact past'. He said that in November 1990. On 4 December 1990, speaking in Parliament about the recession, Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a condition in fact engineered by the Government.
I think that is what Senator Crichton-Browne was alluding to: the fact that the Treasurer did it himself, that it was engineered by him and the Government. On 6 December 1990, Mr Keating said:
No one person and no one factor determines the overall state of the economy. The important point is that I accept the responsibility for managing it.

That was a year ago. Glory be! That man stayed on as the Treasurer of this country until the middle of 1991. Now he is being pushed by people on the other side who are sitting on the front bench and by the little dagger-pullers who sit behind their Prime Minister—the Prime Minister of our country, whom young people look up to: it does not matter who he is, young people look up to the Prime Minister. They are the little—I had better watch the words I use; I would like to use a word that starts with `h', but I will not—people who sit there who should give total allegiance to the Prime Minister, but who do not give it to him. They are knifing him in the back and trying to make him bleed to death. They are suggesting that this man—the man who has engineered a recession—should come in and lead our country. I ask you!

PARA.TAB: One of the other Bills in this cognate debate is the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which will increase the applicable threshold under which people are exempt from the levy. Medicare is flagged as one of the Labor Government's great success stories in equity and justice. In the real world Medicare is a monumental failure, and an expensive one at that.

The levy raises far less than health services actually cost in this country, and I am quite sure that Senator Patterson will allude to this, as she is one of the Opposition's experts in health care. She knows a little more about it than some people on the other side do. The levy raises, as I said, far less than health services actually cost in this country, so it is just another contributor to our massive debt.

The levy has also assisted in generating the notion, which is becoming increasingly prevalent in our society, that Medicare is paid for by the government so it is there for the taking and for abuse. Few stop to think just where and how the Government gets its money. Medicare is not an efficient use of the public dollar, and we in the Liberal and National parties have been game enough to say so and to suggest that those who can afford to pay for their own health services ought to be encouraged to do so.

The health services in this country are in chaos and in poverty, and in large measure it is the fault of the Labor Government. Free health services ought to be available to those in genuine need of them, and that is simply not happening in Australia today. People are literally dying before they get to the head of the queue.

In contrast to the Government's position, our package proposes assistance to those on low incomes to encourage them to take private health cover. For those over 65 who earn less than $12,000 a year for single people or $14,500 for married couples, tax credits equivalent to the full cost of basic private health insurance will be provided. Not only will this save $1 billion in public health outlays; it will take the pressure off the existing overworked public health system. This is another example of bringing fairness back into the system.

Some seven years ago we had a balance of payments deficit of $7 billion. This year it is some $16 billion. When the Hawke Labor Government came to power the Government took $35 billion from the taxpayers of Australia in income tax revenue. Now it is estimated that some $67 billion is being taken out of the pockets of taxpayers in Australia. The doubling of tax revenue from the people who work in Australia is not a bad achievement! Sales tax, which we will abolish, has gone from approximately $4 billion to a $9.4 billion tax take by the Government. Foreign debt has gone from $51 billion to $124 billion. I could go on and on.

The Opposition proposes second reading amendments to these Bills. I fully support the amendments moved by Senator Short and Senator Herron respectively. I remind the Senate again of the words of Mr Keating and of what he has done to cause so much misery and hardship for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on just one of the Bills currently before the Senate, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. The purpose of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991 is to increase the threshold above which the Medicare levy is imposed on people who have a spouse or dependants. This threshold will increase from $19,045 to $19,674. Medicare is partly—and I emphasise `partly'—funded through a 1 1/4 per cent levy on taxable income.

PARA.TAB: Collections from the Medicare levy in 1990-91 totalled $2,480m which, it should be noted, is 9.3 per cent lower than the forecasts in the 1990-91 Budget. It has been estimated that in 1991-92 Medicare levy collections will total $2,580m. I cannot let this opportunity pass with the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill before the Senate without commenting on the inequities, the inefficiencies and the inadequacies of Medicare and the Hawke Government's health system. Firstly, this Government has told one big lie and misled the Australian public into believing that the Medicare levy pays for the health care of all Australians. Nothing is further from the truth. The Medicare levy covers only one-eighth of the real cost to the Federal, State and local governments of providing health services.

As I have said previously, the current Medicare levy is expected to raise only $2.58 billion this year, which is less than one-fifth of the expected $13.7 billion. Who pays the difference? It is obviously the Australian public via their taxes, via their private health insurance and via the gap. As the payment of the Medicare levy is not directly related to the use of health care services, there is no price disincentive to prevent overuse. Indeed, many have said that, since they have to pay the levy whether they use the system or not, they may as well use health care services as much as possible.

One of the biggest problems in the current system is the encouragement of bulkbilling. As the Opposition has said time and time again, the absence of a price signal only leads to overuse and overservicing. The Auditor-General, in Audit Report No. 32 of 1990-91, clearly indicates that there is an association between the overuse of medical services and the incidence of bulkbilling. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is notable that, generally speaking, the areas with the highest growth in outlays are those with a high proportion of direct billing.

The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services dismissed the comments of the Auditor-General, claiming that it had tried to mirror the results of the Audit Office but that it could not. The Department's conclusion was that there was obviously not a link between bulkbilling and the incidence of overuse and overservicing. However, this is not the only piece of evidence to which the Department and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) are turning a blind eye.

PARA.TAB: We should compare the evidence of the requests of bulkbilling GPs for pathology services per patient with that of non-bulkbilling GPs. We only have to look at the fact that New South Wales, the State with the highest incidence of bulkbilling, has the biggest usage of medical services. We never mind the evidence which shows that in Tasmania, where only 55 per cent of GP services are bulkbilled, the per capita cost is $191 whereas in New South Wales, with 75 per cent bulkbilling, the cost goes up to $250 per capita.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop being selective in your statistics. New South Wales has the highest number of doctors per head of population. That is the reason.

—If Senator Maguire wishes to participate in this debate, let him do so when he has the floor, otherwise I will continue. This Government refuses to acknowledge that there is any sort of problem and that bulkbilling is an ill in our health system. The coalition does not go around blind—
—They're all Liberal voters, anyway.

—I wonder if Noddy could just keep quiet for a moment. The coalition, unlike the Government, does not go around blind, refusing to admit there is a problem when there is clear evidence showing that there is. That is why, as part of our Fightback policy on health, we have announced that we will abolish bulkbilling, except for the four million pensioners, health care cardholders and the disabled. For the rest of the population, there will be a price signal that will act as a disincentive to overuse.

PARA.TAB: Not only have there been the widespread problems of overuse and overservicing, but also the hospital system is plagued by chronic waiting lists. The system is so bad that something like 700,000 pensioners hold some kind of private health insurance. They are frightened at the prospect of being subjected to the whims of Medicare and, in particular, the thought of being left without a hospital bed when they require elective surgery. Each of these pensioners is paying $200 or more for private cover.

So much for this Government whose Ministers today stand here talking about the poor when it has pensioners paying for private health insurance because they are too scared to take the risk of trusting this Government, which they now know never keeps its promises. The pensioners get no incentive, help or encouragement from this Government.

One of the biggest problems in our health system has been the dramatic reduction in the percentage of the population covered by private health insurance. In 1983, 70 per cent of the population had some private health cover. In 1990 that level had fallen to about 45 per cent of the population. The system has been grossly unfair to those who have chosen to take out private health insurance. It has pushed up private health insurance costs because insurance funds are left with a higher proportion of high risk cases as healthier, younger people drop their insurance. By discouraging the taking out of private health insurance, the Government has placed the burden of the nation's health costs directly onto the taxpayer. As funds have become increasingly scarce, the system has been starved of resources, resulting in rationing of services, running down and dilapidation of hospitals, excessive burdens on health professionals and the deterioration of the quality of services.

These are not the only problems in our health system. There has been a dramatic increase in the number of diagnostic services disproportionate to the increase in the population. The number of doctors has increased by 50 per cent in the last 10 years. The gaps between medical fees and Medicare funds have increased. The costs of the public health sector have increased by 163 per cent in the last 10 years and there is a maldistribution of health personnel. Our health system is in a mess.

The Government's present policy of so-called free health has led to a grossly inefficient and unstable health care delivery system that can no longer be sustained. All the Government does is tinker at the edges. It is straitjacketed by its narrow ideological thinking. What we need is a coalition government that will transform Medicare into a viable, stable system of quality health care. Our reforms will: retain and improve Medicare; guarantee all Australians access to high quality health care; reduce waiting lists in public hospitals; contain the costs of public health care; and restore the balance between the public and private health sectors by encouraging individuals to provide for their own health care through private insurance.

On 2 December, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Brian Howe, launched what was supposed to be the first part of a concerted attack on the Fightback program. However, what we got from Minister Howe was a whimper, particularly when it was discovered that he had his figures wrong. In two of his media releases Minister Howe had fundamental inaccuracies and was forced to admit that he was wrong. His media release said:

SPEECH.PARA: `Australians who are not card holders or pensioners would be forced, under an Opposition health policy, to take out private health insurance', the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Brian Howe, said today.

That was totally wrong. The coalition's policy is to require single income earners above $40,000 who do not take out private health insurance to pay a maximum levy of $400 per annum, and families with an income of over $50,000 will pay a maximum levy of $800 per annum. All those Australians earning less than $30,000 per annum will be given a tax credit to assist them in taking out private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that Australians will be better off under our health system. Under our policy, assistance will be provided to age pensioners to take out private health insurance; we will not have pensioners struggling to pay because they are scared of the system, as is the case under this Government. As I said, some 30 per cent of pensioners already take out private health insurance. Hundreds of thousands of families will be given an incentive under the coalition's Fightback package to take out private health insurance and will have access to the underutilised health services in the private sector.

One thing is certain from Minister Howe's media conference and that is that he has very little credibility. Firstly, the Minister presides over a health system that is chronically ill and he refuses to admit that there is a massive problem. Secondly, he fronts up at a media conference and he gets his facts wrong. Thirdly, he floats some suggestion that there is a $2 billion hole in the policy and provides little substantiation for this figure. Is it any wonder that nobody believes him?

The Treasurer, Mr Willis, also got his figures wrong in relation to our health policy. His calculations were based on a number of false assumptions. It would pay this Government to get its leadership straightened out—Senator Maguire nodded when I said that. It would also pay the Government to concentrate on the mess that it has got this health system into, rather than criticise the visionary policies in the coalition's Fightback package. I take the opportunity tonight to say that this Government needs to get its own house in order rather than try to tear down the house of the coalition. It has very little chance of doing that, because a house divided against itself will not stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to touch briefly on two matters tonight. The first is the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991 and the second is the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991. I find it rather quaint to have the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, telling us today that our change to the zone allowance of an increase of 25 per cent is but a mere pittance, as though a 25 per cent increase in the zone allowance—a figure set by this wretched, corrupt Government—is too low, and that a 25 per cent increase is not substantial enough. In other words, increasing the Government's level by 25 per cent is a pittance.

PARA.TAB: I am moved to observe, as I look at the Government's proposal for the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, that it is increasing the threshold from $19,045 to $19,674, which will have a zero effect on revenue this year and a mere pittance of an effect at $10m next year. What Senator Collins failed to observe was that not only will we increase the zone allowance by 25 per cent, but we will also have a thorough review to examine any anomalies which exist to ensure that people in the remote and isolated areas of Australia are not disadvantaged by their choice to be at the frontier of Australia's development and growth.

I move quickly to the fringe benefits tax. While I did not hear most of Senator Knowles's speech, I am certain that she would have touched upon the areas of consequence that affect mining areas, particularly of Western Australia. It is not without significance to note that, since the introduction of fringe benefits tax, there has not been one new town developed in Western Australia. Until that point, we had Dampier and we had Karratha; and we had expansions in Port Hedland, Kununurra, Tom Price, Newman, Paraburdoo and Pannawonica. Western Australia literally blossomed with new towns, new development, new infrastructure, new growth and new wealth.

I have to say that the fringe benefits tax was not the only barring feature—that all happened, of course, under a Liberal government. To my memory, not one of those towns was started under the Labor Government which followed the Liberal Government. Perhaps there are two notable reasons for that. The Liberal Party has also said in its package—which this Government says it is striving to destroy—that it will review anomalies in respect of that also, not the least being in mining areas, pastoral areas and tourist areas. There clearly are some anomalies.

Why is it now that the resource development areas of Western Australia are serviced by fly in, fly out staff and crew? It is because it is cheaper for mining companies and shareholders to put on an aircraft to fly these people in and have them live in basically spartan conditions, divorced from the reality of a natural living environment; fly them out again at the expiration of their period of work; and have a new crew fly back in again. Argyle is a good example, although the contemporary royal commission tells us that there are some added reasons—reasons, I might say, which pollute proper integrity—for there not being a town in Argyle.

Argyle was one of the first to adopt this practice. The lead-zinc mine at Cajuput, between Halls Creek and Fitzroy Crossing, is another company that chose to fly in and fly out its workers rather than create the infrastructure for a living vibrant community in the heart of the remote areas of Western Australia. Mines are taxed for providing necessary inevitable accommodation for their employees. A mine could hardly say to its employees, `You've got a job with us at Cajuput', which is X hundreds of kilometres from nowhere, `provided you can find your own accommodation'. How absolutely absurd! The same situation applies in respect of the pastoral industry. Do we expect a farmer to say, `You can work on my station, provided you can find your own accommodation'? Do we expect employers of people working in remote hotels or motels in Western Australia to say, `You have got a job as a housekeeper or a barmaid provided you can find your own accommodation'? What an absolute nonsense!

In effect, this tax is simply an add-on cost of labour to these operations with no material benefit to either the employee or the employer but a significant disincentive for the expansion, development, growth, prosperity and wealth of Australia. If there is something to be gained, it appears to me from my superficial observations and empirical evidence that the level of industrial disputation seems to have gone down in those mines that have fly-in, fly-out operations. I can only imagine that that is because the employees have other jobs. People spend a fortnight in Argyle and another fortnight at their little hobby farm. They are interested only in getting up there and earning cash. They then invest this money in developing the south-west or whatever other beautiful parts of Western Australia they want to live in. To that extent, I suspect that this arrangement has had some material benefits.

People living in Broome and working in Cajuput want to make sure that they are getting paid for lying on Cable Beach. If they were on strike they would not be paid. To that extent, I think this arrangement has had some sobering influence. But in real terms it has had a decimating effect on development in Western Australia. Many projects are at present in the pipeline. No doubt many more will be considered. However, magnificent towns which would form an intrinsic part of the fibre, culture and fabric of Western Australia will not be built because of the rigid, inflexible and artificial way in which this fringe benefits tax is imposed. We propose to conduct a proper review of any anomalies that we find, notwithstanding this Government saying that it will do all it can to ensure that we do not.

I move to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991. If ever there was an area of government service that has been plunged into absolute chaos and failure, it is the health system of Australia. I well remember Mr Hayden's promise to provide cheap or free quality health readily to all Australians. He was rigidly driven by an ideological belief—but also presumably altruism—of some egalitarian notion without understanding the implications of such a system. The health services and the health delivery system in Australia tragically have never been worse. The fact is that the public hospital systems in the States and the Territories—and that is all I have time to speak about tonight—are in absolute chaos.

Recently I went to a doctor in the ACT who told me that he had had a visit from another athletic young man in this town, who had discovered that his times around the lake had deteriorated somewhat. He was feeling run down, so he went for a check-up. On careful examination, the doctor found that this man had the most virile form of stomach cancer there is. The recovery rate, even after operations, is about 25 per cent.

Of course, the doctor promptly got on the telephone to book this man in for an operation. This is in Canberra, with all its wonderful hospitals—the Calvary Hospital, the Royal Canberra Hospital and the Woden Valley Hospital. The doctor was told it would be three weeks before this man could have an operation. He could have saved himself a telephone call and rung the undertaker instead. This man was going to die because the system could not find him one rotten, stinking bed. That is in an affluent city such as Canberra. We are supposed to believe that we have a cheap system, a quality system which is readily available to all people, yet no hospital could provide this young man with a bed to save his life. Tragically, that is not a bad example; that is not an aberration; that is not an exception. That is the rule.

We have this system, which Senator Patterson touched upon, that has driven up the number of visits to doctors and the number of people seeking beds, and there is no empiric or classic evidence that the quality of health in Australia has improved as a result of having this system. Australians are hospitalised and visit their doctors at a greater level than people in almost any other country in the OECD. In Australia the rate of hospital admissions is 22.6 per cent. In the UK, another country with a free system, it is 15.8 per cent. We seem to learn from these other systems. The USA rate is 14.7 per cent and in the Netherlands, which I think charges people, it is 11 per cent. The tragedy is that as the number of these visits, the number of people going into hospital and the number of people on waiting lists go up, the number of hospital beds available goes down.

In my own State of Western Australia alone, between 1988 and 1990 there was an increase of 34 per cent in the number of people on the waiting list. There are presently 10,000 people, out of a population of a little more than one million, on the waiting list—just waiting to go into hospital to have an operation to get well. Two thousand of them have been on the waiting list for 12 months or more. That is with this fabulous, mystical system given to us by this Government, under which health care is but a phone call away for anybody.

There are about 70,000 people on public waiting lists throughout Australia. No doubt Senator McMullan will say, `That is elective surgery—a luxury. Most of those people are probably people who are feeling good now and want to feel super-good. There is a difference between terribly unwell people and people who just want to feel normal'. The definition of `elective surgery' now includes operations to remove cataracts and surgery such as hip replacements, throat operations, nose operations, ear operations and heart bypasses—the sort of stuff that keeps people alive. It is `elective' not for the person but for the system, as to whether a person lives or dies and whether a person has quality of life.

What about knee operations or back operations—all those things that make a person feel more human? That is elective; that is optional; that is the top-of-the-range stuff, above and beyond normal health care in Australia. In June 1986 the total number of beds in public hospitals was 69,739. In June 1990 that number had fallen to 63,574. That was not simply because Australians were feeling really well. That was not because this country is full of Lazaruses who all got up and went home. That was simply because bed numbers were contracting because State governments could not afford to service them.

There are all sorts of examples of that. My own mother died of cancer recently. In her ward alone half of the beds were closed. She was having chemotherapy like everybody else in the ward. When people have chemotherapy, their blood count is down to billyo and they only have to have a visitor cough on them and they promptly die. What happened was that the person with the lowest blood count got a single bed ward. The person with the next lowest went into a double ward. People with the next lowest blood count went into a four-bed ward. It was Russian roulette as to whether they got a bed in a single ward that provided them with an opportunity to be insulated from the sort of infection which is inevitable through contact with other people in those circumstances.

In 1986 there were 734 public hospitals. In 1990 there were 702—again, driven not by efficiencies, not by health, but simply by funding. The Royal Perth Hospital in Western Australia has had funding cuts and, in fact, has suspended elective surgery on every fourth Friday because of cuts to its budget. It does not mean that on every fourth Friday nobody needs an operation. It does not mean that on every fourth Friday the whole of metropolitan Perth is well. It simply means that operations are suspended because the hospital cannot afford them.

We recently had a case where a lady was admitted, prepped, shaved and anaesthetised ready for the operation and woke up to find herself ready to be dressed and sent home because hospital staff were not available. She was a 68-year-old woman, if I remember correctly. She had been prepped for the operation and had gone through the trauma and anxiety that we all do, never mind at that age, in readiness for this relatively serious operation, only to discover that it had been called off—I was going to say at the death knock, but I should say at the last minute. The tragedy is that there are 7,000 to 8,000 empty beds in private hospitals now.

It is not as though we do not have the infrastructure; it is not as though we do not have the facilities. The trouble is that we do not have the common sense; and we do not have a sensible, balanced, proper, humane approach to health care problems in Australia.
