In Tasmania, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia between 1987 and 1990, 1,600 beds were closed because the hospitals simply could not afford to fund them.

As I say, it is not because Australians are getting any healthier. Every Australian visits a doctor approximately eight times a year. This compares with an average of 4.5 visits annually in the United Kingdom and 3.5 visits in the Netherlands. Yet we have a system which cannot deliver us proper health care. As Senator Patterson said, we have this absurd system—Senator McMullan could not honestly look me in the eye and say that we do not—which causes both overuse and overservicing.

When the Government has the courage to put an up-front fee—not a real figure but a figure just to introduce a modicum of price sensitivity, a figure just to introduce the notion of cost—its ideologically hell-bent members, with their continuing obsession for free medicine, knock it on the head. It is now being used as an artificial excuse, as the bridge across which to march, to vote for Mr Keating. I do not have the exact figure but, of course, the cost of health services in Australia is about $26 billion. But we are given this absurd indication that the Medicare levy in some way pays that. Of course, it does not; it pays a very modest part of that. I conclude by saying that I get no satisfaction out of any of the legislation that is presently before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone listening to the debate on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill and associated Bills could be excused for not realising that we are actually dealing with some fairly important pieces of taxation legislation, none of which I heard referred to in the debate this evening. The debate on the earlier occasion did, and I will deal with some of the points raised later. I want to make clear that the important parts of this tax package relate to elements of the package announced in the March industry statement, and this is a further stage in the implementation of the package. We dealt with the sales tax legislation last week. We have a further set of measures concerning depreciation which will be introduced into the House of Representatives tomorrow. We also have this package which deals with some important parts of the package: for example, retention and extension of the research and development concession for industry and deductability of environmental impact statement expenditure, et cetera. Some of the major changes that were announced in the March statement are being implemented on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: There is a large number of other changes, which, as part of the macro tax system, are minor changes, although in each instance they are important to the individuals affected by them. There is also the implementation of some Budget changes to do with mining and prospecting and with valueless shares, and there are associated Bills which essentially are of a minor machinery nature. During this debate we had a couple of major excursions into the Medicare area. I do not want to take up a lot of time at 10 minutes past 10 to pursue all those tangents. There has been much sound, fury and concern about overuse and overservicing. Everyone always wishes to have a better health service and more services available, although I have to say that in the recent experience of my own family the service has been first class in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have private insurance?

—No, and nor does the person I am referring to; it was not I but a very close relative of mine. However, at this stage I do not want to pursue the points that were raised in debate, because there will be plenty of debates on Medicare on more appropriate occasions both here and elsewhere, and that will be the appropriate time for that to occur. I simply say that the evidence makes it very clear that, by international standards or by Australian traditional standards, Medicare has been very successful in its cost containment. Whatever else honourable senators opposite may say about it and all these allegations about the cost of Medicare and the cost of health care in Australia, as a percentage of GDP the costs of health provision in Australia are and remain remarkably low and have been remarkably stable.
—Eight per cent of GDP.

—Yes, that is very low by any standard. Compared with the examples which those opposite have quoted and compared with the system that the Opposition is proposing, such as the United States system, it is much cheaper in Australia. There are very few examples, and none with the sort of service that the Opposition is advocating, which can come close to that level.

PARA.TAB: That really takes us out at a bit of a tangent on this legislation. I want to deal with some of the substance of what honourable senators raised in the time I have available; I do not want to abuse the privilege of the Senate's giving me some time to sum up. Much of what Senator Watson raised will be covered in the committee stage, so I will not duplicate now what we will deal with then. Many of his concerns were also covered in the earlier Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearing on this legislative package, although I will refer to some things which I undertook to do there with regard to tabling. I will come to that later during this summing up but otherwise I will not go over the matters covered in that hearing and which are recorded in Hansard.

However, some extra matters were raised during this second reading debate, mainly by Senator Watson, although I wish to refer to a couple of matters raised by other honourable senators. Senator Watson raised a concern about the quarantining of the Attwood matter. I reiterate my previous indication that the Government's intention is that the amendment be quarantined to offshore oil and gas rig workers. That remains our intention.

We have had much discussion and some correspondence about camp allowances and the application of fringe benefits tax. I do not want to take too long with this matter because it can be a very complicated debate. The fringe benefits tax law provides that an allowance, including a camp allowance, will be a living away from home allowance fringe benefit if it is concluded that the allowance is paid to compensate an employee for additional expenses incurred or other additional disadvantages to which the employee is subject because the employee is required to live away from home in order to perform duties of employment. If the allowance is not paid for these purposes it will be subject to income tax in the hands of the employee. That covers most of the points raised in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that quarantining?
—That is quite different from what is happening with regard to Attwood. That is a separate situation.
—They are still cash payments.

—There is nothing new about the application of fringe benefits tax to cash payments. Cash payments made under an award of that sort have always been subject to fringe benefits rather than income tax. There has been no extension of the policy in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson also raised a concern about the auditing of the ATO's situation with regard to fringe benefits tax itself. The Australian National Audit Office in particular ensures that the Taxation Office meets its obligations and the Department of Finance also monitors that matter because its requirements have to be satisfied.

There was also some debate about the treatment of taxi fares for employees who are required to work after normal working hours. Where such a benefit is provided on a very occasional basis the minor benefits exemption would apply. It would not apply to regular transport provided to shift workers or others who regularly work late hours. Those guidelines which apply to all employers apply to the Taxation Office as well.

In the course of the debate at the Finance and Public Administration Committee hearing Senator Watson asked me to table two taxation rulings which are relevant to this general area of debate in this Bill. Without going to them in detail, I table taxation rulings Nos IT 2569 and 2570 for the information of honourable senators. There will be some other matters covered by Government amendments which I will come to in the committee stage.

Senator Panizza raised a matter to which I wish to reply. He said that in the past we have reviewed annually the provisional tax uplift factor and asked why it was not in the Bill on this occasion. The situation is simply that last year we changed the law to provide that the factor be set at 10 per cent in the legislation, unless the Parliament otherwise provides. It was not set for a specific time last year and therefore it has a continuing effect. That is why it is not here, as it is no longer required to be an annual event.

Senator Kernot raised a question with regard to imputation credits and sought confirmation that the Bill corrects a deficiency in the existing law. I can confirm that the amendments in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) will correct the deficiency she referred to and result in a situation where there will be no double counting of credits, as can occur under the existing law.

I think that in some senses that does not do credit to all the points that honourable senators have raised but, in terms of responding to new matter, I think it does. We could wander off into a fairly long debate about the Fightback package. There has already been one go at that today; I do not intend to have a lengthy debate again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a go.

—Well, if it were not a quarter past 10 it would be delightful. But I do want to deal with two aspects of the Fightback package that relate specifically to the two amendments. When I spoke earlier today, I said that it amounted to—I used more colourful language, but let me be more moderate here—deliberately misleading the Senate to claim that the Fightback package would create two million jobs, because the two million jobs figure in the document is not based on, and cannot be remotely considered to be based on, the policy provisions in that package. The high road scenario in the Access Economics analysis is not an analysis of the Fightback package and does not pretend to be. Nobody can honestly claim that it is, because the tax package does not even include a goods and services tax. It is an assessment of an interesting scenario. It may or may not be a correct assessment, but that is a totally different debate.

PARA.TAB: To come in here and say that the Fightback package will create two million jobs because a completely different scenario, which happens by chance to be reported in the same document, would create two million jobs amounts to deliberately misleading the Senate. To find it in writing in this amendment is scandalous. It is deliberately misleading. Certainly the mover of this amendment, Senator Herron, must have known that the document that refers to the two million jobs bears no relationship to the policy that is being advocated, and that the policy that is being advocated is back to the old formula of dealing with unemployment by putting people out of work, just as it deals with inflation by putting up prices and deals with the living standards of Australian workers by cutting real wages. That is what this package does. It is a fairly conventional conservative formula dressed up in tinsel.

The only other point I want to make relates to the further amendment that is being proposed, I understand, by Senator MacGibbon, expressing concern that the Government may be going to take further measures. We get the situation where, if the Government does not propose to change policy, there is concern that it is just the same old package; if we do propose new policies, there are allegations that somehow or other this is a very bad thing and there should not be any such changes. The fact is that the Australian people will get plenty of opportunity to debate the relative merits of the package. I do not intend at 10.20 this evening to take it any further than those responses. With regard to the more outrageous of the criticisms that were run and that are dotted through the amendments, we had a debate this afternoon which I thought was a bit of a waste of time, so I certainly do not intend to duplicate it here. The second readings are being supported by all honourable senators, and I thank them for that support. I will debate the detail in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 31, page 17, proposed subsection 26 AJ(11), definition of "return", line 32, after "profit", insert ", but does not include betting, lottery, gambling or game winnings unless those winnings are provided as a substitute for income that would otherwise have been derived as a result of the investment".

TAB.EMPHASIS: Deduction of allowable environmental impact expenditure

PARA.TAB: "`82BB. (1) Subject to this Subdivision, if a taxpayer incurs allowable environmental impact expenditure during a year of income (in this section called the "current year of income") in connection with an income-producing project of the taxpayer, then:

TAB.TAB: (a)if a decision is made before the end of the current year of income to abandon the project—100% of the expenditure is an allowable deduction for the current year of income; or
(b)if paragraph (a) does not apply and the project ends before the end of the current year of income—the expenditure is an allowable deduction for the current year of income; or
(c)if it is not practicable to readily estimate, as at the end of the current year of income, the time when the project will end—33 1/3% of the expenditure is an allowable deduction for:
(i)the current year of income; and
(ii)each of the 2 subsequent years of income; or
(d)if:
(i)none of the above paragraphs apply; and

(ii)it is practicable to readily estimate, as at the end of the current year of income, the year of income (in this paragraph called the "final year of income") in which the end of the project will occur; and
(iii)the final year of income is one of the 3 years of income subsequent to the current year of income;
equal parts of the expenditure are respectively allowable deductions for:
(iv)the current year of income; and
(v)the final year of income; and
(vi)the second year of income (if any); or
(e)if:

(ii)it is practicable to readily estimate, as at the end of the current year of income, the year of income (in this paragraph called the "final year of income") in which the end of the project will occur; and

SPEECH.PARA: In moving those amendments, I acknowledge the Government's action in moving and accepting in principle three amendments to the original legislation. Under the first amendment, the taxpayer is able to write off a loss against current or future capital gains in circumstances where the company is in liquidation. I thank the Government for the recognition of the benefit that will give to taxpayers. I also acknowledge the Government's second amendment to the original legislation, which provides a vehicle whereby after 120 days a taxpayer can, in circumstances where an objection is in dispute with the Australian Taxation Office, have that objection deemed to be resolved in the negative. That gives the taxpayer the option of going directly to court or the AAT. Following the third amendment, in the committee stage of the legislation many weeks ago the coalition drew attention to the consequence of the withdrawal of Part V, that is, the potential of the taxpayer being denied the dual option of going to the AD(JR) and using the tax mechanism in the event of certain appeals.

PARA.TAB: We thank the Government for these three amendments. We believe that they make a substantial improvement to the legislation. There are two other amendments which we are presently dealing with in the committee stage of debate. We acknowledge some recognition by the Government of environmental impact statement costs. We believe that the regime as presented before this Parliament is inadequate.

The Opposition is therefore proposing—and we seek the support of the Democrats—that environmental impact expenses be deductible in the following circumstances: where the project proceeds, expenditure is to be written off over three years; where the project does not proceed, the expenditure is to be deductible outright. We think it is only just and equitable that where the project does not proceed expenditure can be written off forthwith, particularly as, in those circumstances, no asset has been created.

If the Government is really serious about its commitment to environmental issues it should accept the amendment that we are proposing. In most new projects nowadays, the law, Federal, State or local, requires an environmental impact study to be undertaken. Therefore expenditure can be regarded as a necessary and legitimate expense of operating.

Comments from industry on the Government's planned 10-year write-off note that this is out of line with the relevant accounting standards which would require full write-off in the year of expenditure. Even the Opposition acknowledges that it would like to go along the path of outright deduction. We do state that in some circumstances an asset has been created and therefore a three-year regime is applicable.

I thank Senator Kernot for giving me prior knowledge that the Democrats intend to accept this Opposition amendment. This certainly adds credibility to the Democrats' concerns for the environment of this world. It is a legitimate cost and one which should be acknowledged in a much firmer and more meaningful way than what the Government is proposing by way of a 10-year write-off.

If the Government were to accept the coalition amendments enabling a write-off of expenditure over three years it would come at the forefront of tax sensitivity to business environmental expenditures. We are pressing for this amendment to be accepted. It was raised at the committee stage. It was a 12 March proposal. It was therefore not a Budget measure that we were tampering with in its true sense. We have to send certain signals to the Government that it does not raise kites and does not follow up immediately. We have some concerns about the techniques that have been used. There is also an inconsistency in the Government's approach to a recognition of the write-off of certain expenses, for example, exploration expenses in the mining industry.
Progress reported.

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said that my second amendment involves a revised deductibility regime for environmental impact expenditure. I will now refer to my first amendment.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition is concerned about the discrimination against the banking system. We seek to rectify that with our first amendment. Honourable senators will be aware that the amendments now before the Committee are in slightly different terms from those of the original amendment. We have noted the observations of the Australian Taxation Office and the Government about the original amendment. We believe that the first amendment to clause 31, page 17, which amends the definition of `return', clarifies the position and rectifies an earlier problem. We therefore seek the support of the Government and the Australian Democrats in removing this unfortunate distinction, which would tend to work against the banking system. It is an unintentional drafting error. I believe that this amendment seeks to clarify that position so as not to disadvantage the banking sector vis-a-vis all other sectors in the community.

To put it in a nutshell, I will give a simple example. If the Commonwealth Bank wishes to encourage new account holders by offering a trip to Fiji, that can be deemed to be part of the return under the original legislation. We believe that is somewhat unfair compared with the example of a cordial manufacturer who may offer a trip to Fiji if a person buys cordials by the crate. If a person is successful, the prize or the lottery in such a circumstance is not related to the return on the investment. We fully support the notion that if a prize, game, lottery or something like that is given in addition to, or as part of, the inducement for the return then it is an acceptable provision that that be part of that income earning stream.

Therefore, I wish to commend the two amendments which I believe are justifiable as an improvement to the legislation. I thank the Government for its three earlier amendments to the original legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the Opposition's second amendment first. I think it is true that an accelerated rate of deduction for environmental impact statements will definitely reduce the cost of such statements to the businesses concerned. I guess that that may have the long term effect of improving the attitude of business to the whole environmental impact statement process. I suppose we could say that it might even improve the quality of some of the environmental impact statements themselves. I can see the arguments that Senator Watson is advancing.

PARA.TAB: My considerations also involve the matter of the cost of the implementation of this amendment. That does concern me. My first sentiments were to say, `I think we could point to a lot of other places where the Government ought to be encouraged to spend similar amounts of money'. For example, last week we heard the CSIRO predicting that in 20 years some western suburbs of Sydney will be virtually uninhabitable because of the effects of smog. We have the catastrophe of the toxic blue-green algae in our waterways. We could argue that here is a sum of money which could be set aside by the Government for quite important environmental projects. However, I indicate that, on balance, I think this is a positive move to change the attitude of business and to lead to an improvement in the environmental impact statement process in the long term.

I am aware that the first amendment is a revision of the Opposition's first version and I am aware that the Government said the first version was not necessary. I am now waiting to hear the Minister's explanation as to whether this revised version is necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to confirm two things, but the first point has been confirmed by the subsequent distribution of a document. I was a bit confused about which version of his amendment Senator Watson was proceeding with. I now have that documentation.

PARA.TAB: The second point is this: given we are dealing with the Bill as a whole, would it be appropriate for me both to move the Government amendments and to speak to Senator Watson's amendment at the same time; or should we deal with them separately?

TALK.START.PARA: —We will need to dispose of Senator Watson's amendment.
—That is what I first assumed and then I thought we might speed it up even more. My enthusiasm to get home is getting ahead of my procedural assessment.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with Senator Watson's two amendments. Firstly, I thank him for his cooperation in allowing that procedural matter to be handled in that way. We could not have done it without his cooperation, and I thank him for that.

With regard to the amendment to the definition of `return' to deal with investment related lottery winnings, we have discussed this before because, to some extent, it came up during the hearings of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I understand that Senator Watson is concerned that in some way or another we are discriminating against banking or perhaps some more broadly defined financial sector. Let me make it clear, first of all, that we do not think there is a perception of discrimination against the banking fraternity. The situation will be the same for anybody offering similar inducements.

Our concern with this amendment is in two parts. One is that the test as proposed by Senator Watson's revised form of amendment may well exclude all investment related lottery winnings from the tax net, because investment related lotteries are provided to make particular investments more attractive when compared with other investments. It is just another form of competitive attraction of funds in the marketplace.

The further proposed amendment appears to require that the lottery chance be chosen by the investor as an alternative to more income under the same investment. The real choice for investors is between investments offering a lottery chance and investments offering other advantages—perhaps a slightly higher interest rate but with no chance of winning the prize—and not between the particular advantages that might otherwise be available under the same investment.

The Bill asks whether the chance is provided in respect of an investment and ensures that winnings will be taxable only if they relate to an investment. That ensures that the winning chance is provided as part of the return on the investment. That is already required in the way the Bill is drafted, so I do not think the proposed amendment is either necessary or appropriate. I think Senator Watson is finding a mischief that is not there and then going to great lengths to try to avoid that problem. My advice is that that is not necessary and not appropriate. I will leave it at that point.

Therefore, we are trying to talk about the taxation of prizes that will be assessable under the provision where there is a chance giving rise to a prize being provided in respect of an investment. I do not think we need go any further. I think that covers the problem and the concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was Senator Watson's analogy accurate?

—Because of the procedural matters that were being debated here I did not hear every detail of Senator Watson's point but, as I heard it, the principle was fundamentally the same as that which he raised at the hearings of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. In a sense, no, it is not relevant to the problem we are confronting. We are not trying here to confront the circumstance where someone is offering an inducement in the normal course, but where, instead of higher interest rates, part of the return on an investment is the potential to win a prize. It is a disguised form of income.

PARA.TAB: Any prize of that sort, whether it is offered by a bank, a finance company or a company floating shares and providing an inducement in that manner or a measurable potential for greater return to attract one to take out its shares, would similarly be treated. It would not apply only to banks. Everything that is dealt with relating to a return on an investment would be similarly treated.

It is a particular issue with which we are trying to deal, and I do not think that the amendment is necessary. We will all have to learn by the experience brought about by implementation of the legislation, because obviously we now are having a disagreement on the meaning of the words. But that which I have stated is the clear understanding and intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole purpose of the committee debate is to remove the sort of uncertainty that Senator McMullan has been alluding to. I beg to differ with the explanation he has offered. It would be unfortunate if taxpayers were put in the unenviable position of having to learn the implications of the legislation by going through what could be a bad experience.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) mentioned that the principle is essentially the same as that which I raised at the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The principle is, indeed, exactly the same. But I would submit that the argument presented in the chamber tonight was essentially the logical argument in relation to amendment No. 1 that the Parliamentary Secretary presented to that Standing Committee on Friday, 15 November 1991.

I mentioned during my speech tonight that the Opposition took cognisance of the matters that were raised by the Government and by the Australian Taxation Office and, for that reason, we revised the original amendment, and I now read it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . definition of `return'. . .
And essentially we are interested in this concept of a return on an investment; but we are adding the words:
. . . but does not include betting, lottery, gambling or game winnings unless those winnings are provided as a substitute—
and they are the operative words, `as a substitute'—
for income that would otherwise have been derived as a result of the investment'.

That clarifies it and puts it beyond reasonable doubt, and people do not necessarily have to find the implications of the legislation through a bad experience. I believe it is incumbent on this chamber to get it right the first time, rather than go through this tortuous process, and remove any shadow of doubt. My independent advisers tell me that this is the way to go, and we will certainly press the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet responded to the environmental impact expenditure amendment; I am dealing only with this part of the Bill first. There are two aspects to our concern. Firstly, there is the general concern I made known in November and which I reiterated today; but, secondly, there is an extra element that explicitly relates to the form of words of the amendment before us now, which is that the test, as proposed, could well—and my advice is that it would be likely to—exclude all investment related lottery winnings.

PARA.TAB: If we start pursuing hypothetical examples, we may debate the example instead of the principle. But let me give a situation where company A is offering a 10 per cent return on investment and company B is offering a 10 per cent return and a one in 10,000 chance of winning $1m. As to the measurable extra benefit, the one in 10,000 chance of winning $1m, it appears, and the implications of the words are, that that is not covered by Senator Watson's amendment—yet that is quite clearly a return on that investment. The person is getting X per cent plus an opportunity to win. The Government is concerned that that is a return and it ought to be taxable, but that it would not be taxable under the amendment. That is our concern. The amendment is neither appropriate nor necessary.

I would like to take this opportunity, so we do not all have to get up too often, also to talk about the environmental impact expenditures aspect. I am concerned that a problem I was not aware of may arise if this amendment is accepted. As well, there might be significant revenue implications. I am not only concerned about that; I am also concerned that there is a question of principle as well. I think it is appropriate—and it might be fair criticism of the Government to say that this is overdue—that we should recognise environmental impact expenditures for tax purposes. In the course of the second reading debate a couple of people made a bit of a point that perhaps we should have done this earlier. I think there is a case for saying that. We recognised it in March and we are implementing it here.

It is one thing to say, `We are going to recognise environmental impact expenditure for tax purposes over the proposed life of the project to which the expenditure relates'. That is a perfectly proper principle and there is no need to pursue it further; it is not argued between us here. As far as I know, everyone in the Senate agrees with that principle. But it is entirely different to say, `But now we are going to use the tax system to subsidise these activities'. I have to say that there are circumstances under the Income Tax Assessment Act and other tax Acts where the tax system is used to subsidise certain activities. Sometimes that is appropriate. It is not something that ought to be done lightly but I do not say it should never be done.

It seems extraordinary that we are here contemplating a subsidy for environmental impact expenditures. We have two different situations. We have a situation where people are required to undertake this action. So it is a fair argument to say, `If the law requires them to do it, if they cannot proceed with the project unless they do this, it is an expense necessarily incurred in undertaking the project and that ought to be recognised by the tax Act'. That is one valid principle, which is why this is in the legislation. But it is entirely different to say, `We are going to subsidise you to do this, which the law requires you to do anyway'. That is quite different from saying, `There are some discretionary environmental expenditures which the tax system might encourage you to undertake'.

If I can divert from income tax for a moment for the purpose of giving an example: some indirect subsidies are given through the sales tax legislation. If we want to encourage people to use recycled paper, if we want to encourage them to use solar heaters, we give some sales tax incentive. People can make a choice and we want to use in some way the tax system to influence their decision.

But that is not the situation we have before us today. We have a situation where the proposal would substantially subsidise environmental expenditures by giving considerable timing advantages in every case where the project to which the expenditure relates has a life longer than three years—which is almost every one. It seems to me entirely inappropriate and, in fact, quite puzzling that we are proposing to take that course of action. I want to counsel caution before we go down that road.

The same principle applies with regard to the debate about immediate write-off. The Bill writes off environmental impact expenditure for a project that is abandoned over 10 years—what is called the default write-off period. This avoids problems with the artificial abandonment of projects and perhaps their subsequent reinstatement, and limits the potential for supposed environmental expenditure that has a different character because the write-off is not immediate.

Senator Watson's proposal—and I am sure it is not his intention—seems to us to carry significant risk of abuse and would be likely to complicate the administration of the deduction by requiring reconsideration of particular cases as and when abandonment of the project is said to occur. I think there are two fundamental problems. It is inappropriate that we should be going down that road, and I urge the Opposition and the Democrats to reconsider that particular amendment. We are taking a significant step forward with the recognition of environmental impact expenditure and I do not believe we should go the next step, to the subsidy of that expenditure. It is not a subsidy that is going to encourage people to take any more environmentally conscious action because it is something that they are required to do. It is appropriate that we recognise it; it is inappropriate that we subsidise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for his response, but I ask the question: how can we hope to get this country going if there is not proper recognition of appropriate expenditure on investment? An environmental impact study is not a subsidy. It is somewhat similar to exploration; it is preparatory to the main work being carried out. In this very legislation before us tonight we have an acknowledgment of an extension of the deductibility regime in relation to preparatory exploration expenditure. Environmental impact statements are obligatory in most cases, or are certainly desirable, preparatory to undertaking the main investment. It is certainly not a subsidy. We must reject that notion out of hand.

PARA.TAB: I believe the argument that has been presented, with due respect to Senator McMullan, runs counter to the proposals that have been put by his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by his colleague Senator Button, both of whom are seeking to establish an income tax regime that will remove impediments so that Australian companies will not be at a disadvantage compared with other companies operating in the international environment. What we must do in this country is ensure that our tax regime matches the world's best. We are seeking by these amendments to match the world's best. Anything less—talk of a subsidy, talk of abuse of the system—I think falls short of that essential criterion; that is, lifting this country out of its stagnation, out of its recession and out of its depression.

One way of doing that is to provide a proper recognition for the investment expenditures, particularly the long-term expenditures such as occur in the mining industry or in manufacturing. These are the two principal industries that would benefit from the amendments that have been proposed by the Opposition and have been, thankfully, supported by the Australian Democrats. Companies are not going to spend valuable dollars—and it often runs into millions of dollars—on environmental impact statements and then abuse that system. I fail to see that argument. It is true that it is a debating point, but this issue is more than a debate in this chamber. This is about real life situations and about getting investment going in this country. I think we have to look at this situation a little more seriously and look at the impact that the Government's proposal would have on industry.

The Opposition is providing the opportunity, the enlightened way, to ease that burden and reduce the time pressures. At times of fairly high interest rates, high costs and unsatisfactory returns, we must improve the cost competitiveness of Australian business. This measure, proposed by the Opposition and now supported by the Democrats, provides that opportunity. Given the lateness of the hour, I ask the Government to accede to the Opposition's request.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amendments be agreed to. Is it the wish of the Committee that the two amendments be taken together by way of vote, or dealt with separately?
—Separately.
—The question is that amendment No. 1, as moved by the Opposition, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Opposition amendment No. 2 be agreed to.

—I wish to make a 30-second statement on that. Obviously, given that it is a fairly significant event when a tax Bill is amended in a way that affects the revenue, we would normally want to call a division on the amendment, but it is late and we will not. I want to put on the record that that is what we would normally have done; we will not on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 112, page 68, after proposed section 14ZY insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Person may require Commissioner to make an objection decision

PARA.TAB: "`14ZYA.(1) This section applies if the taxation objection has been lodged with the Commissioner within the 60 days and the Commissioner has not made an objection decision by whichever is the later of the following times:
(a) the end of the period (in this section called the "original 60-day period") of 60 days after whichever is the later of the following days:

TAB.TAB: (i)the day on which the taxation objection is lodged with the Commissioner;
(ii)if the Commissioner decides under section 14ZX to agree to a request in relation to the taxation objection—the day on which the decision is made;

PARA.TAB: (b) if the Commissioner, by written notice served on the person within the original 60-day period, requires the person to give information relating to the taxation objection—the end of the period of 60 days after the Commissioner receives that information.
`(2) The person may give the Commissioner a written notice requiring the Commissioner to make an objection decision.

`(3) If the Commissioner has not made an objection decision by the end of the period of 60 days after being given the notice, then, at the end of that period, the Commissioner is taken to have made a decision under subsection 14ZY(l) to disallow the taxation objection.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Schedule 4, clause 113, page 88, amendment of Schedule 1 to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, at the end of proposed paragraph (ga), add "disallowing objections to assessments or calculations of tax, charge or duty".

These amendments propose two alterations to part 7 of the Bill. The first of these amendments introduces a time limit for the determination of taxation objections by the Commissioner of Taxation. The other amendment proposes a minor change to schedule 1 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to ensure the continuation of existing rights to judicial review in respect of objection decisions. The amendments are not expected to have any impact on the revenue.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment inserts proposed new section 14ZYA in division 3 of part IVC of the Taxation Administration Act. Honourable senators will be aware that at the hearing of the Finance and Public Administration Committee on this Bill Senator Watson proposed an amendment which would have allowed a taxpayer 60 days after objecting against an assessment to give notice to the Commissioner requiring the Commissioner to treat the objection as being disallowed.

While the Government does not have any difficulty with putting time constraints on the objection process, we consider that it would be more appropriate for the taxpayer to be required to put the Commissioner on notice that he is to determine the objection within a further specific time. The proposed new section specifies 60 days. At the expiry of this further 60-day period, the objection, if undetermined, will, as proposed by Senator Watson, be deemed to have been disallowed. This section will operate so that a person can give notice to the Commissioner 60 days after objecting or, if the Commissioner has asked for additional information in relation to the objection, 60 days after he has received that information.

The amendment will provide taxpayers with a degree of control over the objection process. At the same time, deemed disallowance of an objection will not change taxpayers' rights. The time limit and deemed disallowance mechanism will operate only where a person chooses to implement it by giving notice and the deemed objection decision will be subject to review in the same way as any other objection decision.

The Commissioner has confirmed that this amendment will not affect the operation of the guidelines set out in income tax rulings IT-2569 and IT-2570 in connection with extensions of time for payment and the remission of additional tax for late payment.

Schedule 4 of the Bill contains amendments of certain Acts that are affected by the Bill's consolidation of objection, review and appeal provisions in the Taxation Administration Act. One of these amendments is to include a new paragraph (ga) in schedule 1 of the AD(JR) Act. This amendment was simply intended to ensure that decisions on taxation amendments that are currently outside the scope of judicial review under the AD(JR) Act would remain that way. However, at the Senate Committee hearing it was pointed out that the new paragraph may remove an existing right to review under that Act. To remove any doubt, the amendment being circulated modifies the proposed paragraph (ga) to ensure that existing rights are preserved.

A number of technical matters were raised at the Committee hearing in relation to this part of the Bill. While amendments are not necessary, I should clarify two matters for the benefit of honourable senators. The first is that in the definition of `appealable objection decision' in proposed new section 14ZQ and in proposed new paragraph 14ZR(1)(a) there are references to section 14E of the Act. The section 14E there referred to is a proposed new section 14E being inserted by schedule 4 of the Bill. It does not refer to the previously repealed section 14E.

The second matter refers to drafting technique. Honourable senators will notice that many of the provisions in proposed part IVC of the Taxation Administration Act refer to persons rather than taxpayers. This reflects the fact that the new provisions apply in relation to objections against taxation decisions of various kinds, for example, objections by employers to fringe benefits tax assessments and by companies to franking deficits tax offsets. While the new provisions could have exhaustively listed these expressions, it was considered that the term `person' was an adequate and appropriate term to cover all cases.
Further details of the amendments are contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators. I commend the amendments to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his detailed explanations. I think they clarify the intention of the Government as to what is meant by some of the wording of the amendments. I understood that Senator McMullan was going to give undertakings about Australian Taxation Office audit practice in collection procedures when there is an objection still in dispute with the Commission. He might recall that, when we put the original 60 days, we did indicate that this was essentially tight and was construed in such a way as to provide some degree of negotiation so far as the Government and the Tax Office vis-a-vis the taxpayer were concerned.

PARA.TAB: We were hoping that an alternative may have been that, while the dispute did continue so far as the Tax Office was concerned, there would be an undertaking that there would be no further penalties and, secondly, that under those circumstances the Tax Office generally would not seek to collect tax. The Government indicated that it would prefer not to have that in the Bill but that it was prepared to give a general indication that in most cases those two sets of circumstances would prevail. Would the Parliamentary Secretary clarify that, because on the basis that that undertaking would be given we did not pursue the issue further?

TALK.START.PARA: —That point was covered, and intended to be covered, by the reference in my earlier remarks to the confirmation by the Commissioner that this amendment will not affect the operations of those rulings. The procedure set down in 2569 and 2570 will continue to operate.

—The Democrats will be supporting the Government's amendments. I think the clarification has been achieved by negotiation between the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats. We have protected the rights of taxpayers while also protecting the reasonable rights of the Commissioner, and I think that is a positive outcome.

—I think the handling of these taxation issues does show the value of a Senate and the new committee arrangements whereby these Bills go off for extensive debate in committee—in this case, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I take this opportunity to thank the Tax Office for its cooperation.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In handling this National Road Transport Commission Bill on behalf of the Opposition, let me declare that the manner in which this Government has chosen to deal with the road transport industry through the National Road Transport Commission and through this Bill is nothing short of shabby and disgraceful conduct. It is disgraceful, too, that its co-conspirators, the Australian Democrats, support this Bill without any hint of critical analysis of the current situation of the industry, the role to be played by the Commission or the procedures under which it will operate.

PARA.TAB: This farce, this waste of the Senate's time, with Labor and the Democrats combining to pass a Bill which is full of inadequacies and shortcomings, would not have occurred had the Democrats been more vigilant and more watchful of what this Government is attempting to do. This piece of legislation should not be before us today. We should not be wasting the Senate's time with a marred prescription for change. The Government has chosen to ignore totally the pleas of both the coalition and the industry for a more thorough and cogent evaluation of all aspects of the Road Transport Commission. Instead, the Government forges blindly ahead, despite the fact that it is clear that ongoing scrutiny of the Commission must take place.

Pressure must be brought to bear on the legislation's architects, the soon to be in opposition Government, for its total disregard of vital industry needs. The Liberal and National parties cannot support this Bill in its present form or before the issues of total taxation on the industry and the efficiency of road construction and maintenance are given a full airing. The Bill chooses not to be concerned with these key problem areas faced by the road transport industry and, consequently, is fundamentally blemished.

If the issues highlighted by the Liberal and National parties in opposition, and subsequently emphasised by the industry, are disregarded and major areas of concern ignored, the industry will be set back 20 years. If a thorough review of the taxation paid by the industry and a removal of the tax burden on inputs are included as two of the basic requirements currently ignored by the legislation, then and only then could the Opposition consider giving support to the Bill.

The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, has been cooing recently about winning so-called concessions from the Government to ensure that the proposed road charges for heavy vehicles are fair and equitable and that there will be increased parliamentary oversight of road transport reform. But there is currently no provision for determining what is fair and equitable.

Senator Coulter's claims that the real concerns of rural communities and the trucking industry will be properly addressed, without derailing the long overdue development of uniform national road transport laws, are pathetic and unsustainable excuses for ignoring the industry's concerns. To date, neither the Government nor the Democrats have shown genuine concern for the level of input taxes and charges already paid by the road transport industry or, for that matter, the current efficiency levels of road construction and maintenance so that recommendations for efficiency improvements might be forthcoming.

The sad truth of the matter is that the Democrats could not even get their act together to consider what this Bill will do to the road transport industry. They certainly could not even muster up enough enthusiasm for their representative on the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure to attend last week's special hearings on this Bill where numerous road transport industry representatives from across Australia took the time to appear and to voice their frustrations and concerns on issues that they fear will be ignored in this legislation and, ultimately also, one suspects, by the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have heard the explanation for that, so don't misrepresent us.

—We have just heard Senator Kernot intervene that there was an explanation for that. There may have been an explanation why Senator Powell was unable to attend that Committee, but there is certainly no explanation why another Democrat could not attend the Committee hearing on her behalf. It is entirely unacceptable that the Democrats failed to attend that hearing. The Democrats' concern has been hollow and their interest indifferent, and that has not gone unnoticed by industry members and by those who travelled at extremely short notice to Canberra to give evidence before the Committee last Wednesday night.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats' choice to demean and not recognise industry distress regarding this legislation may ultimately hijack the road transport industry and cause irreparable damage to it and to all those who benefit in some way from it. The Democrats will never live down the fact that they gave this failed Hawke Labor Government carte blanche support on the legislation without even bothering to hear the concerns of the industry. The Democrats refused to support the initiative of the Liberal and National parties for a wide-ranging inquiry into the issues affecting the transport industry before this Bill was given further consideration. They then failed to turn up to hear the evidence presented to the legislation committee hearing last Wednesday, as already detailed.

In this, they were almost matched by the Labor Party which, through most of the hearing, was represented only by the Committee Chairman, with one other member appearing briefly at the beginning of the hearing, another appearing intermittently but briefly during the evening, and one not appearing at all. Only the three Liberal members—Senators Panizza, Macdonald and I, as Deputy Chairman—plus Senator Boswell of the National Party, by invitation, and the Labor Chairman heard the comprehensive and distressing evidence that was given to us about the detrimental impact of the Government's legislation. As a consequence, at the conclusion of the Committee hearing we three Liberals, in the absence of sufficient Labor and Democrat Committee members, were able to have the following resolution passed at the conclusion of the hearing last Wednesday night:

That the Committee recommends that the Senate not proceed with the National Road Transport Commission Bill, because of the failure of the Government to adequately answer questions raised in evidence before the Committee as to the impact of the legislation, unless and until the Interim National Road Transport Commission examines and publicly reports on—

SPEECH.PARA: 1.the economic and social impact of full cost recovery of road costs on rural and regional Australia;
2.all input taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry;
3.the likely level of road charges and road use charges on various operators;
and the Committee has had the opportunity to consider the Interim Commission's Report.

Today, at a hastily convened meeting, again in the absence of the Democrats, the Government was able to use its full quota of numbers on the Committee to overturn this recommendation and have the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure recommend that the Bill proceed. That is why Senators Panizza, Macdonald and I have lodged a dissenting report in the following terms:

PARA.TAB: We dissent from the recommendation by the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for the following reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The resolution that was adopted by the Committee after the hearing.
that is the resolution to which I have just referred—
2.The concerns expressed at the hearing by witnesses from all over Australia that either gave written submissions or appeared in person.

I will not take up the time of the Senate to name all the authors of submissions or give the names of the witnesses who appeared but they were many in number and their experience ranged widely across industry. Details are contained in the report of the Committee that was tabled in the Senate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to.
—I note Senate Panizza's interjection that he is going to name them, so I will leave that task to him later in the debate. The final paragraph of our dissenting report of today states:

PARA.TAB: The evidence given in the brief time spent on the inquiry, which cannot as yet be actually analysed—confirms to us the belief that a comprehensive inquiry must be held before proceeding with legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats should be standing with us and denying passage to this Bill until the issues are resolved. The resolution of the Senate earlier today for a full scale inquiry into the issues, sponsored by the Democrats, even though it incorporates the Opposition amendment to include investigating all taxation on the industry, is a meaningless sop to the industry after the Democrats have sold it out.

PARA.TAB: It is not good enough to have a Senate committee inquiry after the legislation has passed, as the Democrats have now indicated. As proposed by the Opposition, passage of the legislation should have been delayed until this detailed inquiry occurred. The legislation is yet further evidence of how disdainfully this leaderless Government addresses the industry's numerous and deep-seated problems which have been caused by the mismanagement and neglect of micro-economic reform issues crucial to the road transport industry's survival.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in one of his regular mega-announcements, made following the so-called most important Special Premiers Conference since the war, trumpeted the setting up of the new Road Transport Commission. Mr Hawke informed us that the Commission would be established to assist with new regulations and registration and charging arrangements and that an interim commission would be in place by September. Is Mr Hawke really serious about these massive changes to the road transport industry? This is a valid question when one remembers that the July agreement foreshadowed the interim commission's appointment in September, three months ago, but that it was actually appointed only late last month—a mere couple of weeks ago.

The interim commission is to report on the registration charges by March 1992; a job initially set to take six months. It now seems it will only take two, because by the time the Commission gets rolling after the summer break, and following its delayed establishment, it will still have to report by March. If this is an indication of the depth of the Prime Minister's commitment to the reformation of the road transport industry and its more than 400,000 workers, it is also an indication of the gross lack of sincerity displayed by both this Government and the supporters of this legislation, the Australian Democrats.

It seems that the Prime Minister may have been in one of his caring, sharing, supportive moods when he announced the setting up of the Road Transport Commission but, from the outset, the issue of poor timing has cast suspicion on the entire process. The road transport industry is extremely concerned at the direction in which the Government wants to take the industry. It, quite rightly, wants some focus on the Government's unwillingness to negotiate changes to its methodology and its reluctance to disclose how the new charges will be derived and, in fact, what they will be. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) says this piece of legislation is merely a mechanical Bill; a straightforward and non-controversial piece of legislation which merely sets up the organisation. Yet it cannot even get that started on time.

The National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991 will essentially set in place the framework under which the Commission will operate. The Commission will then be required to investigate and make recommendations to the Australian Transport Advisory Council regarding the establishment of a national heavy vehicle registration scheme and the introduction of nationally consistent heavy vehicle regulations and charging procedures.

However, within and across the industry there is major disquiet with the direction of, and the methodology to be used by, the Commission. Last Wednesday, the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure hearing on the legislation heard, loud and clear, the worry and dissatisfaction among industry members who are concerned with the intended operation of the Commission and the Commission's failure to consult, as was promised, with key industry players.

The road transport industry is probably the most competitive in Australia. All forms of economic restrictions were lifted as long ago as the 1950s. This factor has assisted industry to achieve efficiencies. The industry needs other reforms—not just in the business of road transport but in the areas of roads, regulations and taxes as well. Road transport carries about 80 per cent of the freight task of this country and employs about 400,000 people. So the pricing of road transport affects millions of customers and consumers across our entire community.

To ensure that the Commission provides both fair and open processes which achieve the best outcome for and satisfy the interests of the whole community, the following five factors must be considered: firstly, the Commission, following its investigations and deliberations, must be given enough time to report; secondly, the Commission must adjust its methodology to take into account alternative and even opposing views relating to how it operates; thirdly, since the Inter-State Commission's report on the excessive levels of taxation imposed on the road transport industry have become legend, they should be thoroughly investigated—and the road transport industry is already taxed 3 1/2 times more in indirect taxes than the average for all other industries; fourthly, the Commission must be able to determine appropriate cost recovery targets independently; and, finally, the Commission must be provided with the capacity to look at appropriate timing to move to full cost recovery.

It is easy to see why the industry is both alarmed and concerned at the direction which this legislation appears to be taking. The National Road Transport Commission has clearly not been given sufficiently wide reference powers to consider the existing taxes that road transport pays, because the new charges will be over and above the existing taxes. This is guaranteed to send many operators and their employees out of business. The Inter-State Commission, not the Road Transport Authority, has already advised that the road transport industry does more than pay its way with taxes and charges. Industry members have also expressed concern that all the beneficial aspects of the proposed reform, specifically uniform rules and regulations, have been sacrificed in the name of political compromise. The zonal system plus the ability of any State to make an application order for variation implies that standards enforcement levels and penalties may not be uniform at all.

The legislation does not address the charging and regulatory regime directly, but it does hint that the major role of the Commission will be a facade behind which the State road transport authorities will continue business as usual. Further, it has not been given the power to scrutinise the supply of roads, and there is ample evidence that road construction and maintenance are inefficient. This is an area where significant savings could be achieved if the issue were addressed.

There will, apparently, be some 21 committees whose work bears directly on the Commission, and one does not have to be a mathematician to work out the amount of time such a workload will impose on Commission members. These and other important aspects of the operation of the Commission in particular, and the legislation generally, are fundamental to the operation of the road transport industry in Australia.

While the coalition agrees with the principle of a commission as a means to achieve a more rational approach to road transport and road funding, it cannot give its support to the current structure of this Bill. I therefore move on behalf of the Opposition the following second reading amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for entering into an agreement with the States which is flawed in that it fails to provide for:
(a)a thorough review of all inputs taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry; and
(b)an investigation of the current level of efficiency of road construction and maintenance practices;

SPEECH.PARA: and notes that the Senate will now have to rectify these omissions by referring the matter to a Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee for inquiry and report".
We also have some specific amendments which we will be moving at the committee stage of the debate on this legislation.

PARA.TAB: This second reading amendment which I have moved on behalf of the Opposition seeks to give strength, support and some hope to the many thousands involved in the road transport industry who are adamant that the Government's legislative proposals are detrimental to the long term development of their industry. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Road Transport Commission Bill seeks to establish a National Road Transport Commission and set in place a framework under which it will operate. Frankly, I do not like its chances of success. I believe that the Bill is absolutely doomed from the start because, as we on this side of the chamber keep saying time and time again on Bill after Bill, the legislation is flawed, it is sloppy and it does not address the very real concerns of the industry to which it applies.

PARA.TAB: We all know that the Government operates in a vacuum. At a time when ABARE is predicting a massive 75 per cent slump in farm incomes and unemployment is at a national level of 10.5 per cent, rising to as much as 40 per cent and 50 per cent in some areas among some age groups, what is occupying the Government's mind? The incessant squabbling, of course, about who should or should not lead the Australian Labor Party into oblivion. I personally do not care who leads the Labor Party, but the way Labor is going it will not only be the Labor Party which fades into oblivion but all of Australia. While the Government is so preoccupied with factions and fist fights, the Government is pushing through legislation which is flawed, which is wrong and which is not in the very best interests of the industry. There is a public funding commitment in this. We are told that it will cost the Federal Government some $3m to $4m a year, or 35 per cent of the total costs. We are spending even more funds from beleaguered taxpayers on something that no-one seems to want.
The legislation, as we know, was referred to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. During that Committee's deliberations, Senator Chapman moved:

That the Committee recommends that the Senate not proceed with the National Road Transport Commission Bill, because of the failure of the Government to adequately answer questions raised in evidence before the Committee as to the impact of the legislation, unless and until the Interim National Road Transport Commission examines and publicly reports on—

SPEECH.PARA: 1.the economic and social impact of full cost recovery of road costs on rural and regional Australia;
2.all input taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry;
3.the likely level of Road Charges and Road Use Charges on various operators.
and the Committee has had time to consider the Interim Commission's Report.

Senator Macdonald and Senator Panizza supported the motion, with Senators Foreman and Faulkner dissenting. The motion was agreed to. The Committee report sums up very clearly what should be happening.

PARA.TAB: Industry representatives, including Mr Ron Seach from Gunnedah, met with the Committee last week in Canberra. He and others put a range of arguments to the Committee and expressed real concerns about how the commission would levy road charges. Ron Seach, a partner in Goodman and Seach, at Curlewis, told the Committee that as his business is an intrastate business his vehicles never leave New South Wales and under the two-zone system proposed it would be locked into a high cost regime. He pointed out that, as he was not a national operator, he would not be able to offset his costs by moving between high and low cost zones as large national fleet operators would be able to do. He pointed out that it was not just the trucking companies which would be affected but those companies whose goods they carry. His business carries black coal.

As Ron Seach pointed out, the very last thing that the New South Wales coal industry needs at the present time is more legislative disadvantage such as this Bill would create. He put the view that, if all Australians benefit from an efficient and viable road system, surely all Australians should contribute to it. The NFF is also opposed to the legislation. At the Committee hearing Gary Goucher, from the NFF, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The farm sector is quite concerned at the progress that is being made in efforts to rationalise the road transport arrangements in Australia. Whilst the objectives certainly sound laudable, the constraints which are being put on the process, essentially by the structure of the agreement between the Premiers and the Commonwealth, do not permit the reforms to get to an end point that is going to be in the interests of improving Australia's position and that of its industries. It does have a risk of in fact making Australia worse off.

I think the Government should think about that statement as it is pushing through this legislation. Mr Goucher further suggested that under the Bill the Government would be shifting a tax burden from one group of taxpayers to another. He said:

To a significant extent, you are going to shift that tax burden onto export industries, of which agriculture is a major one. I know for a fact that that particular industry has no capacity to accept additional charges and suggest that Australia as a whole has no capacity to be thinking about putting additional charges on its export industries.

Of course, those are two points that really should be taken into account. The NFF was also concerned about the powers, responsibilities and independence of the Commission. Even the Transport Workers Union has concerns. It complained about lack of consultation—which seems a little strange, given the union movement's traditional closeness to and control over the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: Road transport is the lifeblood of any country town, every country business. Any charges that affect freight make life in non-metropolitan New South Wales, or any part of Australia outside the major metropolitan areas, that much less affordable. The Government has yet again forgotten the impact that this legislation will have on rural people. We today saw the situation the rural sector is in. We only have to look at the front page of this morning's Australian to see the plight of the people in rural areas. They are literally at a one-minute-to-midnight crisis point. No government has any right to contemplate legislation that will increase charges for rural dwellers by even as much as one cent.

I support the Opposition's amendment moved by Senator Chapman, which addresses the anomalies in this Bill. The legislation is flawed; it is sloppy; and it is inflationary. The Government needs to go back to the drawing board and do something about it. It needs to come up with a Bill that is a lot better than the one which has been presented to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The function of the National Road Transport Commission Bill is to establish a National Road Transport Commission. The Bill will bring into effect an inter-governmental agreement that was signed on 30 July by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premiers and Chief Ministers of all the States and Territories. The proposed Commission is to develop national legislation on road use charges. Of course, the Bill will provide the framework for the National Road Transport Commission. The legislation will be developed by the Commission, and any changes will be dealt with in separate legislation. Of course, it deals only with vehicles over 4 1/2 tonnes. Let no-one forget that the Premiers Conference is still considering what to do with lighter vehicles, those under 4 1/2 tonnes, so they are not quite out of the net yet.

PARA.TAB: The Bill is a nonsense at this stage. The Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure would probably agree that it has been brought before the Senate at this late stage with narrow reporting from the Committee due to the narrow guidelines it had to work with when investigating the charges. It is essentially a taxing Bill and a revenue raising piece of legislation. While it does not affect current legislation or charges, it provides the interim arrangements. I have already said that the first set of charges is to be determined and recommended by March 1992 and then implemented in January 1993. So I cannot really see what the hurry is. For some unknown reason, that is what the Government wants to do.

I believe that the Government wants to get those charges up, not recognising at all what road transport is already paying. There is an admission by everyone around the country that they are paying 3 1/2 times more tax than anyone else. But here we have the Government wanting to set charges for full road construction and maintenance cost recovery by March, to be implemented in the next year. The second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: Transport has a pervasive influence over the efficiency of our economy and improvements in the system will have significant national benefits.

The Industry Commission has estimated that a more efficient land transport system, including a more efficient rail system, alone could realise an additional $6 billion in Gross Domestic Profit every year.
It further states:
This Government is committed to a competitive and efficient transport system. Cheaper and more efficient transport means greater success in ensuring Australia's industries are more competitive.
Those are very worthwhile words, but the Bill does not provide for cheaper transport; in fact, it provides for more expensive transport.

PARA.TAB: The Bill focuses only on the charges. It concentrates on raising costs, not on achieving savings. It fails to achieve any micro-economic reform objectives and provides no recognition of community service obligations. That is a point that was brought out very strongly at our Committee the other night by those of us on this side of the chamber. The proposal does not recognise any government community service obligations to provide roads for less return than the full cost of supplying them in developing Australia. Community service obligations should be taken into account when it is in the national interest to provide roads to rural and remote areas for the purpose of defence and economic development, particularly for major export industries such as mining, primary production and tourism.

The Government has gone back on the undertaking which Senator Evans provided in 1988 that the cost of production would not be reflected in registration charges. I suppose that the Government is relying on an action in the High Court about that time that gave it some hope to get out of Senator Evans's undertaking at the Yass blockade in 1998, which I will not go into at this time.

I will return to the issue of the CSOs for one moment. The roads provided in Australia, which the registration charges will reflect, are not wholly or totally used by members of the heavy transport system—in fact, some roads are never used by them—yet they are taken into consideration for setting those charges. Tourist roads seldom see a heavy vehicle. Tourist places in remote areas especially are serviced by light vehicles. So how can the Government say that the cost of those roads will be reflected? Defence roads are another example.

The coalition's position has been well pointed out by Senator Chapman and by my colleague Senator Brownhill. No doubt Senator Macdonald will back up these honourable senators later. I would like to reinforce what the coalition believes. I believe that we need an inquiry into the social and regional impact of the price increases on rural and remote Australia to report before the Bill is legislated for and a thorough summary is made of the taxation already paid. I have already mentioned that road users are paying three and a half times more in charges than anyone else and yet no-one, especially the Australian Democrats, was interested enough in the inquiry last week to turn up. Senator Kernot had better not interject because I have an answer for her. Further, we want an inquiry into road costs and the efficiency of making those roads in Australia. Given the deadline in setting the registration fees by 1992, I cannot see how this new Commission has a snowball's chance in hell of ever achieving cost recovery by March 1992, especially since, as I have already said, it will not be set up until January 1993.

Out of various discussions held on this proposed Bill, it has been decided that we will have a zonal system. I welcome the zonal system when talking about Western Australia and probably Queensland because there will be a discount on the charges; I do not quite know what they will be. However, it will provide more problems than it will solve because basing it on the State borders is strictly illogical. If it was based right around the coast of Australia where most of the population lives, I would agree with it. But it is being based on State borders. I seldom defend New South Wales, but the western part of that State is as remote an area in Australia as one can get. South Australia, which is not yet part of the system, has the same problem. Western Australia is in zone B and thus has lower charges. The working of the system is utterly impossible.

When questioning representatives of the Department at the Committee inquiry the other day, I asked what the situation would be if a truck travelled from Perth in Western Australia right across South Australia and into Broken Hill, which is only a few kilometres inside New South Wales. Would the journey be split up into the lower zone and the higher zone? I was told by them—it is a pity we do not have some departmental people here tonight to listen to what is going on so they can advise us later—that if a vehicle or a vehicle with a trailer travels into the other zone, zone A, at all, then higher charges will have to be registered there. That is exactly what I was told the other night. I hope I am wrong, but that is what I was told.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are going to have to register in two States.

—No, not register in two States; but register in the State with the higher charges. If I am wrong I would like to be told that I am wrong. That is why I believe the scheme certainly will not work across those zones.

PARA.TAB: As has already been pointed out by Senator Chapman, this Bill was referred to a committee last week. We, on this side of the chamber, had attempted to send it to the same Committee and have it report back in the middle of next year, or give it whatever time was needed in order to cover the points that we have discussed already. I will run through them again briefly. At the Committee hearing last week our side moved a motion which was carried. It involved:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.the economic and social impact of full cost recovery of road costs on rural and regional Australia;
2.all input taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry:
That was the main thing: we wanted to find out what they were before we started setting new ones. The motion continued:
3.the likely level of Road Charges and Road Use Charges on various operators.

and the Committee has had time to consider the Interim Commission's Report. That was what we were looking for.
