That motion was passed and, contrary to any other debates, regulations or resolutions, it was overturned in another place in three minutes when the Chairman called another meeting in order to overturn it. I thought one had to give at least 14 days notice of the intention to rescind a motion before one could move another motion, but obviously that does not work in this place.

PARA.TAB: That meeting consisted of us and the Government. The timing of the meeting was changed about three or four times. In the five days notice that was given to the road transport industry of Australia, some people came to Canberra to appear in front of the Committee on a Wednesday evening. The Committee sat from 8 o'clock until 2 o'clock in the morning—which shows how dedicated these people were. These people included: Mr G. Boulton of the National Freight Forwarders Association; the Hon. F. Finch, the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works; Mr B. Fletcher of Fletchers Freighters; Mr G. Gouche of the National Farmers Federation, and the National Farmers Federation represents all the farmers federations around Australia, as well as the pastoralists and graziers; Mr R. Gunning and Mr B. McIver of the Road Transport Forum; Mr J. McLean of the New South Wales Branch of the Transport Workers Union of Australia; Mr J. Pearson of the Long Distance Road Transport Association; and Mr R. Seach of Goodman and Seach. Submissions were received from L. Arthur Smith Pty Ltd, BHP Transport, the Northern Territory Government, the National Freight Forwarders Association and the Victorian Road Transport Association Inc. That is the calibre of the submissions received and of the people who appeared before us for six hours that night.

I was very saddened that the Australian Democrats, who receive at least one-third of their votes from the rural areas of Australia, did not make the effort to attend. No-one can tell me that they did not know that the meeting was being held. They chose to ignore it; just as they chose to ignore the meeting we had today.

If anyone is disputing the fact that the Australian Democrats chose to ignore this meeting, I will read out part of a release or a statement that came from Senator Coulter, the Leader of the Democrats. This is his statement to witnesses and observers who showed up on that night. The Australian Democrats did not have the decency to send one of their representatives, so they sent a statement. So let them not deny that they had knowledge of this meeting. The statement read in part:

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that the Australian Democrats are unable to attend tonight's meeting. Our Transport spokesperson, Senator Janet Powell, is on compassionate leave;—
and I sympathise with her—
I will be handling the Bill in her place, but prior engagements and the short notice of this meeting prevent me from attending.

Five days is given as being too short a period of notice for someone who is here in the Parliament. Yet look at the list of witnesses I have cited as coming from all parts of Australia in order to attend this very important meeting. Once again, let not the Democrats say that they did not know about this meeting.

PARA.TAB: That Committee reinforced my concerns as to what were the problems with this Bill and as to the charges it would be likely to set up without reflecting on what is being paid around Australia already. It reaffirmed my conviction that this Bill, without its going any further, should be under the scrutiny of a committee sent to gather evidence from all around Australia to determine what the impacts would be, because we certainly do not know half of what is going on.

Of course, the Bill has come back into the Senate for processing, after the overturning of our motion at the meeting this morning. So Senator Chapman, Senator Macdonald and I have put in a dissenting report, which is published in this publication for everyone in the Senate to read. That is the position we have arrived at.

If the Senate or the Government has any idea of enacting such a Bill to start setting charges before looking at other things, it would be totally wrong. We have to look at other things too. We have to look at how independent this proposed Commission will be. The Bill sets up a Commission that I believe would in no way be independent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is not.

—It seems independent on paper. But when we look at the guidelines the Commission can work within, we must ask ourselves: how can it be independent? It is being locked into a set of guidelines within which it cannot move, so it has to come up with recommendations that the Government tells it to come up with. It cannot use as a main criterion what the industry is already paying.
—Do you believe in cost recovery?
—I am sorry, but I cannot hear Senator Kernot. But the point is

SPEECH.PARA: that the Commission cannot be independent with those sorts of guidelines. Where is the real reform that has been made by this Government? In a statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made in 1983, he told how this Government was going to reform transport, roads and rail. Where is the reform that has been made? I cannot see it.

PARA.TAB: One would think that, before we even look at charges and reflect on the cost of building roads, we would look in Australia to see whether we are efficiently building roads. Anyone who drives along main roads, as I do, and cares to look at the road-making gangs will see that there are umpteen pieces of plant sitting there—graders, loaders, come what may. What hours do they work? They are employed for 35 hours a week if we are lucky. Those machines could be working not 24 hours a day, which I think could be quite dangerous on main roads, but 12 hours a day, seven days a week, and be two or three times as productive. Nothing has been done about that. Outdated plant is being used as well.

However, the main thing that we could be looking at is contracting out, going out to tender and letting the main roads department in each State submit tenders. We could then see whether the departments got the jobs. If the departments got the jobs themselves as the result of a real tender, I would say that they could be efficient. But I think that, in the first instance, most of those jobs let out on tender would go out to private contractors.

Then we have to look at engineering. We had submissions in here some time ago from road construction people—asphalt suppliers—that the education amongst the more remote shires and makers of roads is lacking. There should be measures such as interchange among engineers to give them experience in those outer areas. We have to look at all those things, and we have to rationalise road making resources and road funds so that the money that we are spending goes much further when we come to road making. Then when all those things are in place—when we have the most efficient road making and the most up-to-date methods—we have to establish something that I have not mentioned, that is, a designated route system for heavy transport in Australia. That is very important.

If we have a designated plan for all of Australia, we can rationalise our resources and spend them on those roads and not on the ones that are not quite so important. They are the things we have to do before we start looking at setting new charges that may put a lot of road operators in Australia out of action and, indeed, the rural and remote areas out of business in other ways. I commend our amendments and look forward to speaking to them in the committee stage.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 12 December, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Chapman had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: Leave out all words after "That", substitute:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)"because of the unacceptable attitude of the Minister for Industrial Relations in refusing to table the Brown Report on COMCARE and failing to explain why the Government rejected its major recommendations, particularly the recommendation for early redemptions:

PARA.TAB: (i)the Senate expresses its concern at the proposed changes to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act;
(ii)the Brown Report on COMCARE be tabled without delay; and
(iii)the Senate declares its support for the general thrust of that Report;

PROCTEXT.PARA: (b)the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to include the recommendations of the Brown Report, especially those concerning:

PARA.TAB: (i)provision for compassionate early redemptions;
(ii)setting reasonable time limits for determinations, reconsiderations and reviews;

(iii)provision to the Minister by the new Commission, within a reasonable time, of a detailed strategy for addressing the most important service problems identified in the Brown Review and an implementation report to overcome them;
(iv)licensing arrangements for self-administrators; and
(v)the appointment of a part-time Chairman of the Commission who is not the Chief Executive Officer of COMCARE;
and to include:
(vi)allowing disputed claims to be referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal before they are reviewed; and
(vii)having self-administrators' disputed claims reviewed by COMCARE; and

PROCTEXT.PARA: (c)the Senate rejects the proposal of the Government to amend the Navigation Act to allow compliance with ILO convention 73, the Medical Examination (Seafarers) Convention 1946, in spite of unresolved concerns on the part of the Government of the Northern Territory, until the Commonwealth Government has undertaken full consultation with the Government of the Northern Territory".
and upon which Senator Reid had moved by way of an amendment to the proposed amendment:

PARA.TAB: At the end of the words to be added, add the following: "; and
(d)the Senate declares its belief that both the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees and COMCARE should be privatised".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was adjourned there was discussion across the chamber to the effect that we would agree to consult about some of the matters in the second reading amendments that I think the coalition parties and the Australian Democrats had tabled. In the ensuing period a number of discussions have resulted in substantial agreement and a statement setting out the intentions of the Government on a number of the key points that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats were concerned about, and making commitments by me on behalf of the Government to ways of resolving those points. It is perhaps too long a matter to go to each of those points separately and, on that basis, as there has been a long discussion about each of them and they are covered in a document that I now have, I will seek leave to incorporate this document, which is headed, `Ministerial Statement', in Hansard for the purposes of including in the written record the commitment that the Government makes on these matters. This document has been circulated to the leaders in the debate for both the coalition and the Australian Democrats. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTERIAL STATEMENT

The Government endorses the approach taken by the Brown Review of the Comcare Program and recognises the merits of commercialisation. This Bill incorporates amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation (CERC) Act 1988 as a first stage in the Government's implementation of the recommendations of the Review.
THE INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AMENDMENT ACT (No 3) 1991
It introduces a series of changes to the operation of Comcare and the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees including:

.a separation of the Commission's regulatory and service functions with the new Commission responsible for regulatory functions including determining and setting premiums, occupational health and safety, licensing of self-administrators, and the Chief Executive Officer responsible for Comcare's commercial and service operations
.a separation of the Chairperson/CEO position. It is the intention that there will be a part-time Chairperson and the CEO will be a member of the Commission but not the Chairperson
.a restructuring of the Commission to broaden its expertise

These are not the only amendments the Government proposes to make as a result of the Brown Review. However, by introducing these as a first step and putting the new Commission in place, I will be able to draw on its advice in implementing other important recommendations of the Review.
As part of the staged approach further legislative amendments will be introduced in the Autumn Sittings covering:

PARA.TAB: .licensing of self-administering authorities

.improved financial arrangements to enable Comcare's financial statements to show that the scheme is fully funded, which will establish a basis for consideration of the need for any further moves towards self-financing of Comcare operations

SPEECH.PARA: Comcare will introduce more flexible operating arrangements involving the expansion of the range of services available to Commonwealth employers.

In addition, the Government will give consideration to the ability of Comcare to offer its services to recently privatised Government Business Enterprises and to the diversification of Comcare's market base outside the Commonwealth public sector.

The Brown Review made a number of recommendations relating to the commercialisation of Comcare. The Government will consider these recommendations next year after the full policy and financial implications have been examined. I wish to reiterate the Government's intention to further reform the Commonwealth's workers' compensation system, in the broad directions recommended by Ron Brown in his Review.
SELF-ADMINISTRATORS

I propose to introduce further amendments to the CERC Act in the Autumn Session which will deal specifically with the issue of self-administrators. When the CERC Act was passed in 1988 provision was made for both Australia Post and Telecom to become self-administrators of the Commonwealth workers' compensation scheme, for a two year trial period, with responsibility for all aspects of the administration of the CERC Act for their employees.

This Bill empowers the Commission to ensure that, as far as practicable, there is no inconsistency in the administrative practices and procedures used by Comcare and the self-administering authorities in the performance of their respective functions. The Commission will be able to prepare and issue general policy guidelines to the principal officer of an administering authority in relation to the operation of the Act, to the extent that the Act confers functions or powers on the authority. The administering authority must comply with any guidelines issued by the Commission.
As a matter of priority I will be asking the Commission to develop guidelines for a number of administrative practices including:

PARA.TAB: .Time limits for determinations and reviews
.Surveillance practices
.The current practice of using medical review panels
.Procedures for review of disputed claims

SPEECH.PARA: Because of some remaining confusion about the status of decisions and recommendations made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal I will also ask the Commission to consider this issue as a matter of urgency.

In the meantime I have asked the current Commission to resolve these issues in consultation with the self-administrators. I will also give an undertaking that the performance of the self-administrators in these areas will be taken into account in determining whether they are granted licences.

The Bill will also provide for the current self-administration arrangements to be replaced with two licences—self-insurance and in-house claims management as recommended by the Brown Review. Both licences would be subject to strict entry thresholds and periodic review. At this stage the Government is not proposing to extend licences for claims management to other statutory authorities or departments, until the new licensing arrangements have been reviewed by the new Commission.

In foreshadowing these amendments to the CERC Act it is the Government's intention to give the Commission the power to develop licensing arrangements and to require any conditions it sees fit, but as a minimum set of criteria:
.The Commission would have the power to grant or refuse applications for either or both forms of licence;

.The Commission will have regard to the suitability of the applicant, the applicant's financial ability to meet current and future liabilities, and the ability of the applicant to meet claims management and rehabilitation standards set by the Commission;

.The Commission will set performance standards including time limits for determinations and reviews, issue guidelines on the administration of the Act to promote consistency in its administration, monitor performance and report annually on the performance of the licensees and on other matters relating to the licensing system;
.A licence would be granted subject to the terms and conditions prescribed in the legislation and as imposed by the Commission;
.The Commission will be empowered to suspend or revoke a licence if the conditions of the licence are not complied with; and
.All liabilities incurred by a licensee during the period of the licence would remain with the licensee following cancellation or suspension of a licence.
REDEMPTIONS

The Brown Review recommended that a special arrangement should be made to redeem the entitlements of some of those beneficiaries affected by the special transitional arrangements in the 1988 legislation. The Government recognises the need to consider the special circumstances of those claimants who have been most adversely affected by these arrangements, taking into account questions of equity. Therefore, we will consider, in the context of 1992/93 Budget, a proposal for a special redemptions arrangement having regard to all factors including equity consideration.
SERVICE ISSUES
The Brown Review drew attention to a number of important service issues identified in submissions to the review and recommended that they be given early attention.

Under the new arrangements proposed in this legislation which establish Comcare as the body responsible for commercial and service operations, I have asked the Chief Executive Officer of Comcare to prepare a service plan for the consideration of the Commission before the end of June 1992 at the latest. This will address the key service issues identified in the Review and establish service standards and an implementation strategy for the organisation. A report on the development and implementation of the Service Plan will be included in Comcare's Annual Report for 1991/92.
TABLING OF BROWN REPORT

I will also take the opportunity to advise the Senate that I will be tabling The Brown Review tomorrow, without the appendices, which include some material provided to the Review on a commercial-in-confidence basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As the Senate will recall, the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats combined to put to this chamber a second reading amendment on this legislation when it was debated last Thursday. The effect of that second reading amendment would have been to throw out the legislation at the second reading stage with an instruction to the Government to redraft it more closely in accordance with the recommendations of the Brown report and then bring that legislation back. As the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, has already indicated, he sought an adjournment of the debate at that stage to engage in discussions and negotiations with both the Liberal Party and the Democrats with regard to our concerns.

PARA.TAB: Last Thursday we granted the Minister's request. The concerns which the Opposition in particular had with regard to the legislation were, firstly, and perhaps most importantly, that it largely ignored, as we saw it, the recommendations of the Brown report; secondly, that the Minister had failed to table the Brown report in the Parliament; and, thirdly, the Minister had not explained why the legislation did not incorporate the 15 recommendations of the Brown report or why he had not tabled the report. In fact, we regarded that in particular as unacceptable, but all three of those concerns were unacceptable to the Opposition. We regarded the Minister's second reading speech as a travesty in terms of its lack of content and information with regard to the Government's response to the Brown recommendations.

I therefore welcome the Minister's statement tonight, which spells out in much greater detail the intent of the Government with regard to the Brown report and to future legislation which the Minister has promised to introduce in the autumn session of this Parliament. In the spirit of cooperation that we have tried to adopt over the last few days in discussions and negotiations with the Minister, I accept that statement in good faith that, in the autumn session, further legislation will be introduced and will proceed further down the track of implementing the Brown recommendations. However, we will seek to move an amendment in the committee stage of this Bill with regard to the structure of the National Road Transport Commission.

Although welcoming the Minister's cooperation in issuing this further detailed statement, I regret that the Opposition, with the support of the Democrats, had to threaten rejection of this Bill before we could get his attention directed to these issues. I regret that, in a sense, I had to help so much in drafting his statement tonight by looking at successive drafts of it and suggesting issues that ought to be addressed in that statement which were of concern to the Opposition. I believe the issues are sufficiently clear that the Minister should have seen them and given expression to them himself without any prompting by the Opposition. I also regret the evident slack administration of Comcare that has required the Opposition to bring this pressure to bear, which is highlighted in the Brown report.

I will turn briefly to the Minister's statement. I particularly welcome his opening sentence, which includes a recognition of the merits of commercialisation. The Opposition certainly believes that commercialisation must become an inherent part of Comcare and it must head down that track. I welcome the fact that, under the heading `The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1991' he made the first dot point a separation of the Commission's regulatory and service functions. Again, we believe that is of extreme importance and is of particular relevance to the commercialisation of Comcare. On the first page of the statement the Minister refers to improved financial arrangements to enable Comcare's financial statements to show that the scheme is fully funded, which will establish a basis for consideration of the need for any further moves towards self-financing Comcare's operations.

We believe that this is a very important issue. One of the major recommendations of the Brown report was that Comcare should become self-funding in its operation. It is perhaps worth referring to the Brown report with regard to that matter. The report identified a major weakness in the current scheme—one which it acknowledged Comcare has no control over—that is, the method in which premiums were paid to Consolidated Revenue and no separate accounting made for them.

The Brown report made the point that funds to cover the emerging cost of the liability are advanced annually to Comcare, as are funds for the administration of the scheme. The report went on to highlight a number of problems with this arrangement, the most significant of which was that by allowing the premiums to be absorbed into Consolidated Revenue, and making no clear provision for the accumulation of funds to cover liabilities under the scheme, the Government was operating a pay-as-you-go scheme rather than a fully funded system. This is contrary to the clear intention when Comcare was established several years ago. As the report says, it has been demonstrated in recent years to be a very unsound practice in the area of workers' compensation.

In evidence given to the review, the Department of Finance put forward reasons why such a situation should continue. However, the Brown report makes it very clear that it regards the arguments of the Department of Finance as inadequate and unsustainable. It is on that basis that we believe that Comcare should proceed to be a fully funded organisation. In particular, we would want to see Comcare operate on the basis of a self-financing organisation which includes both receiving and investing all premium income from the scheme and financing all Comcare operations out of investment income. I trust that, as the Government proceeds down the path of commercialisation, that is the course it will follow.

The other issue about which we have concern is that of the transitional arrangements for certain recipients of Comcare benefits. Again, the Brown report highlights the fact that some people have suffered relative hardship as a result of those transitional arrangements. It indicated that it might be more satisfactory if those people were able to quit the scheme altogether under a mutually acceptable arrangement. There were recommendations in the Brown report with regard to lump sum payments being made to cover those people. Again, this is an issue which has not been picked up in the legislation. We regret that. However, I welcome the fact that the Minister has indicated in his statement that this is a matter to which the Government will give consideration in the context of the Budget for the next financial year. The Opposition would urge the Government to give very serious consideration to that issue and come forward with a program in the forthcoming Budget for lump sum redemptions of people who have suffered as a result of those transitional arrangements.

I conclude by saying that the Brown report commenced its investigation some 12 months ago in December 1990. Comcare provided support staff for that inquiry. Throughout the Brown inquiry—it was conducted between December and April when the report was given to the Minister—Comcare was very much aware of the issues that were being raised and the progress that was being made towards conclusions and recommendations.

It is our belief that the Government and Comcare have had more than ample time to address and act on the issues that were raised by Brown, yet we are really only now seeing the commencement of those issues being addressed, some eight months after the report was presented to the Minister and 12 months after the inquiry commenced. We regard that delay as entirely unacceptable.

As a result, already one Budget has been missed to implement any financial implications of the recommendations of the Brown inquiry that might be applied. We are now told that it will take until June 1992 for Comcare to prepare a plan on service issues that were raised in the Brown report. That may well raise the danger that some of these issues are not addressed even in the next Budget. I urge that those service issues be addressed and recommendations made to the Minister in time for account to be taken of them in the next Budget.

As I said, I believe there has been ample time for the issues raised by Brown to have been considered by the Government and by Comcare. I believe it is slackness on the part of the Government and on the part of Comcare that they have not been addressed as yet. I also believe it is slackness that, despite this report being handed down in April, it was only two weeks ago that we were presented with this legislation.

Tonight, as the Senate sittings reach their conclusion, we particularly wanted to move amendments which addressed the relationship between the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the administration of Comcare issues. In particular, we believe there should be the opportunity for people to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal concurrently with their application to Comcare or the administering authority for a determination.

We have not been able to proceed with that amendment, despite the fact that the Minister has indicated to us that the Government has no immediate opposition to that proposal, but because the Minister would not have the opportunity tonight to obtain expert advice as to its implications for the legislation overall. This, again, is one of the recommendations that came forward, yet the Minister says at the twelfth hour that he does not have the opportunity to obtain expert advice on it. The same applies to other amendments which we would have sought to move in the committee stage of this legislation. We regard that as particularly unsatisfactory.

We have been assured by the Minister that one of our other concerns—that the chief executive officer of Comcare will not be the chairman of the Commission—is addressed in the legislation and in his statement, and that the part time chairman will not be the chief executive officer. We are satisfied with that.

We still have some concern that Government authorities other than Comcare which make determinations with regard to compensation under this legislation will remain the bodies which hear appeals for reconsideration of their initial determinations. We have had presented to us information that those bodies do not have the expertise adequately to make a fair reconsideration of those issues. Our view was that reconsideration should have been referred back to Comcare for further determination. Again, we are precluded from proceeding with that amendment because of the lateness of our receipt of, and dealing with, this legislation.

Having expressed those concerns, I conclude by saying that generally we support the additional statement which the Minister has presented tonight. We look forward to the next stage of the legislation—the next Bill being presented in the autumn session, introducing far more of the recommendations of the Brown report, and those which we want to see implemented—and we will certainly await that with interest. On that basis, we will not oppose this Bill at the second reading stage, but we will be moving one amendment at the committee stage.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Senator Chapman, you have before the Senate two amendments to the second reading. Do you propose to have those voted down or will you withdraw them?

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw those second reading amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments—by leave—withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As was indicated by Senator Chapman and also by Minister Cook, I believe there has been a considerable amount of negotiation on what we have before us. In fact, that negotiation has brought us to a position of compromise, if not consensus. So little needs to be added that has not been said in that negotiation process.

PARA.TAB: We now have a ministerial statement before us. The assurances given in that statement are in many ways commendable and will be received with considerable relief by the aggrieved parties who have been expressing their concern about the administration of workers compensation by the described self-administering authorities, Telecom Australia and Australia Post. A litany of disputed decisions by these authorities has provoked the passionate concerns being expressed to us, the Australian Democrats, and the Opposition, in the hope that when the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) was presented to us it would assist in resolving the concerns of the aggrieved parties.

I do not blame these people for making their grievances known. Upon seeing a Bill which was called the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, many people would not be aware that such a Bill would promise to resolve the many problems they have experienced in trying to have what they thought were their just concerns about workers compensation claims met. When it became apparent that this so-titled Bill promised to institute some of the recommendations of the review of the Comcare program, known as the Brown review, people wanted to see many more of those recommendations implemented immediately.

We are now assured in the ministerial statement that this Bill is the vehicle for establishing a much more efficient system for the administration of the workers compensation arrangements and that in future, in the autumn session, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) will be moving to use that vehicle to bring about a considerable number of changes. It is the nature of those changes that has been the subject of much of our discussion in the past few days.

When I spoke earlier in the second reading debate on the Bill I did raise a couple of examples of the sorts of concerns that had been expressed by people who had suffered from what could only be described as poor decision-making. The situation which brought about the examples I gave at that time has not changed. In fact, since giving those examples many others have been brought to our attention. It was surprising to find that these examples of poor decision-making really existed in the current Act, the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. It was surprising to find section 69F stating that the Commission has functions which include:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to maintain contact with each administering authority and rehabilitation authority to the extent necessary to ensure that, as far as practicable, there is no inconsistency in the administrative practices and procedures used by the Commission and the authority in the performance of their respective functions;

It was patently obvious that inconsistencies had developed between what was practised by Telecom and Australia Post and what was practised by Comcare. Those inconsistencies led to poor decisions. It was surprising that it seemed there was the capacity within the existing Act to address those inconsistencies and to consider them, but that was not done. We are now told that we need a new Act and a new system to provide the capacity to do something about that inconsistency. We are told that will be done through the licensing provisions that will be instituted.

PARA.TAB: I can only hope that that is so. I honestly believe, from reading the Minister's statement, that it will be so. But it is not so now, and it appears that there are no teeth in this legislation. I plead with the Minister to ensure that the promises made in the statement are fulfilled in the proposed legislation. I have no reason to suspect that that will not be the case. The aspects that require the backing of legislative teeth are those that the Minister has promised to consider. The Democrats certainly support him in that promise. We shall certainly keep a close eye on and look very carefully at that proposed legislation.

I am pleased that the Minister has identified in the statement that, as a matter of priority, in the interim the Minister will be asking the Commission to develop guidelines for a number of administrative practices, which include time limits for determination of reviews, surveillance practices, the current practice of using medical panels and the procedures for reviews of disputed claims. That little list identifies the typical pattern of the sorts of complaints about the decisions that are made by the self-administering authorities.

I will not take up much more time, but the other thing I want to highlight is the fact that there has been confusion about the role and status of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the body to which people should normally be able to refer when they feel aggrieved by decisions that have been made by administering authorities. I am very pleased to see that in the statement the Minister has said that, because of some remaining confusion about the status of decisions and recommendations made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, he will also ask the Commission to consider that issue as a matter of urgency. I can only underline the fact that this is a matter of urgency, because there are people who have interpreted the statement made previously by Minister Beazley, when speaking about the status of recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, as applying to decisions and not recommendations. That confusion I hope will be removed by the statement made by the Minister for Industrial Relations that he will ask that the Commission consider this issue as a matter of urgency—and I certainly believe that it is urgent.

The pleasure that I find in relation to a number of the comments made in the ministerial statement is tempered by the fact that this is a ministerial statement; we have yet to see the legislation. That is in the future; it is a promise, or an assurance at least. We will have to be vigilant when the legislation is presented. As I said earlier, when I first became aware of the legislation before us I had little expectation that it could lead to such a prolonged discussion about what should or could be in the Bill.

There are most favourable prospects about what could result from legislation which gave teeth to the supervision of this whole process by Comcare, the Minister or the Commission. There are good prospects. We will have to wait. I promise that I will be vigilant in waiting because this is such an important matter and it impinges upon the livelihoods of so many people. All of these organisations have huge numbers of employees and, with such numbers, some of the measurements of productivity and efficiency have been inappropriate in the past. I look forward to seeing much more appropriate measurements of the equity and the appropriateness of the decisions that are made under the auspices of this package of legislation. I foreshadow that the Democrats will seek to move a couple of small amendments in the committee stage. The Democrats support the Bill at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I close the debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 by saying that what has happened here was reasonably predictable. We have spent a fair bit of time over the last week coming to a series of understandings which are embodied in the statement which has been incorporated in Hansard as a record of this debate. It is a statement of commitments by the Government on the points raised by the coalition and the Australian Democrats. It was referred to by both parties in their presentations in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman made a number of references to what the Opposition believed to be the case with respect to the Bill. I do not propose to deal with each of those references individually, other than to say that I think there is a genuine commitment by all parties—certainly the Government, which commissioned the report—to see that the Brown review report is implemented. We are all seized with equal passion that that be done expeditiously. There is no difference between us on that.

I think the genuine misunderstanding between us, which gave rise to the original confusion, is that the amendments that we include in this legislation tonight set up a framework which enables a commission to be appointed to work hand in glove with the Government in the implementation of the Brown review recommendations. The proposed commission will have the responsibility for managing workers' compensation and rehabilitation in the Government and in government business enterprises. Therefore, when this legislation appeared on the horizon it was perceived to be legislation which was meant to implement all of the Brown review and not for what it was—a framework which enables us to implement all of the Brown review. Thus, we got into a debate about whether the legislation is adequate for the implementation of the Brown review. It is not adequate for that. I have no difficulty in saying that. It is adequate to create the framework necessary.

I do not think there has been any dilatoriness on behalf of the Government or on behalf of Comcare. There has been a misunderstanding on that point which has given rise to some confusion which is now cleared up. I also think, like all compensation matters, there are matters of outstanding claims and people feel aggrieved by an unsatisfactory settlement in their view of the claims. This always creates an extra background tension in dealing with legislation of this sort. I think that we have substantially got the matter right. I accept the constructive way in which useful suggestions have been made by the other speakers in the debate. I commend the Bill in its present from to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Before clause 5, page 2, insert the following clauses:

PARA.TAB: "4A. Section 57 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (1) the words `by a legally qualified' and substituting `by one legally qualified.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment simply replaces the word `a' with the word `one'. The reason for doing that is that, when we read section 57 of the principal Act as it exists now, it reads, `a legally qualified person', and that relates to the person who would review a claim for compensation. In fact, Australia Post, in particular, has chosen to interpret that to suit itself. It is used to justify the establishment of a medical board or panel to the considerable detriment of the capacity of some people to present and demonstrate their cases. We believe that this amendment is one quick, succinct way of removing any possibility of misinterpreting what is meant by those words.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard the reasons advanced by Senator Bell for this amendment. We will not oppose the amendment; I am prepared to accept it into the Bill. I do not think it requires me to say any more than that.

—On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our support for the Democrats' amendments. These amendments were developed as a result of the joint discussions of the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats. We support them.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 12, page 5, proposed paragraph 89B(a), lines 29 to 33, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a) to ensure that, as far as practicable, there is no inconsistency in administrative practices and procedures used by Comcare and the administering authority in the performance of their respective functions.".

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this amendment, as it reads quite plainly, is to ensure that, as far as practicable, there is no inconsistency in administrative practices and procedures used by Comcare and the administering authority in the performance of their respective functions. The words speak for themselves. They convey to me the sort of behaviour to be expected from those who are subcontractors—for want of a better word—in this arrangement. The authorities which are permitted to administer their own arrangements—the Comcare practices themselves—really should be seen as a model for behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no objection to this amendment. The Government will support it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 12, page 6, proposed paragraph 89E(1)(c), omit "2 members", substitute "1 member".
2.Clause 12, page 6, proposed paragraph 89E(1)(e), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(e) a member who, in the Minister's opinion, represents Departments of the Service, as defined in the Public Service Act 1922;
(ea) a member who, in the Minister's opinion, represents Commonwealth authorities, as defined in the Public Service Act 1922;".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the constitution of the members of the Commission. As provided in the legislation, the Commission will include two representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and only one representative of the Government. This is in contradiction to the recommendations of the Brown report, which recommended that there be one representative of the ACTU and two government representatives, one being in effect a representative of the government on behalf of departments within the meaning of the Public Service Act and the other being a representative on behalf of the government relating to government business enterprises or Commonwealth authorities.

PARA.TAB: We believe that it is unnecessary to have two representatives of the ACTU on this Commission. We believe that it would be much more appropriate to have one representative of the ACTU and, as Brown recommended, two respective representatives of the government, namely, one from government departments per se and one from government business enterprises. It is on that basis that I move this amendment on behalf of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —At one stage we were tempted to suggest that if the Australian Council of Trade Unions were to have two representatives one of those representatives should be a person who has been, if you like, a client of the workers' compensation system. That suggestion was not pursued for the reasons that it could be difficult to determine such a person's willingness to serve in this way or that such a person may have such a vested interest that proper decisions would be hard to reach. There may also be other reasons, such as an accusation that this was an appointment made not on merit but on some sort of quota arrangement.

PARA.TAB: It is an entertaining prospect that somebody who was on the receiving end, if you like, of the system might be able to bring an evaluation of its processes to part of the decision making. I hope that the union representatives ensure that, in their representation, they take the point of view of both the union members who want to be protected from injury or incapacity of any description at work and those who have suffered some injury or incapacity so that their representation is effective and well informed. Of course, I trust that that will be the case. Therefore, we will not support the amendment proposed by the Opposition but hope that such representations made by the ACTU are most effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support the amendment, for the reason that the Bill contains a Commission board which is properly balanced in the interests of employees and employers. The two members nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions are balanced by a member representing the administrative authorities and a member representing the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth authorities other than the administrative authorities.

PARA.TAB: This is a board of nine. We are talking here about two people representing the employees of the Commonwealth as nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The employees are the users of workers' compensation and rehabilitation and the ones to whom accidents, disease and injury occur and for whom compensation payments are made and rehabilitation procedures are entered into. There cannot be any case made that they are not entitled to a voice, nor can any case be made in a fair society that they are not entitled to an equal voice with the employers.

Even so, the employers' and the employees' representatives combined are still in the minority on the board. It is a board of nine and they constitute four in number between them. So no one party will be the dominant party. We therefore think it represents a proper balance of interests and we reject the amendments.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the Committee that clause 38 be voted upon separately. There being no objection, the question is that clause 38 be agreed to.

—On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate that we will be opposing clause 38. This clause relates to part 5 of the Bill and amends the Navigation Act 1912. We have had particular expressions of dissatisfaction with the way in which this legislation will give effect to ILO convention 73 relating to the Medical Examinations (Seafarers) Convention 1946. Our advice is that there has not been adequate consultation between the Commonwealth Government and the Government of the Northern Territory with regard to this matter.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has indicated to me that it was his intention that there would be further consultation in regard to the regulations. Our advice is that is unsatisfactory to the Northern Territory Government and it is not happy to see this portion of the legislation passed. It is on that basis—as I spelt out during the second reading debate—that I have indicated that we wish to delete this clause; although we are letting the convention relating to crew accommodation pass because we do not have a problem with that. We have a problem with clause 38; therefore, we seek to delete that clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the stance taken by the coalition.

—It is with great reluctance that I will support the deletion of the clause. The position has now been articulated by Senator Chapman. I do so reluctantly because I recognise that, with the Australian Democrats' support, there is a majority in the chamber and we would lose were this to go to a vote. That is the first reason for reluctance, because there is some sense of need, in this case, for the convention to be supported. But we would lose it on a vote. I think reality should intrude into our considerations because the charge against us is not a charge that the substance of what we seek is unreasonable, but simply that the consultation process has not been as exhaustive as the Territory Government in this case would want.

PARA.TAB: One can have different views about the exhaustiveness or otherwise of consultative arrangements, but the importance of this element of the Bill is that it does not enact any change. What it would have done, were it to have gone ahead, would have been to clothe the Government with the power to make regulations which would bring about some change. Therefore, we are seeking simply a clothing of power to do things through regulations. The undertaking given by the Commonwealth to all of the States and the Territories—and I repeat it here for the record—was that we would not proceed with the regulations until such time as we had reached an agreement with the Territories and the States about the nature of those regulations.

Not proceeding with this provision now means possible delay in achieving the outcome which I think we all, in terms of the merit of it, support. That is unfortunate, but it is not a total disaster and it is not something without which we cannot live. While it would have been convenient, reasonable and appropriate to have proceeded with this, in view of the objections raised and the fact that I am outvoted anyway, I might as well be gracious about it and reluctantly, on those terms, accept the deletion of the clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I accept the Minister's graciousness in that regard and his support for our position.

PARA.TAB: Clause 38 negatived.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to address the Senate and commend the work of the North Australian Development Unit of the Department of Social Security. This particular unit has been based in northern Australia and has operated principally from offices in Darwin for a period of three years.

PARA.TAB: The Government has recently made an announcement that this office is to be altered and functionally changed. In effect, it is to be disbanded and dissolved from within the Department of Social Security, and a new functional office—an office of northern development—is to be created within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

Despite the particularly hard circumstances under which the North Australian Development Unit has operated over many years, it has achieved results in the performance of its work in which many Australians can take a great deal of pride. The unit came into existence in late 1988 and commenced operation, I believe, in early 1989. For three years a number of senior officers—first, Mr Glenn Hurry; and more recently a series of other officers, Mr Ken Ross, Mr Barry Smith and Mr Ross Worthington—have contributed to the management of this unit. There have, of course, been a number of other very competent staff officers attached to the work of the unit.

I note from the Senate Estimates Hansard dated 14 May 1990 that I raised a number of issues with regard to the resource development and resource allocations of the Department of Social Security to this particular unit.

At that time it was indicated clearly by the officers of the Department of Social Security that the functional role of this group was to continue and that adequate resources would continue into the subsequent financial year for its ongoing work. I note that in the performance indicators of the Department of Social Security for the year 1991-92 the following mention is made with regard to the North Australia Development Unit:

SPEECH.PARA: NADU is a small national administration outpost located in Darwin. The unit concentrates on the development of policies and strategies to improve the applicability and delivery of departmental programs and services to people residing in north Australia. NADU's work program is based on the outcomes of both departmental and community consultations.

I also note that the recently tabled annual report for 1990-91 entitled 50 Years of Service to Australia 1941-1991 by the Department of Social Security makes two scant comments with regard to this particular unit. One comment is made under the issue `The National Administration' in the chapter on the corporate overview of the Department and is to be found in one paragraph on page 9. On page 39 of the annual report, there is a slightly more comprehensive cover of the work of the unit and the work that it was undertaking for the financial year. I do not believe that those comments, either in the performance indicators or in the annual report for 1990-91, give proper and due credit to the work of this important section of the Department.

PARA.TAB: I have taken the opportunity to review the various papers and projects that have been prepared by this unit in the three years of its existence. I highlight those particular research programs. The following research and discussion papers were undertaken:

SPEECH.PARA: .Remote Area Allowance.
.A Community Based Rehabilitation Program for Alcoholics & Other Disadvantaged Groups.
.Response to CO Discussion on Polygamous Marriages—Paper 1 and Polygamy in Transition—Paper 2.
.Where to Now? DSS Payments & Programs and ATSI Communities.
.Rural Women's Access to Social Security: Directions for Future Study.
.Invalid Pensions and CDA. Remote Area Problems With Determination.
.Perceptions of the Community Agents Program.
.AES, Industries and Employment: Remote North Australia.
.ATSI People in North Australia's Remote Area: Population Trends and Their Policy Implications.
.CDEP and DSS.
There were also a number of very important occasional papers produced under the work of NADU. They were:
.The Concept of Community in Aboriginal Policy & Service Delivery.
.Welfare Service Delivery: Options for Remote Areas.
.Social Research in Remote Areas—To What End?
.Has Policy and Legislation Guaranteed ATSI people equal access to DSS Benefits and Services?
.Filipino Brides in Remote Areas.
.Department of Social Security Payments and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Communities: A Review of Literature.

Each and every one of those research and discussion papers and occasional papers has provided an invaluable resource to many government departments and I hope to the Government itself in developing programs. Many of them may, of course, be embarrassing to the Government for its ongoing program. There are currently a number of other projects in the various stages of being completed, and I understand they will be concluded before the unit is disbanded at the end of January 1992. They are:
.Community, Co-ordination, Planning and Evaluation.
.Newstart (AES) in Remote Aboriginal Communities.
.Internal Migration to Northern Provincial Centres.
.Royalties.
.Hawking & Profiteering Practices—
that is trade practices—

PARA.TAB: in Remote Areas.

SPEECH.PARA: .Australian Family Living Standards Study (Joint AIFS/NADU).

The last in that list is a study in consultation with the Australian Institute of Family Studies which I believe is looking into food costs relative to urban centres and the costs of housing for social security recipients. Other projects are: social and economic circumstances of the aged in remote communities; and a community plan for the community on Mornington Island in north Queensland, another project being undertaken in conjunction with DEET.

PARA.TAB: These current projects that will be wound up and concluded within the next six or eight weeks are vitally important. They must be published. I believe there is some indication that the Department may well not choose to publish these important projects that are still to be properly concluded. I would certainly be asking in the forthcoming Estimates for copies of each and every one of those project papers to be produced and certainly made available to all members of parliament and anyone else who has to work through the various policy implications.

As I said at the commencement of my speech, I certainly want to commend the work of all of the people who contributed to this important unit over the past three years. They have done an outstanding job, often under difficult circumstances, often with scant resources, often having to cope with the various bureaucratic policies and politics between departments, and also with the constraints that obviously have been imposed by government policy. That is the praise.

The criticism that I want make about this issue relates to the fact that this year, on 9 October, a question was asked very seriously by Senator Reynolds of Senator Collins with regard to the broadening of the research activities that have in the past been undertaken by the North Australian Development Unit. In reply Senator Collins said:

Late last year, along with others, I expressed considerable interest in broadening the Northern Australia Development Unit's activities which, until now, have been specific to the Department of Social Security, to encompass other portfolio areas of interest to Northern Australia. A particular concern was to provide through NADU some cross-portfolio coordination of these issues. After extensive consultation with the Prime Minister and several ministerial colleagues, particularly Senator Graham Richardson, the Minister for Social Security, it was decided to broaden the functions of this unit to enable it to conduct and sponsor research on potential economic and other developments in Northern Australia as well as research on social security and program delivery in line with the economic development and social justice strategies of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 November this year, Senator Reynolds directed another question to the Minister with the responsible portfolio, Senator Richardson. His response was:

It is not only a matter of making guarantees to Senator Reynolds about the value for money project. I think I can make a guarantee that all of the work that has been undertaken by that unit will be continued and furthered. Having Senator Collins involved is probably better in any event because, as the Minister for northern development, he is in touch with so many of the communities which will benefit from the work of NADU.

My criticism is that what has eventuated in the change of the administrative structure from the Department of Social Security to the Office of Northern Development in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet under Senator Collins is a very significant change in the staff resources. For example, the current unit of 11 people is comprised of a senior officer grade B, six other research officers at grade C level, two ASO6s, one ASO3 and one research assistant. That has been the unit that has produced the outstanding level of work that I alluded to and praised earlier.

PARA.TAB: We have now ascertained that, for the same Budget value that is being transferred to the Department of the Prime Minister, the new structure is to include, firstly, a chief executive officer. It has been announced that Mr Bill Gray, from ATSIC, will fill that particular position at secretary of department level. That would be a significant salary commitment; I presume in the order of some $90,000. The deputy will be at SES officer level 1, which would be a salary component of $64,000-odd plus benefits. There will be two officers at the SOG B level—two at the current senior officer level of the present unit—on salaries of $53,000, and under them two other clerical assistants, an ASO5 and an ASO4.

As a result of the transfer of this function we now have a top-heavy group which will naturally be concerned with macro-policy issues but will not have the capacity to undertake any of the excellent field work that has been done in the past. None of the officers of the previous unit of the Department of Social Security would have been capable or competent enough—that is not a criticism of any one of them—to seek positions in the new structure. Therefore, we are going to lose those people as they transfer back to the Department of Social Security and other departments.

We will end up with a new unit—an Office of Northern Development—in the Department of the Prime Minister that will be concentrating largely in two areas. There is to be a northern Australia social justice strategy and also an economic development strategy for northern Australia. If that is anything to go on, I am afraid there is still a lot of fear and criticism of where this new unit will be taking us. The new unit will continue to do policy work but it will not have the capacity to do the hands-on field work for which Senator Reynolds, I and so many others have praised NADU in the past.

The level of involvement in the service delivery area is vital and must not be lost. It will therefore be incumbent on the Minister, Senator Collins, to ensure that we have a unit that will be effective and not just another front of senior officers, as we have seen in so many of these departmental areas of change by the Labor Government.

Senator Collins commissioned a major economic study some time ago from the James Cook University, which he announced in Estimates hearings. He promised me a copy of an interim report of that group some 12 weeks ago. Whilst I know of other people who have received copies of it, I have been unable to obtain a copy of that taxpayer funded document. It will be very interesting to compare the value of its work with that of NADU. Certainly, we will need to assess the work of this new unit of the Office of Northern Development and ensure that it is not just another marginal seat strategy of the Labor Government, seeking to initiate ALP campaign policies rather than the decent and proper detailed work that the North Australian Development Unit has now been nobbled from doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I briefly want to get on to the Hansard record my congratulations to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council for a recent booklet it has published. It was published in conjunction with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Section of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I am sure that other senators have also received the booklet, which is entitled Regulatory Control of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals: Questions and Answers. In part, it is a response to an inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, of which I was the Deputy Chairman and you, Mr Deputy President, were the Chairman.

PARA.TAB: The Senate may well have forgotten that Committee; it seems that the Government has. The Committee worked very hard and brought down a most commendable and responsible report. Given the genesis of the Committee, it is to the credit of the Chairman, Senator Colston, and others on the Committee that we are able to work cohesively and produce such a worthwhile document.

It is not just the Committee that thinks the report is good. The recent reports of the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Group also referred to the report, as have other groups, including the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. I have to ask, then, why the Federal Government has so far not brought down a response to that report. The report was tabled in July 1990 and the time for response is now well overdue. On 20 February of this year I asked Senator Cook a question. In response, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Government response to the Senate Committee report is being prepared now and should be completed by early March. The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council has had an input into the Government's response.

As we are very close to the end of the year and the Minister said that nearly one year ago, what has happened to the Government response to that report? The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council of the DPI has responded by producing a worthwhile guide. Its annual report, tabled in the Senate today, also praises the Senate Committee reports and says that it has considered the Committee's recommendations thoroughly. I commend the 1991 annual report of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council to honourable senators. I hope they can apply pressure to the Minister to get on with delivering a response to this chamber and to move on some of our recommendations. The subject of agricultural and veterinary chemicals is important and booklets such as this are essential for the broader education of the public. I commend this booklet to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which I first noticed reported in the Launceston Examiner of Monday, 25 November this year. It is a matter which has become of increasing concern to many residents of northern Tasmania. We were told in that article that the Latrobe Council had previously agreed to ask the Tasmanian Forestry Commission to restrict the clear-felling of trees on the upper slopes of the Dazzler Range above the 270-metre level. The Dazzler Range is a range of mountains in northern Tasmania which is clearly visible from the tourist areas of Port Sorell and Hawley Beach. That range is a backdrop to the Asbestos Range National Park. Cable logging operations in that area have left devastating scars on the hillside. The article gave this description:

SPEECH.PARA: The logged area is clearly visible from Port Sorell to Hawley, appearing as a grey quarry among an otherwise unbroken series of tree-covered hills.

I concur with that description. I visited the area just after the newspaper article was written, and that is an apt description—`a grey quarry among the otherwise tree-covered hills'. This logging creates considerable aesthetic pollution, and residents of the area, one of the fastest growing regions of the State, are understandably upset. I daresay that that is the reason why their council has approached the Forestry Commission. There is a great deal of concern about the wisdom of conducting logging operations on such steep slopes. The coupe in question has a slope of 48 degrees and this slope is very difficult to stand on. Such practice is in clear breach of the draft practices code of forestry in Tasmania, which sets an upper limit of 38 degrees.

PARA.TAB: The erosion problems from such bad logging practices in this area could be disastrous. A private land-holder in the Dazzler Range located on Branch Creek is already taking action because of precisely this problem of erosion possibilities. The logging on steep slopes has led to soil erosion and Branch Creek is filling up with silt and logging debris. That results in flash flooding and the washing away of the creek beds.

I am sure honourable senators who are listening have already associated in their minds the devastation recently in the Philippines, and the flooding and erosion which resulted in such tragedy, which has been ascribed to poor logging practices. The denudation of the hills and mountains in the Philippines is a larger manifestation of the very thing that I am talking about tonight.

My point is that we really should have regard to this whole problem. If we need further explanation, it is available. It should be apparent to everybody that there are many regions where, with that sort of slope and the sort of rainfall that is experienced in the area, regeneration is made slow and difficult. With increased run-off, very little soil is left behind for plants to grow in and those that do take hold are left exposed to the high winds of the area.

We are talking about an area that is very close to the shores of Bass Strait. Even those unfamiliar with Tasmania's topography would readily appreciate that in such an area regeneration of anything, let alone the original vegetative cover, is nigh impossible. It takes at least seven to 10 years before full ground cover and full ground protection are achieved. There is a possibility that the original cover will never be re-established.

The consequences of these practices have been entrenched in the Tasmanian resource security legislation. They will be further set in concrete and could easily be further verified with Federal legislation. That is of great concern. Neither piece of legislation seems to address the problem of forest practices. The problem must be addressed. We see evidence daily on our television sets and we also see considerable discussion in the press of the problem that we have in Australia of the blue-green algae in the Darling River system and beyond. Surely, it is apparent to all that such a devastating environmental problem is a result of not being able to foresee the consequences of previously endorsed land management practices.

The land management practices in the forest are those which determine the suitability of logging, the style of logging, the area which must be differentiated and the different practices to be instituted. That same parallel can be seen in our farming practices. We should learn these lessons. They are there for us to see. I raise this matter because it is yet another example of people pursuing in an ignorant fashion something which should be demonstrable to all and from which we all should have learned ages ago. How these forests are managed in the bush affects all people directly. It affects us in how the forest looks. It affects us in the quality of our lives. It affects us in the situation of the water catchment areas and it affects us in our future prospects for land use.

We cannot afford to ignore any opportunity that we, as a community as a whole, have to take part in and to have some say in these matters. At the moment the prospect of the Tasmanian resource security legislation and the prospect of Federal legislation are likely to reduce the opportunity that anybody has to participate further in that debate. What is happening right now in the Dazzler Range and in pockets of other communities in Tasmania is what is not being addressed by anybody's forest legislation.

It seems apparent that, apart from a very small piece in the Launceston Examiner in which it was pointed out, as I previously mentioned, that we are looking at a quarry where we were previously looking at full vegetative cover, this matter is not being addressed. It is apparent that our State Government in Tasmania is more concerned with what large companies want to do with the trees after they have stripped the hillsides bare. We have little opportunity in the community to take part in the debate. Not only is that disappointing but it is also tragic. In Australia we see the absolute tragedy of poor land management and poor land use. It can only be a lesson from which, I am sure, we will all say, `I wish we had thought about that some decades ago'. Here we have another opportunity to think about it and be aware what resource security legislation in this place would mean for Australia as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to take a few minutes of the Senate's time on a matter of some importance and of some particular significance to me. During the days preceding the New South Wales ALP Conference, which was convened on 7 and 8 December 1991, the Australian Financial Review ran a series of articles that were inaccurate, damaging to me and defamatory of me, regarding matters which, ultimately, were debated at the New South Wales Labor Party Conference. This happened repeatedly, and in the majority of circumstances the journalists concerned, Prudence Anderson and Michael Dwyer, did not afford me the opportunity either to rebut the anonymous and false allegations or to defend myself; indeed, the Australian Financial Review appeared to lend itself willingly to a campaign of McCarthyist smearing, which assumed the proportions of a vendetta.

PARA.TAB: This is not the first occasion on which the Australian Financial Review has published material that was damaging to me. In fact, on a previous occasion this newspaper was obliged to publish a correction concerning inaccurate material which it had printed falsely as fact. I rise tonight because this is the first opportunity that I have had to respond to these defamatory articles, having obtained the benefit of legal advice and not wishing to interrupt the Government's legislative program. It is my intention to commence legal proceedings against the Australian Financial Review over a number of false allegations that it published in late November and early December.

I propose to deal with a number of allegations tonight, although might I say that it is not possible to deal with all of them in the course of one address to the Senate. Some matters I must leave exclusively to my lawyers. The first article in question appeared on 29 November under the by-line of Michael Dwyer, with various claims, all of them false. The claim, for example, that I had reneged on a cross-factional deal to resign as ALP National President is, of course, untrue. This claim suggests dishonesty and duplicity on my part. The claim was false and remains so. In fact, no such suggestion was ever made to me; no such undertaking was ever given by me; therefore it was not possible for me to breach any such commitment.

The second claim by Dwyer in this article was that the real value of the ALP Centenary House was probably less than $2m. This is also a false claim and remains so. In fact, the ALP Centenary House was valued professionally for the ALP at $3.8m. This valuation was confirmed by the Commonwealth Bank at the time and, indeed, an offer for more money was received for the building after the purchase had been made. Michael Dwyer did not offer me the opportunity to answer these claims.

The second article in question appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 2 December 1991 under the by-line of Prudence Anderson. The article accused me of misleading the New South Wales ALP about its rising debt. This claim is also false. Never at any time did I mislead the New South Wales ALP about its real financial situation. Indeed, for virtually all my period as General Secretary the New South Wales ALP operated in a financially sound manner. Anderson then cited anonymous sources accusing me of mismanaging my financial responsibility as New South Wales ALP General Secretary. This is also untrue.

During seven years as Party Secretary of the New South Wales ALP that claim was never made by any person. No-one could have given more meticulous care to the financial situation confronting the New South Wales ALP than I did during my period of service. No-one could have been more open or forthright about our financial position than I was during that period. In this article, Anderson then claimed, again referring to anonymous sources, that I was guilty of a deliberate financial cover-up. This is also untrue. In fact, the contrary is the case. When the real extent of the Party's financial difficulties in New South Wales emerged, I urged the current General Secretary, Mr John Della Bosca, to make the situation public and to begin a fundraising campaign, on the basis of the pressures upon us. Mr Della Bosca is happy to confirm this.

Moreover, at the time I also urged earlier and more regular meetings of the New South Wales ALP finance committee, which I chaired between the middle period of 1990 and the end of 1991. Senator Sue West, a member of the finance committee, is only too happy to confirm this reality.

In addition, the Australian Financial Review ignored the salient reality that all of the New South Wales ALP's financial accounts are made public on an annual basis to the Party conference. That occurred every year during the period in which I was Secretary. It certainly occurred in June 1990 when the purchase of the ALP Centenary House was ratified by the Party conference. No material was withheld; no material was concealed. Access to all details of the Party's financial circumstances was afforded members of the New South Wales ALP administrative committee and finance committee for the entire period during which I was Secretary.

Citing anonymous sources again, Anderson maintained that the ALP Centenary House was never intended to be occupied in celebration of the New South Wales ALP centenary year, that it was merely bought as a speculative initiative. This is untrue, as any cursory examination of documents presented to the June 1990 conference in support of the purchase will attest. Moreover, I specifically rejected a proposition for the sale of the building—that is, ALP Centenary House—for more money after the purchase was concluded on the simple basis that 291 Sussex Street, Sydney was not bought as a speculative initiative.

The journalists concerned, Dwyer and Anderson, wrote an article on 4 December 1991 which again cited anonymous sources accusing me of withholding information from the Labor Council of New South Wales. This again is untrue. In fact, the Labor Council of New South Wales did not become officially involved in the Labor Centenary House project until long after I had resigned as Secretary of the Party. The article repeated the defamation that I had agreed to the purchase of Labor Centenary House prior to approval by the New South Wales ALP administrative committee. This is manifestly untrue, as any cursory examination of the ALP administrative committee minutes will confirm. Anderson and Dwyer went on to claim that I had assured the administrative committee that the New South Wales Labor Council had agreed to take up a one-third share in the project.
