This is again manifestly untrue. Again, a simple reading of the New South Wales Labor Party administrative committee minutes will verify the truth of what I am saying.

The false and defamatory claims concerning the purchase of the building and the briefing of the New South Wales administrative committee are repeated in an article on 5 December 1991. The inaccuracy of the claims made by Anderson and Dwyer can be seen vividly, in that they refer to the Labor Council of New South Wales purchasing a one-third share in Labor Centenary House in May 1991. Given that I had retired as General Secretary of the New South Wales ALP in June 1990, I would have thought it obvious that it would not have been possible for me to have misled the Labor Council regarding its formal involvement or to be held responsible, as the Australian Financial Review apparently holds me responsible, for the problems that subsequently arose due to financial pressures on the New South Wales Labor Party.

The Senate might take note that in all of these false claims and untrue allegations no-one is identified as having made them. All of the sources are anonymous. This is surely a very low point in journalistic standards. Put simply, McCarthyism cannot flourish without journalists and publications willingly lending themselves to a process by which scurrilous claims are printed as fact without attribution. The Senate might also take care to note that when the campaign against me failed on the morning of Saturday, 7 December 1991, the Australian Financial Review chose to report this as a minor item on its inside pages the following Monday morning.

I concede that I made a serious political error in the days preceding the New South Wales ALP Conference. I underestimated dramatically the levels to which my political opponents would sink in their campaign of personal denigration and defamation of me. In conclusion, no-one among my political opponents ought to underestimate my resolve on these matters. My lawyers have been instructed to take the appropriate action immediately.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much was spent by the department in 1990-91, for the purpose of producing New Times for Older Australians.
(2) How much was spent on postage.
(3) How many copies of the publication are produced for each edition.
(4) How many copies of the publication are distributed and sent to interest groups throughout the community.
(5) How many copies are sent to offices of Members and Senators for distribution and do all Members and Senators receive copies.
(6) Are copies sent to age pensioners as a matter of course; if so, at what expense.
(7) How many staff are involved in producing the publication.
(8) How many editions of the publication are produced annually.
(9) Who is responsible for printing and publishing the magazine.
(10) If it is done externally, what are all the details of the tendering process for the contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) During 1990-91 two editions of New Times for Older Australians were published. Printing costs were $85,693 ($46,440 for vol 1 No. 4, August 1990; and $39,253 for vol 1 No. 5, March 1991). The cost of each edition is different because the number of pages in each varied.

(2) Identifiable postage costs for the two editions in 1990-91 were $98,903 ($65,653 for vol 1 No. 4, and $33,250 for vol 1 No. 5). The postage costs for each edition were different because the weight of each edition varied. Vol 1 No. 4 was 16 pages and weighed 54 grams. Vol 1 No. 5 was 12 pages and weighed 30 grams.

Other postage costs were charged to general departmental postage and are not able to be separated. Other copies were distributed at special events or delivered personally to organisations by project officers and therefore incurred no postage costs.
(3) In 1990-91, 200 000 copies of each edition.
(4) The numbers of copies sent to interest groups were 85,219 for vol 1 No. 4 and 100,969 for vol 1 No. 5.

(5) The numbers of copies sent to Members and Senators were 70,860 for vol 1 No. 4 and 18,062 for vol 1 No. 5. The numbers distributed for each edition vary according to requests received from Members and Senators. There is no restriction as to which Members or Senators can receive copies.
(6) No. Individuals are placed on the mailing list at their request.
(7) One staff member devotes 3-4 weeks time per issue.
(9) Publishers are Australian Government Publishing Service. Printers of vol 1 No. 4 were Pirie Printers (Fyshwick, ACT), printers of vol 1 No. 5 were Ambassador Press, (Granville, NSW).
(10) Printers selected by AGPS through the usual Government tendering process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Were discussions initiated by the Minister between relevant States and the Commonwealth in accordance with Resolution No. 1 of 12 June 1991 of the Fisheries Council concerning the compulsory surrender arrangements due to take place in the Northern Prawn Fishery in 1993; if so, what possible, or likely, unintended impacts of the arrangements were identified and what action is proposed to prevent such impacts occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In accordance with Resolution No. 1 of the Australian Fisheries Council meeting, held on 12 July 1991, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy wrote to the relevant State Ministers proposing a meeting of the appropriate fisheries officials from the Commonwealth, Queensland, West Australia and the Northern Territory to discuss impacts of the compulsory surrender arrangements in the Northern Prawn Fishery. The Minister further advised that the initial meeting was subsequently held on 24 October 1991.

The main area of impact of the second round buy-back is the effect on other fisheries for which NPF fishermen are endorsed, particularly in West Australia and Queensland. Legal advice had been obtained from the Attorney General's Department on this issue. This advice raised questions regarding aspects of the AFC policy on licence splitting. A further meeting of Commonwealth and State officials is planned to consider if these could be addressed through practicable legislative or other measures. The Minister further advised that the state fisheries Departments and their respective industry groups are continuing to develop strategies, specific to their states, to cope with boats displaced as a result of the buy-back. They are due to report back by mid December 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Minister recently announce a second round of applications for NSCP Community Landcare Projects funded by the National Soil Conservation Program.
(2) Has the Western Australian Government decided to cancel the second round.
(3) Is the Minister satisfied with the low level of support for the National Soil Conservation Program from the Western Australian Government.
(4) Why have these funds been targeted solely at farming areas when there are also many problems in coastal dune areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. A second call for applications for project grants under the Community Landcare sub- program of the National Soil Conservation Program

ANSWER.PARA: (NSCP) was advertised on or about Saturday 24 August 1991.

PARA.TAB: (2) Some 29 applications for grants have been recommended from Western Australia as worthy of consideration for funding in the second round.

The Soil and Land Conservation Council (the State assessment panel responsible for assessment of NSCP landcare project applications in Western Australia) already had high quality applications before it from landcare groups which met the NSCP guideline requirements and which exceeded the amount of funds WA could expect to receive in the second round. Rather than make a further public call for applications that would raise expectations that could not be fulfilled the Council decided to consider those projects already before it.
(3) The Western Australian Government actively supports the NSCP .

(4) The NSCP guide-lines for landcare groups which applied for the second call were unchanged apart from a preference being given to projects of one year's duration. While there are problems in coastal dune areas, dune reclamation is not a priority objective of the NSCP. The primary focus of the NSCP is to assist in combating land degradation on commercial agricultural and pastoral land.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 21st meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council held in Wellington, New Zealand, in July 1991:
(1) Given that only two New Zealanders attended (as observers) and that only two of the resolutions passed mentioned New Zealand, why was the meeting held in Wellington.
(2) What was the cost to the Australian Government for the 39 Australians who attended.

(3) Will the Minister give an assurance that future conferences concerned with essentially Australian interests and attended primarily by Australians will always be held in Australia to benefit the Australian hospitality industry and to place the least burden on Australian taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The 21st meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council (AFC) was held in Wellington New Zealand at the invitation of the New Zealand Government. Meetings are usually held annually on rotation in each State and the Northern Territory.

There are important reasons why a meeting of the AFC was held in Wellington. Australia and New Zealand enjoy a close working relationship on a range of fisheries matters of mutual interest such as, for example, the development of global management arrangements for southern bluefin tuna, the management of straddling stocks of orange roughy, South Pacific co-operation, surveillance and monitoring of fisheries in the Tasman Sea and efforts designed to bring about a cessation of driftnet fishing on the high seas.

New Zealand has participated actively in AFC meetings as an observer since 1984. Following an understanding reached at Prime Ministerial level consideration is being given to New Zealand becoming a full participating member of a number of Ministerial Councils, including fisheries. The main benefits from having New Zealand as a full member involve a desire on the part of both our countries to deepen and broaden the trans-Tasman relationship across a number of fronts and especially to reinforce Closer Economic Relations.

(2) All State and Territory Governments bear the costs of their own participation in AFC meetings. Costs to the Commonwealth covered the Commonwealth delegations to the Standing Committee on Fisheries and the Australian Fisheries Council involving travel and accommodation as well as the operation of the Secretariat. Total costs to the Commonwealth amounted to $23 506. However, the New Zealand Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) provided extensive assistance to the Secretariat and all transport within New Zealand for the Commonwealth and some State Ministers. Hospitality is traditionally paid for by the host State, in the case of 1991, New Zealand.

(3) Given that the meeting venue rotates amongst all members, the majority of AFC meetings will be held in Australia. South Australia will be the host state for the 1992 meeting which is scheduled to be held in Port Lincoln.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Government given approval for the export of any mines for military purposes during the period 1983 to the present; if so (a) how many mines were exported; (b) what countries did they go to; and (c) which companies supplied them.

(2)(a) Where does the Australian Defence Force acquire its mines from for military purposes; (b) if they are imported, which country does Australia buy them from; and (c) if they are made in Australia, which companies make them.
(3) How many members of the Australian Defence Force are trained in detecting mines and removing them (a) on land; and (b) at sea.
(4) In which overseas countries have members of the Australian Defence Force been involved in mine detection and removal in the years 1983 to the present.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are no records of any approvals to export mines for military purposes.
(2)(a) The Australian Defence Force acquires its mines from both overseas and local sources.
(b) Imported mines have been obtained from the USA and South Korea. Procurement of mines from Italy is in progress.
(c) Mines made in Australia have been obtained from Australian Defence Industries and its predecessor the Office of Defence Production.

(3)(a) The Australian Army is responsible for the detection and removal of mines on land and trains approximately 300 personnel per year. Detailed records of total numbers trained are not kept. Thirteen Royal Australian Air Force personnel are trained in the detection and removal of ordnance from airfields.
(b) Two hundred and thirteen personnel of the Royal Australian Navy are currently trained in either the detection, or the removal or both detection and removal of sea mines.

(4) Since 1983 members of the Australian Defence Force have been involved in the detection and removal of mines in Namibia, United Kingdom and Kuwait. Army personnel have been involved in the training of Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Afghanistan in the detection and removal of mines.
